Title: You Cannot Do It Alone
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political tips you can use in everyday life: Part One As promised, this is the first in a series of learnings from the campaign trail you can apply to the workplace or your relationships with family and friends. I’m doing this ”journal style”—a little more informally, just as if we were having a conversation on a drive. Hope you will enjoy. MOTIVATING PEOPLE — You don’t get far in a political campaign (or a neighborhood project or a complicated/last-minute/weekend/unpleasant work task) without volunteers. People volunteer for a variety of reasons, but motivating and keeping them motivated takes effort. Make sure they see the bigger reason. They aren't getting involved to help you or even themselves. They are in it for the bigger cause. In campaigns such as the many important US Senate races this year, volunteers should get involved to stop the Democrats from taking back the US Senate (remember, I'm a GOP strategist). In my workout group, F3, men worked all weekend to help their neighbors clean up after Hurricane Matthew. They knew they weren't in F3 just to get fit. They're there to better our community, too. The next really important thing is recognition. Let’s face it—in everyday life, few of us are the quarterback whose team just won the Super Bowl, or the rock star, or the President of the United States. We’re not getting the balloon drop, the Gatorade shower or the laser show and confetti cannons. But you would be surprised how much good a little thing like remembering to say, “We couldn’t have done it without Betsy” does. Be as thoughtful as you can be about knowing who to thank (meaning don’t leave anyone out) and when and how. But it can be as simple as a group email or a short talk with the team. Appreciation goes a step beyond recognition. You're not just telling someone they did a great job. You're telling them how much that great job meant to you and to the cause. You're giving them the bigger reason behind the recognized task. You can take this even one step further by saying "I appreciate you" instead of "I appreciate what you just did." Let people know that you appreciate them as people instead of just as machine who completed a given task. No campaign can be won by a single person. Neither can most of life's big tasks. Change takes many people. Rally your troops with a cause, recognition and appreciation.
Excerpt: No campaign can be won by a single person. Neither can most of life's big tasks. Change takes many people. Rally your troops with a cause, recognition and appreciation

Title: It All Begins With The Right Message
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Two Here are some more ideas you can use to win at home, at work, in your neighborhood, etc. MESSAGING—It’s crucial in politics to have a SHORT message about who the candidate is (in this case, who you are). Similarly, if it is a ballot proposal or an issue advocacy position, you have to explain it in three words. Four if necessary. Okay, maybe seven like in the picture above. Yes, in politics you will have many, many other things and you will have longer policy statements and positions and press releases. But to start, you need a catchy, concise message. One of my favorites is for South Carolina Senator Shane Massey. “Shake Up Columbia.” Three words, easy to understand, provocative and positive. Whoever wrote that is a freakin’ genius! This is the same messaging format YOU need to motivate your team, to rally the neighbors, to convince your family about a major decision. And you don’t need yard signs—it’s enough to say it and remind people. BUILD THE PLAYGROUND. BUY THE COTTAGE. FINISH THE PROPOSAL. The messages could also be for a general theme or goal and not just a task. NO MORE WEEKENDS (meaning work harder/smarter during the week). YES TO DESSERT (if vegetables eaten first). EVERY IDEA COUNTS (to generate more). In a pinch, you can try one that rhymes. But instead of the “elevator speech”—which is helpful but long—this is a good way to simplify and clarify your objective. Shorter than a tweet. Shorter than a billboard. NOT “I intend to go to our state capital after the election and start a process whereby I will challenge the status quo and… ” INSTEAD: Shake Up Columbia. (Boy, do I love that line!)
Excerpt: Here are some more ideas you can use to win at home, at work, in your neighborhood, etc.
Image Title: It All Begins With The Right Message

Title: Find People Who Get Sh*t Done And You Can Accomplish Just About Anything
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life Part 3 Here’s the next installment of suggestions, direct from the campaign trail to your desk or kitchen table. It’s all about people who get sh...things done. In digital politics and in marketing, who are we looking for? Who do we need? I could give you a half-hour on field communications structure, but I'll make it simple and quick. We want people who get sh*t done. So, how does that relate to you? You’re also looking for the same people. You just have a smaller universe and easier access. Think of it this way: if you’re at a PTA meeting, or a church men’s group meeting or some ad hoc group meeting at work, the same people show up. Guy who talks too much. Guy who never talks. Guy who questions everything. Not-paying-attention guy. Do it my way guy. Right? The people you’re looking for are the ones who drive action—the roll your sleeves up, get your hands dirty, follow me people. The people other people listen to. Those are the people you have to get on your side. When you have a project to tackle, would it be ideal to have more time or more money? Sure it would. But what really helps? People you can count on to get sh*t done. They volunteer. Better yet, they're self starters. They set the chairs up before the meeting. Bring their rakes or chain saws around to all the houses on the street after a big windstorm. They make the calls or pass out the mailers. First to arrive. Last to leave. No complaints. No questions. No excuses. And, believe me--worth their weight in gold. Need a real life example? My wife. She's on everyone's short list in the community. Groups, boards, whatever. Everyone wants her involved because she is constantly marking items off the todo list, always crossing the finish line. No excuses. No delays. Just progress and completion. She's the person you can absolutely count on to get shit done. Get yourself an army of people who bust their asses at church events, at the gym, at children's activities, at work, in the community--and you can accomplish anything. More time or a bigger budget is nothing compared to that kind of energy and work ethic. When push comes to shove, take my advice: get more people who know how to get sh*t done. Trust me. You won't be sorry. Until next time— W.
Excerpt: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life Part 3
Image Title: Find People Who Get Sh*t Done And You Can Accomplish Just About Anything

Title: I Get Knocked Down But I Get Up Again
Content:
I didn’t post my weekly fitness update last week because I was sulking and whining like a little punk. Yep, I went down again. It wasn’t an illness this time. It was some serious pain in my right leg.

Three weeks ago I crushed it hard with 51 miles in one week. My leg started bothering me toward the end of the week but I finished out with a 13-miler anyway. You know, that whole "push through the pain" mentality. That was a mistake.

I went down hard. Pain started in my knee and crept up to the top of my leg and around my thigh. It was pretty strange because it would hurt in difference places throughout the day. Often, especially in the morning, I couldn’t put any pressure on my leg at all. Being busy with a newborn, a two-year-old, a hurricane an an election, I didn’t go to the doctor and instead self-diagnosed as having an IT band injury. I prescribed to myself 10 days off and use of one of those roller things.

It seems to have worked. My leg isn’t pain free yet, but I was able to knock out two four-milers and an eight-miler this week so far (it’s Tuesday).

So where does that leave my event schedule? Unfortunately I’ve made the decision to drop from the Savannah Rock and Roll Marathon to the half marathon. The following week will be the Sweet Tea half marathon in Summerville, SC and in December I’ll have the Kiawah Marathon. I’m a little disappointed that I’ll only get two marathons in this year, but that was my goal anyway so I can’t cry too much.

Hopefully I’ll remain illness and injury-free for the remainder of the year and crush what’s left of 2017. Thanks for reading!

W.
Excerpt: I didn’t post my weekly fitness update last week because I was sulking and whining like a little punk. Yep, I went down again. It wasn’t an illness this time. It was some serious pain in my right leg.
Image Title: I Get Knocked Down But I Get Up Again

Title: Understanding Your Audience
Content: YOU IN 2016:  Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Four A common mistake people used to make in business (and, frankly, still do) is looking at the marketplace in terms of what they want to sell, rather than what people want to buy. In other words, totally not understanding the audience. Well, the truth is—that happens a lot. And it happens a lot not just in business and in politics but also in our other relationships, such as with our families, friends and neighbors. So how do you find out what is important to your audience? If you were chief digital strategist for a presidential campaign (as I was this cycle) you’d rely on polling. Of course, the size of our total audience was 325,000,000. You probably have a more manageable group. Sometimes it’s as simple as a show of hands. But there’s something about privacy and anonymity that people really like, just as they typically like being asked their opinion. So ask. Again, depending on your group, a simple one-page questionnaire would work. At the office, it might be better to use something like Survey Monkey which works really well. You also have your intuition and your gut and don’t discount those. Not very scientific, but often right. But, one way or another, you need to get the answer. It’ll save you from spending time and/or money on the wrong message. I've been there. Law and order message to electorate whose #1 interest is jobs. Etc. Don't make that mistake. Is your neighborhood more interested in beautification or safety? Does the local school need a new playground, or more tablets? Is everyone interested in new furniture at the office, or would they rather have a more flexible work schedule? Is the extended family yearly vacation a done deal, or is there room for discussion? Find out—and act accordingly. W.
Excerpt: YOU IN 2016:  Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Four

Title: Things That Drive Me Batshit Crazy #3
Content: Keyboard Courage OK, this has to stop. “Keyboard Courage” is driving me out of my frigging mind. I’m not sure if it’s because it can be done anonymously on the internet, or just because it can be done without looking at another person eye-to-eye, but this “type anything to anyone” mentality is totally out of control. Maybe the election year has made things worse—I don’t know.  But I do know I see the most vile, nasty, hateful, foul comments just about everywhere. These are from people who you know would NEVER in a million years say something like this to anyone’s face. I think spending hours online writing awful and rude comments makes some people feel brave, but it’s the very definition of cowardice. That the level of discourse in this country has dropped to the sub-basement is troubling, to say the least. It isn’t just no courtesy, it’s no civility. You support another candidate?  Fine. You have a different opinion on an issue?  Also fine. What are you accomplishing with six hours on news sites typing every swear word you know? You’re just bullying people online. Please: trolls, angry people, activists—think of something else to do. Or have the courage to say it to a person's face where you may have to suffer the consequences of your actions. You have the right to free speech. But no one said free speech doesn't come without a cost, like you getting put on the ground. Which reminds me of another thing that drives me absolutely batshit crazy-- people who don't understand that the 1st Amendment protects you from the government, not from someone's fist. I'll save that for a later post.
Excerpt: OK, this has to stop. “Keyboard Courage” is driving me out of my frigging mind.

Title: Delaying Your Way To Failure
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Five You probably heard the advice first when you were little: “Never put off to tomorrow, what you can do today.” It’s true. It’s especially true in campaigns. To say you need a sense of urgency to work on political campaigns is putting it mildly. We have to work like there’s no tomorrow because there may not be. One wrong move, one bad debate, one new opponent…and the campaign could be over. You just never know. So you just can’t afford to wait. That’s good advice at work, at home, in your neighborhood and with your friends and family. Don’t wait. Don’t wait “for the timing to be better.” Don’t wait for “someone else to do it.” Somebody should see about getting a stop sign on your street. Not somebody. You. Somebody should plan a party. Somebody should buy a gift for the teacher. Somebody should start thinking about new audience targets for the company’s products. Not tomorrow. Today. Sounds like “somebody’s” going to be busy. But, seriously—what’s the alternative? Wait and see if someone else does it? Wait and see how it turns out? No, no,no. Bad plan. Believe me—days make weeks, and weeks make months. It happens in the blink of an eye. Take the initiative. Raise your hand. Say “I’ve got this one.” Besides the obvious (task being accomplished), you’ll feel more fulfilled personally, and people will see as being dependable. But whatever else you do—at work, at home, at church, in the neighborhood—do it now. Don’t delay. W.
Excerpt: You probably heard the advice first when you were little: “Never put off to tomorrow, what you can do today.” It’s true. It’s especially true in campaigns.

Title: VERY true: It's Not What You Know. It's Who You Know
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use in Everyday Life: Part Six In politics, you might be surprised how much happens simply because of relationships. And I don’t mean secret, backroom, you-scratch-my-back relationships. I mean actual friends, neighbors, former co-workers…it’s the next segment of campaign lessons you can adapt for work, home and family. What compels someone to run for office? What then compels other people to volunteer or be supporters? As often as not, it’s relationships we have that drive these decisions. I have worked on many campaigns at the request or suggestion of people I’ve known for quite some time. And many of the candidates I know well ran in the first place because a friend or neighbor or family member urged them to. Yes, they have a sense of duty as regards public service and feel they have skills to offer as well. But an older or more experienced person offering support makes a big difference. The same is true in the (non-political campaign) workplace. We used to collect stacks of business cards to keep track of our contacts—it is so much more efficient now. And you just never know when that person you interviewed with once, met at a party, have a mutual friend with at church—turns out to be your next big lead, big sale or big promotion. All the more reason to do two things consistently. First, treat people well. Ever heard somebody say “be nice to people on the way up—you’ll see the same people on the way down”? I think really it just means be polite. To everyone. I’ve worked around people who were just awful to anyone in a service capacity—waiter, checkout person. That’s bad karma. And bad manners. Second, keep in touch. Not annoyingly. But back to the “you never know” thing—that’s why it’s a good idea to wish people a happy birthday or send a funny story you know they’ll like. As long as it’s sincere (and not like how people reached out to me on LinkedIn!), that’s a kind of thing people remember. I have people who still remind me what a nice note I sent when one of their parents passed. Relationships. They need care and nurturing, like most things in life.
Excerpt: It’s All About Relationships
Image Title: VERY true: It's Not What You Know. It's Who You Know

Title: Production Is More Important Than Ideas
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life : Part Seven  No one appreciates a good idea more than I do. I do run an ad agency, after all—(technically a digital marketing firm). Our business runs on good ideas. But as important as they are, implementing them—executing them—is more important. It won’t help us to have a great idea for a web video, an email or even a yard sign—if we don’t make it, make it well and have it placed or distributed properly. Execution is key. The same is true at work and at your church group or neighborhood association. Brainstorming ideas is a great exercise. Someone can stand in front of the room with a marker and an easel with a big pad, furiously writing down the things people in attendance say. And then…? Even in a free flowing forum of ideas like a brainstorming session, there has to be structure. There has to be a goal. Not just next steps, but a decision to be made. What’s the idea? What’s the plan? What are we making? You may be the decision maker. I often am. Make sure someone is. Particularly in big companies, there is the myth of the “good meeting.” But it’s not a good meeting if it doesn’t result in action. And that’s true when you need a fundraising idea for new church furniture, or you’re launching a new product or it’s time to plan the Halloween party at your child’s school. “It could be this.” “It could be that.” Yes, it could be. But,enough. What WILL it be? Decide. Plan. Delegate. And, above all, execute.
Excerpt: Production Is More Important Than Ideas
Image Title: Production Is More Important Than Ideas

Title: Jingle All The Way
Content: My weekly fitness update For those of you who don’t know, I’m a leader in an all male peer-led workout organization called F3 - Fitness, Fellowship, Faith. During a man’s first workout he gets a nickname chosen by his peers. Mine is Jingles. So for all of you who wonder about the Jingles references here and on my social media, there’s your explanation. Jingles is back! After being down for a couple weeks and falling off my marathon training schedule, I rebounded last week with a total of 41 miles, two weight-lifting days at the gym and one F3 bootcamp, which I led. That was a total of 10 workouts, which was capped off with a 15.5 mile run on Saturday, my longest in about seven months. My leg issue continued during the 15-miler, but it wasn’t so bad that I couldn’t hit my goal. The twice-daily foam roller and stretching is helping there. I felt no fatigue or soreness after my run either, although the IT band was acting up on Monday. All in all, I feel much better. I had to travel a lot this week so I haven’t run in four days. I need to make up the mileage with a couple of long runs this week. I might be signing up for a half marathon on Saturday. The following Saturday is the Savannah Rock and Roll Marathon. I’m currently signed up for the full marathon but will most likely drop back to the half due to the IT band killing my training schedule. The week after that is the Summerville Sweet Tea Half Marathon. That all means I might have three straight weekends of races. Why the hell not? I need more bling. Wesley
Excerpt: Weekly fitness update

Title: Believe It Or Not, A Lot Of Political Campaigns Refuse To Pay Their Bills
Content: Things That Drive Me Batshit Crazy, Part 4 How’s this for business model? You engage a firm to do work for you—they do it—and then you don’t pay them. Where do you end up—in jail? No, you end up in the US Senate or the US House of Representatives or the state capital, the mayor’s office, etc. Political campaigns are NOTORIOUS for not paying their bills. Leaving their vendors (including their digital firms) holding the bag. And, depending on the size of the campaign, that could be a pretty big bag. And that’s when the candidates win. When they lose, they fold up shop like a pop-up Halloween costume store, never to be seen again. And never to pay. This would NEVER work in any other industry. NEVER. Dine and dash? Five-finger discount? Unacceptable. Not paying me? Perfectly fine, apparently. This is a massive problem in campaign life. The pace is fast—there’s always next week and the next fundraiser. “Don’t worry—we’ll take care of you.” The candidates usually have to concentrate on two things: getting votes and getting money. There’s nothing wrong with that. Even if you are running for school board, you will have expenses. But it’s wrong to not your bills. It just is; whether it’s me, the printer, the landlord or the utility company. It’s particularly frustrating with conservative candidates who rail against the government racking up debt. It's completely morally wrong.
Excerpt: Political campaigns that don't pay their bills

Title: Work On What You Believe In
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Eight When you are passionate about something, you can move mountains. Similarly, if there’s something you couldn’t care less about it, your effort will reflect it. I have been fortunate in my political career personally—and we have been at Push—to work with candidates, issues and corporate clients we believe in 100%. Okay, that's not entirely true. I went out on my own with one $500 a month client to start Push. I had to take any check I could in the beginning. And honestly, I worked for some candidates I didn't particularly like on the issues, and some I didn't even like as people. That's not the case now. We have the flexibility to work with folks we believe in. A good example is Senator Marco Rubio. I worked on his presidential campaign and I'm working for him now on his US Senate race. I talked to other presidential candidates, but my mind always went back to Marco. I agree with him about 98% on the issues (I don't agree with anyone on EVERYTHING) and I believe he's the embodiment of where the Republican Party needs to be to both win elections and, more importantly, to move American toward prosperity. I'm not just happy to work for Marco. I'm all out friggin pumped. I don't mind the late night emails, early morning calls, the weekend work and all the stress that goes into running campaigns because he gives me energy. He gives me hope for our party and our nation. I've learned that there’s no substitute for this feeling. You just can’t fake or manufacture enthusiasm. This should help guide you in your interactions with family, friends, neighbors and at work. If it’s a new project, or you are looking for a volunteer opportunity, or you get appointed to a committee—try your best to find a match with something you are totally into. What really moves the needle for you? Kids? Animal shelters? The symphony? Parks? Mammograms? Hunger? There are so many opportunities for fundraising projects, volunteer projects to tackle at and through work, outreach programs from your church, neighborhood clean ups…if you can get involved you won’t miss the meetings, you’ll become an advocate, you’ll feel more fulfilled. Of course we all need and like money. But that fire in your belly burns for another reason. Go after that—as much as you can and with all your might.
Excerpt: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Eight
Image Title: Work On What You Believe In

Title: Winner, Winner; Chicken Dinner
Content: My weekly fitness update I won something. I’ve never won anything fitness related. Cool, huh? This past weekend I got seventh place overall and first place in my age group in the Georgetown Bridge to Bridge Half-Marathon. I missed my PR by 40 seconds with a 1:43:10. Man. 40 seconds! Admittedly, it was a pretty small race due to Hurricane Matthew rescheduling. I’m not sure how many folks ran it, but it was more than 500 I think, so seventh is still pretty good. But I don’t want you thinking it was in the thousands. Still, I got that second medal and it says WINNER, so I’m feeling like a winner this week. Except for one thing. I have firmly decided that I’m not ready for this weekend’s full marathon in Savannah. Not only did the leg injury halt my training, but it’s actually back this week. It doesn’t hurt as bad as it did, but it’s definitely feeling the effects of the race. So, I’m going to drop to the half- marathon this weekend and then follow it up with the Summerville Sweet Tea Half-Marathon the following weekend. That’s back-to-back-to-back Saturdays with half-marathons. Maybe there's a medal for that! Should be, right? Then I’ll go for a PR at the Kiawah Marathon in December and then again at the Charleston Marathon in January and then I’m not likely to PR at the hilly Asheville Marathon in March. The weekend after that I will have the Palmetto 200 ultra-relay. YAY! That’s a lot of running. Okay, so let’s talk about this past weekend’s race. I wore my five finger Vibrams, which typically speeds me up pretty good. However, my feet hurt like hell by mile ten and those last three miles were a real struggle. My leg did start bothering me around mile eight, but I pushed through the pain. I crushed it from an endurance standpoint though. I’m definitely in the best cardio shape I’ve ever been. The course included two tall bridges, thus the bridge to bridge theme. We had to go over and back each twice, so that was four pretty large inclines. Those slowed me down a good bit and had it not been for them, I definitely would have PRed. This week I’m running about 20 miles before Saturday’s race, lifting twice and Qing one F3 bootcamp. That’s a pretty light week. On to Savannah…
Excerpt: I won something. I’ve never won anything fitness related. Cool, huh?

Title: Dropping The Hammer
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Nine The velvet glove? Or the iron fist? The fact is, if you’re in charge, you’ll need both. And you’ll use both, believe me. Political campaigns are high energy, high anxiety, high stakes affairs. They’re not a place for the faint of heart. Sometimes, you have to drop the hammer. Because people are goofing off. Or because things aren’t getting done. Or because things are getting done, but they’re not getting done well. That’s when it’s time to drop it. The same is true at work, or at home, or in your groups—neighborhood, church, friends. You wouldn’t want to be walking around screaming all the time—what would that accomplish? But at the same time, you can’t always be “nice, nice, baby.” Leading is not a popularity contest. It’s a results contest. That’s what counts. Did the new playground equipment get put in? Did we raise enough money for the church van? Did we pack city hall for that hearing? Yes, or no? That’s what matters. If you aren’t getting the results you want—the results you need—on a consistent basis…well, you know what to do. It’s hammer time.
Excerpt: The velvet glove? Or the iron fist? The fact is, if you’re in charge, you’ll need both.

Title: This Has Been One Hell Of A Campaign Season
Content:
That’s probably putting it too mildly. But like a lot of people, I ran out of words to describe some of the things that have happened.

What I wanted to talk about, proudly, was this political cycle at Push.

We have been working our asses off for months and months. A lot of late nights. A lot of weekends. And when I say we have not only our largest staff but also our most talented one, I mean it sincerely.

We have done some really great work. Really nice videos, totally cool social posts, super effective fundraising emails. And everything started with solid digital strategies and advertising that was well planned (can’t say enough about how impressive our ad group is—that will take another post in the future).

For starters, we worked on a presidential campaign. While we didn’t make it to the general election, it was a great experience—every primary and every debate. A wild ride.

We have worked on senate campaigns and on behalf of senators who were not up for re-election this year. We were also privileged to assist the National Republican Senatorial Committee in key states.

In the House of Representatives, we have clients who have been in office and others running for the first time. We also worked with some different conservative groups on congressional campaigns in many other states.

We had campaigns for governor in Louisiana and Missouri.

We supported candidates for lieutenant governor, judge, mayor; even school board.

Additionally, we helped some people running for state senate and state house seats.
And we worked on behalf of several ballot issues, and a military base.

Does that sound like a lot?

Did I mention we did that while moving three separate times, surviving floods and a hurricane evacuation? And that we also managed the rest of the Push portfolio of clients with nonpartisan issue advocacy groups and corporate clients?

Did some of our clients lose races? Yes. Did we lose some clients? Yes. Did both hurt me personally? Yes.

But when I have a spare minute to really consider all that we did, and how much the company has grown and grown up, what I mostly feel is pride. I am so proud of this team. And so blessed to be with them.
Excerpt: That’s probably putting it too mildly. But like a lot of people, I ran out of words to describe some of the things that have happened.

Title: You’re Not Moving to Freakin’ Canada
Content: Things That Drive Me Batshit Crazy #5 Seriously? If you don’t get your way, you’ll take your bat and ball and leave? Like a five-year-old? I don’t get these rich, spoiled Hollywood (and New York) celebs. If your candidate doesn’t win, you’re going to move to Canada? Or Switzerland? Or (Cher) another planet? Number one, be my guest. Number two, grow up. In every election, someone will win and someone will lose. You can’t always get your way—even if you’ve spent your adult life getting your way constantly. We support the candidates we like, and we vote. But then everyone else also votes. And we accept the results, even if we’re disappointed. If everyone was a bad sport like you, half the country would be headed north on Wednesday. I have news for you—Canada might not really be overjoyed at that prospect. Also, don’t you have several houses? Money? Fame? Influence? And that isn’t enough for you? Here’s a partial list of people who apparently are packing heir bags right now, just in case: Bryan Cranston, Chelsea Handler, Amy Schumer, Barbra Streisand, George Lopez, Cher and Jon Stewart.
Excerpt: Things That Drive Me Batshit Crazy #5
Image Title: You’re Not Moving to Freakin’ Canada

Title: Rocking and Rolling Through Savannah
Content:
I took on a half-marathon for the second straight Saturday. You’ll remember that I was supposed to run the full Savannah Rock and Roll Marathon. I was even telling myself during the first few miles that I was going to run the full marathon, but unfortunately my leg had other plans. I dropped down to the half at the 11 mile split and hobbled across the finish line. Yeah, literally, I hobbled… straight to the medical tent where some awesome massage therapist worked me out real good.

I wasn’t too depressed because going into the event I pretty much knew I was going to drop back. The leg has been giving me fits for weeks now and it was really hurting after the Georgetown half last week. So knowing I would probably drop back, I went out of the gate at half-marathon speed, about a minute faster per mile.

I felt really good, aside from the leg. My cardio is better than its ever been. My energy level is way up, which is probably because I’m taking in a lot more food. Also, I’m nearly 20 pounds heavier than I was during last running season, mostly a result of the heavy weight days at the gym. Speaking of which, I benched 235 for the first time yesterday.

I popped some ibuprofen and pushed through the leg pain, resulting in a PR of 1:41:52 according to my MapMyRun app. The chip time has me at 1:44:03, which is far from a PR. So hell… I don’t know.

Anyway, this Saturday is my third straight race—the Sweet Tea Half- Marathon in my hometown of Summerville. Then it’s a month until the Kiawah Marathon.
Excerpt: I took on a half-marathon for the second straight Saturday.
Image Caption: Savannah, Georgia, USA at Forsyth Park Fountain.

Title: Dropping The Hammer
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Nine The velvet glove? Or the iron fist? The fact is, if you’re in charge, you’ll need both. And you’ll use both, believe me. Political campaigns are high energy, high anxiety, high stakes affairs. They’re not a place for the faint of heart. Sometimes, you have to drop the hammer. Because people are goofing off. Or because things aren’t getting done. Or because things are getting done, but they’re not getting done well. That’s when it’s time to drop it. The same is true at work, or at home, or in your groups—neighborhood, church, friends. You wouldn’t want to be walking around screaming all the time—what would that accomplish? But at the same time, you can’t always be “nice, nice, baby.” Leading is not a popularity contest. It’s a results contest. That’s what counts. Did the new playground equipment get put in? Did we raise enough money for the church van? Did we pack city hall for that hearing? Yes, or no? That’s what matters. If you aren’t getting the results you want—the results you need—on a consistent basis…well, you know what to do. It’s hammer time.
Excerpt: The velvet glove? Or the iron fist? The fact is, if you’re in charge, you’ll need both.

Title: The Buck Has To Stop Somewhere
Content: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Ten Remember those carefree days when you were younger and not in charge? Any problems you encountered or heard about were someone else’s to solve. You weren’t responsible. Not any more! And, with political campaigns, you run into problems you’d never even heard of before. If you’re running the campaign, you’re responsible for problems even if you didn’t create them. Because the buck has to stop somewhere. And, almost without exception, that won’t be anywhere near the candidate. The press has a problem? You dropped robocalls in the wrong district (yeah, that happened)? You got that certified letter from Paramount's attorney for using an image of ET on a mailer (yeah, that happened too)? Raise your hand. That’s on you. And, if you’re in charge in any of your circles—neighborhood, work, friends, family, church, whatever—get ready to raise your hand as well. It won’t do to start pointing fingers. That not what a leader does. If you’re a leader, you have to step up, own up and man up (or woman up). Because the buck stops with you—plain and simple. It’s Friday at 5 at work and you want to start a relaxing, fun weekend and an unexpected project comes in? Somebody else totally f’d up and no food was ordered for a cookout? The A/C stops working on the hottest day of the year? Congratulations. The buck just stopped right directly in front of you. Embrace it. It’s the only way. Otherwise it will drive you nuts. Expect the unexpected. And fasten your seatbelt!
Excerpt: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life: Part Ten
Image Title: The Buck Has To Stop Somewhere

Title: People Want Transparency
Content:
Since the election, the Dems have been complaining and blaming everyone but themselves. They had a flawed candidate for president and she couldn’t—or they couldn’t—turn their people out. GOTV, we call it in the biz. Get out the vote.

Did the Republicans have a flawed candidate? Yes. The Republican candidate for president understood that people are angry. People are upset by the elites, by government, by what they call the mainstream media and by politicians (both parties).

Trump appeared unvarnished and unrehearsed. People often cringed when he spoke, but he wasn’t repeating talking points prepared in D.C. People were SICK of that phoniness. He was authentic.

He spent more time on Twitter (especially) and Facebook. He didn’t spend all of his time with Hollywood celebs or at fancy fundraisers. He held rally after rally after rally all over the country, in big cities and small. He was transparent. What you saw was what you were going to get.

Turns out, he proved almost everyone wrong (including me). He didn’t raise a billion for TV. Didn’t have a large ground game in every county in every state. Didn’t play by the rules.

Didn’t do what the “experts” suggested. Wasn’t conservative enough for the old guard.

And got elected president.

I wouldn’t recommend doing it that way. But I would strongly recommend two things: be authentic and be transparent. Any candidate for any office can do both of those—you don’t need a big budget or a media machine. (We just saw how well that worked.) Be yourself.

[gravityform id="2" title="true" description="false"]
Excerpt: Since the election, the Dems have been complaining and blaming everyone but themselves.

Title: Everyone Is Tired Of The Canned Bullshit
Content:
Everything has changed. Donald Trump is about to be President of the United States of America. People are sick and tired of the establishment, the fake BS and the canned one liners. They want authenticity and transparency.

There are a lot of lessons we all need to learn from the 2016 election. This might be the biggest one.

Be authentic. Be transparent. Just be you.

Title: Campaigns Take Hard Work And Money
Content: Both are great. One is necessary. The best political campaigns have both—lots of people to do the work, and ample amounts of money. But not every campaign has both. The truth is, most don't. And that's OK with me. Tight budget, not fully staffed--I'm up for the challenge. I'm not a snob who wouldn't touch a smaller-dollar campaign. But there IS one campaign I swore I'd never run. I promised myself I would never—ever—work on a local campaign where I live. You know all the reasons. “You’ll be too close to it.” “Don’t sh*t where you eat.” “You have to see these people at the grocery store and church.” Etc. So what did I do? I worked on a local campaign in my hometown. But there was a reason. I swear. Listen, the people in my community had been complaining like crazy on message boards about a proposal to change from a strong council form of government to a strong mayor form. Not as sexy as working on Marco Rubio stuff, right? It is for me—it’s where I live. It's where I'll raise the boys. I finally gave in and said, “Guys, you won’t get anywhere by just bitching. You can’t win that way. You need to get organized, you need a strategy, and you need to get your people together and deploy them.” They asked for help and I jumped in. I helped with the first two. They did the rest. We didn’t have the budget. But we did have the workers. And, boy, did they work. That was a lot of putting in yard signs and a lot of knocking on doors and a LOT of drama. But you know what else there was? A victory. More money would have been helpful. But there’s no way we could have done this without lots of people willing to work hard on it. No way. Y'all know I'm a digital guy, but trust me, grassroots still matters.
Excerpt: The best political campaigns have both—lots of people to do the work, and ample amounts of money.
Image Title: Campaigns Take Hard Work And Money

Title: Three Halves Equal 1 1/2
Content: My Weekly Fitness Update I ran a half-marathon for the third straight Saturday. And I crushed it with a PR of 01:41:32. That’s a pace of 07:45. I finished 26th out of 365 and 4th in my age group. I felt great, too. Maybe it was the yoga, the deep tissue leg massage, the cooler weather, the flat course, the motivation of running with 25 F3 brothers or a combination of everything. I wish every race could be like that. Now, on to the Kiawah full marathon in less than a month. I’m excited, scared and, frankly, a little tired. But it’s time to pick up the pace (not literally) and put more miles on the road. There’s not a whole lot more to report this week except that I also started yoga. I’m trying to get in two sessions a week to help with core strengthening and flexibility. The mental calmness sure doesn’t hurt, either. I’ll report back later on how that’s going. Have a great week. Push Harder! [gravityform id="2" title="true" description="true"]
Excerpt: I ran a half-marathon for the third straight Saturday. And I crushed it with a PR of 01:41:32

Content:

Here's a little clip from my TEDx talk that explains exactly why America is not a democracy.  So, what is America?  I explain that, too.

Title: YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life
Content: At the height of the campaign season, I had this idea that many of the things I do naturally—because I’ve been working in politics for 20 years—might help people who don't work in politics (often referred to as “sane people.”) By that, I mean it might help you in your neighborhood, at your church or at work, or when it’s time for PTA meetings. I don’t know why this occurred to me during the absolute busiest time of year for a political firm, but it did. I really do think many of these tips about motivating volunteers and getting your message out are easy to apply in other situations. And I am always happy to help. Sometimes one suggestion can make a big difference at the office or at home. I hope you found the tips enjoyable and useful. The election season ended last week, and so did my series of tips. In case you missed any: The Buck Has To Stop Somewhere Dropping The Hammer Work On What You Believe In Production Is More Important Than Ideas VERY true: It’s Not What You Know. It’s Who You Know Delaying Your Way To Failure Understanding Your Audience Find People Who Get Sh*t Done And You Can Accomplish Just About Anything It All Begins With The Right Message You Cannot Do It Alone YOU IN 2016: Political Tips You Can Use In Everyday Life
Excerpt: The election season ended last week, and so did my series of tips. In case you missed any click here for a recap.

Title: Push Out Content People Want And Need
Content:
We're about to launch a new local web show

We all self promote. Or at least we better. No one else is going to promote us. We have to do it ourselves.

But most companies get into the habit of pumping out content that's nothing more than a beefed up press release. They like to talk about how cool they are and all their big accomplishments.

Let me tell you how many people care about that. Almost none. People want to consume content that helps them. They don't have time to hear about how cool you are. Give them something quick and useful.

That's our content strategy. So we are launching a new web show to answer the question we get more than any others - where should I go in Charleston?

We hope this helps.

Title: What I'm Thankful For
Content:
This post is obviously a few days late. The first thing I’m thankful for is the ability to have taken a few days off. That was nice. And unusual.

It’s been one hell of a year. Some great. Some horrible. That’s just life, especially when you run businesses. But it’s been a good net positive thus far so I’ll take it.

So let’s get into it. This year I’m thankful for…

My wife. She’s put up with far more than any woman should. Every one of my accomplishments, from growing businesses to finishing the GORUCK HTL, are equally hers. But I can’t say her accomplishments are equally mine. Giving me two amazing sons and raising them daily is all her. She’s quite the badass. A smoking hot badass.

My boys. Harlowe is growing like a weed and at 2 1/2 years old can just about hold full on conversations. I don’t want to be one of "those fathers," but the kid is wicked smart and a real sweetheart. As for Tennyson, well, he just kind of lays there all day and occasionally smiles so I can’t vouch for his intelligence or kindness, but he was born healthy and he sleeps well, so that’s all the blessing we need right now. I can’t wait to see his personality arrive.

My team. We’ve been in an endless election cycle for five years. As soon as we came off of the 2014 cycle, Marco’s presidential campaign heated up. Then we immediately went into the 2016 cycle. They hunkered down and built out some of the most creative digital strategies in the business. And they did it without me having to be involved in the details so I could concentrate on strategy and creative. They crushed it. Since I can’t call out all 25, let me at least name the senior team - Michael, Phil, JP, Brooke, Jonathan and The Rock.

My partners. Y’all, Frothy Beard Brewing Company is going to be a big deal. Joey, Steve and Michael are producing amazingly creative beer, the move and expansion is in full swing and the new brewhouse got delivered this morning. We should open in January and start canning just a few months after. And speaking of partners, we haven’t talked a whole lot yet about Zombie Bob’s Pizza, but look for some big things from Ryan in the coming weeks.

My clients. Push’s continued growth wouldn’t be possible without amazing clients. Some political. Some corporate. All awesome! I’m thankful that they’ve put their trust in us and given us a creative outlet for our team to push harder. Oh, and money. Money is nice. You know, it helps make payroll and all.

My health. In 2016 alone I will knock out 2 marathons, a GORUCK HTL, two additional GORUCK Toughs, an ultra-marathon relay and three half- marathons. I started working out because both parents and my step-father passed away at early ages. By now you know that I take things to the extreme, so it shouldn’t be a surprise that I didn’t just stop at going to the gym daily. But knocking out that much in just one year is a huge surprise to me. None of that would have been possible without…

My other boys. The ones I roll with. F3 has completely changed my life and it’s all about the accountability and push the men of F3 Summerville give me every day. They force me out of bed, they make me sign up for stupid events and they push me past limits to places I thought I would never be. They also hold me accountable to being a good man, a spiritual one, and a good father and husband. I’m thankful for all of them, but especially Hotspot (my Normandy brother), Goose and Cousin. Also a big shoutout to Pyle who pushed me in my first marathon and just signed up to pace me at Kiawah.

There’s so much to be thankful for this year and we still have 1/12th of the way to go. Keep pushing harder!
Excerpt: This post is obviously a few days late.

Title: This Brewery Thing Is Actually Happening
Content: A Very Frothy Update One day while sitting on a beach with some friends, I looked over at Michael Rentiers and said “know what would be cool? Putting our digital agency inside of a brewery.” We where half drunk so it was definitely one of those “yeah, that would be badass” and then you forget about it kind of things. But it festered. I visited all these cool tech offices like Google, Facebook and Twitter. I kept thinking to myself “yeah, this is badass, but it isn’t a brewery.” I mentioned to my wife that it would be super cool to do one day and she replied “one day? Why wait?” Well, that was a damn good question. Why wait? Well, the wait is almost over. This thing is happening. Construction is in full swing and this week we crossed another major milestone. The brewing equipment showed up - the brewhouse, bright tank and fermentors. Check out this new video:
Excerpt: Check it out here.
Image Title: This Brewery Thing Is Actually Happening

Title: Getting My Namaste On
Content: My Weekly Fitness Update I’m just over a week away from my second marathon. It couldn’t come at a worse time. Damnit, I’m sick again. Yes, AGAIN! It seems like at least once a quarter I go down with a bad cold and chest congestion. I was never like this before. Before what, you ask? Before kids! I’m about two seconds from turning Harlowe into a little hermit so he never gets infested by your kids. AAAGGGGHHHH!!! Okay, enough whining. This week I’m taking it easy so that I can get all the crud out of my chest. And by taking it easy, I mean I’m not running much and I’m drinking way too much at Christmas parties. 'Tis the season. On Thanksgiving morning I knocked out 17 miles and felt great. I’ve pretty much taken it easy since then except for a couple lifting days at the gym and a couple yoga sessions. Yes, yoga! I’m finally hitting that goal I’ve had all year and getting in two sessions each week.  I’m loving it so far. So, why yoga? Two things. First, I’m not very flexible and I have a hard time stretching at home. It’s just like running, rucking, lifting or anything else. If I don’t have the accountability, I don’t do it. Yoga gives me that accountability to stretch and concentrate on core strength. I believe it’s going to ease some of the injuries I have been having recently, such as the IT band issue. Secondly, as you know by now, I strongly believe in mental training. Learning to breathe and concentrate are core ingredients for endurance challenges. I’m hoping yoga is an additional step in getting my mind right for some upcoming events. Tomorrow I’ll lift, do yoga and go for a five mile run. Saturday I’ll go for a twenty miler. Then next week it’s a couple short runs, two yoga sessions, three lifting days and no bootcamps or rucks in order to taper a bit and prevent any injuries. All in all I’m feeling pretty good, except for all the green crud I’m hacking up. Namaste, yo! Keep pushing. Wesley
Excerpt: My Weekly Fitness Update

Title: Why A Digital Agency And A Brewery In One?
Content:
I love drinking. In college I got tired of drinking the same fizzy yellow crap every night so I wondered into the craft beer space and fell in love. I can drink a different kind of beer every night. Craft brewers are the same exact creature as us marketers. They're creatives.  I discovered that I love craft beer for the same reason I love my marketing agency.

It's that love of creativity that binds us together. We're rule breakers. We don't believe in doing things the same way they've always been done. 

Frothy is under full construction with plans to open in about two months. In the meantime the Push team is hunkering down and working from an often loud construction zone. The pain will be well worth it.

Title: People Who Say, “I Can’t"
Content: THINGS THAT DRIVE ME BATSH*T CRAZY #6 One of the most powerful phrases you can say or hear is “I can.” I suppose I have always been determined or stubborn about things. That has served me well even in jobs I had as a teenager. I was quick to raise my hand to volunteer and I was not intimidated by anything or anyone (at least not outwardly!). As an adult, I have tested my limits to get in and to stay in better shape. And, I did it for the challenge as well. Thanks to F3 and GoRuck I have done TONS of things I never thought I would do. Taking part in a 200-mile tag team ultra-marathon? Carrying all kinds of heavy sh*t all over hell’s half-acre? Back-to-back-to-back half-marathons? Completing a GRUELING HTL in Normandy??? This weekend during the Kiawah Marathon both legs and arms locked up around mile 21. It was strangest thing I've ever felt. I literally could not control my limbs as if they had been detached. I fell to the ground. I told my buddy "I can't." I have rarely been so ashamed of myself. I immediately felt that shame and said out loud, "what the f*ck did you just say? (excuse my language but that's what I said). I got up. I walked. I limped. I ran- limped. Then I ran. I can. In fact, I did. Maybe that’s why I have so little tolerance for people who say, “I can’t.” I’m not talking about legal or moral issues here—I’m talking about pushing yourself. Running longer or faster. Lifting more weights. Climbing a higher mountain, literally or figuratively. The same is true with non-physical tasks. At work. At home. With friends. There can always be a reason to NOT do something. People will say, “I can’t” to just about anything, for just about any reason. Too busy. Too tired. Too expensive. Too complicated. Bullsh*t. I’m the least athletic person I know, and I did it. And I didn’t leverage my parents’ friends at the country club to help me start my business. Instead, on both fronts, I busted my ass. That’s how I got in shape. And started a business. You can’t quit smoking? You can’t spend more time with your kids? Sure you can. Start by saying it: I can. W.
Excerpt: THINGS THAT DRIVE ME BATSH*T CRAZY #6

Title: Humblebrag: I’m A Two-Time Marathoner
Content:
The cramp might slow me, but it won't stop me

Well, I did it. I crossed my second marathon finish line this past Saturday. It wasn’t pretty at all, but I beat my goal by eight minutes; finishing in 3:52:06. That’s 20 minutes faster than my first marathon, the Charleston Marathon, this past January. 

I’m happy with my performance, but I’m also disappointed because I could have, I should have, finished much sooner. Honestly, at this point, I’m not sure I will ever be completely satisfied with my performance in any event. I always want to do better. But this time is different because I WAS doing better. So here’s the deal…

F3 Summerville’s Pyle was kind enough to sign up late for this race, having not trained for it, to pace me. The dude is a beast. We were flying at a sub 8 pace for the first 10 miles. Then we started backing off to about an 8:15 - 8:30 pace. Around mile 19 I started hurting pretty good. My endurance was high but my legs started cramping up slightly. Knowing I had a good bit of time and I was on pace for a 3:40 - 3:45 finished, we backed off to a 9- minute pace. 

Then around mile 21, disaster struck. Both legs AND both arms totally cramped up. It was like nothing I had ever felt before. I literally could not control them. They hurt like hell, so I knew they were there, but it was like they detached. I hit the ground hard.

Ryan ran over and forced me up, telling me that moving would make it better. Another F3 guy ran by and threw a pack of salt tablets at me. I took a few and just started walking. Then I was limp-running, basically a hobble. Eventually I could run a few minutes at a time, backing off occasionally to a brisk walk. But by now I had dropped to an 11-minute pace.

A few times I felt a surge of energy and was able to maintain an 8:30 pace for a couple of minutes, but the cramping kept coming back. I saw a few F3 guys on the side of the road including TNT and Stagecoach. Their cheers gave me energy to run, but the running never lasted more than five minutes before I had to back off. 

Those last five miles hurt like a son of a bitch, but thankfully I had Pyle by my side to push me through. Thank God for our F3 brotherhood. 

So, I crushed my PR and my goal. But I didn’t finish where I could have. 

I trained hard.
I drank a lot of water.
I ate before the race and along the way. 

However, I didn’t take any salt or additional electrolytes. I’ll be playing with those over the next four weeks as I prepare to take my revenge on the Charleston marathon in pursuit of a 3:45!

This week my routine is: two bootcamps w/ ruck, three days lifting, two yoga and a 5k. Next week I’ll do all that minus the 5k, with two five-milers and a 15-miler. 

BOOM! On to Charleston…

W.
Excerpt: The cramp might slow me, but it won't stop me

Title: The Digital Political Landscape in Sixty Seconds*
Content:
How digital agencies like mine fit into politics has been changing rapidly ever since we opened our doors. Competitors and clients alike have ranged from skeptical to amazed.

The current trend has two conflicting parts. One, that media consumption is more and more niche messages to niche audiences. That’s a plus for a digital agency. Two, that traditional TV agencies are grabbing more of the budgets meant for digital. And how do they spend it? By putting TV spots online. Square peg, round hole.

So where does that leave us? We’re becoming silent ATMs churning out fundraising emails (which we do and do well—don’t get me wrong).

Of course when the TV agencies see larger and larger parts of “their” budgets going to digital they would try to do something about it.

Yes, they’re drinking my milkshake. Or trying to. And it doesn’t make sense. Because trend #1 isn’t stopping—content will keep being more and more niche to audiences that are also—-closer and closer to 1:1.

Advantage: digital. (Say it like the court announcer says at Wimbledon.)

WATCH THE VIDEO to learn more and see a handsome guy. 😉

*Watch this and by the end, the landscape will have shifted again—that’s how fast it’s moving.

Title: This is My Bah Humbug Moment of the Christmas Season
Content:
I don’t like gifts. I don’t like giving and I don’t like receiving. 

Here’s the thing: 

I don’t like how everything has become so commercialized and how gifts have taken away from the true meaning of Christmas, which is the birth of Christ. 

I also don’t like how the wise men giving gifts to our Savior and Saint Nicholas giving gifts to little poor children, has all been commercialized by major corporations with the main intent to sell shit. That drives me absolutely crazy.

I think whenever you’re forced to give someone a gift, it doesn’t mean as much. It’s not that I don’t like gifts, I don’t like being forced to give a gift. When it’s mandatory to give a gift, I think that takes away from the true meaning of a gift.

Gifts should be given when someone truly deserves it or you want to surprise someone that you love. 

I also don’t like receiving gifts. I personally feel very awkward when people give me things and when others stand around me and watch me open gifts. I never know what to say and it always makes me feel really funny.

I am much more of a gift giver than a gift receiver. I like giving people gifts not because I have to, but because I want to. 

Things that drive me batshit crazy are gifts.
Excerpt: Things That Drive Me Batshit Crazy #7
Image Title: This is My Bah Humbug Moment of the Christmas Season

Title: Christmas Carols—The Wesley Way
Content:
“You better watch out, you better not cry

You better not pout, I’m telling you why—

somebody’s going to get a beat down.”

If you work on political campaigns (as we do) or in a fast-paced environment like a digital ad agency (as we are), then you had seriously better not pout and better not cry. OK? 

No moping. No “He got a bigger piece of pie.” No gossiping. This is the office, not a middle school cafeteria. Concentrate on just f’ing killing the tasks in front of you.

Not just at Christmas. Year-round. Dust yourself off and get back to work.

We have campaigns to win. Causes to champion. Products to launch. No time for long faces and hurt feelings. Get over it.

Or else Wesley Claus is coming to town…

W.
Excerpt: “You better watch out, you better not cry. You better not pout, I’m telling you why—somebody’s going to get a beat down.”

Title: Programming Note: It’s Vision Time
Content:
One of my top goals for 2016 was to relaunch my personal blog after a couple years off and blog every weekday. I can’t say that I’ve blogged every single weekday, but I can say that I’ve crushed my blog and pumped out a lot of content. Some of it is really really good. In fact, later next week I’ll post a round-up of my favorite posts.

For now, I just wanted to let you know that I’m going to chill on the blog for the next seven to ten days. I’ll post a couple things, like the before mentioned round-up, but I’m going to take the next week to stay off the computer and concentrate on my goals for 2017. You know, those things I’ve blogged about repeatedly over the last year. So, I’m stepping into my cave to write Vision 2017. W.
Excerpt: I’m stepping into my cave to write Vision 2017...

Title: Why I Was Blessed To Have A Crappy Childhood
Content:
"I truly believe I was blessed for having a shitty life. When you come from shit and you've seen shit you have a real drive not to be in that shit." This is the first time I've been interviewed for a podcast and it's also the first time I've opened up about my childhood beyond my own blog. I'm honestly pretty nervous to share this with you. This is full of really good marketing and personal advice. Listen to the whole thing if you want to hear about goal setting, which is super important as we head into 2017.  Listen from 26 minutes on if you want to hear my personal story. Sorry that my Wi-Fi connection sucked and my Skype was choppy.

Title: How You Can Actually Lose Weight in 2017
Content:
Yesterday the Push team arrived back in the office for the first time in 2017. During our weekly staff meeting I asked each of my teammates to give me two things: 1. One of your personal resolutions. 2. One of your professional resolutions to improve yourself, your department and the company. Like many Americans, I continuously heard “lose weight” as a personal resolution. Or as Phil Vangelakos said, “not have my gut jiggle when I brush my teeth.” No surprise there, as you’re probably seeing lines for the treadmills at the gym right now. Give it two months. You’ll see three of eight treadmills completely open at all times. I’m not going to give you some “Lose 30 pounds in 30 days” quick solutions. Those almost always (and inevitably) fail. You might lose those pounds, but your tendency to want quick solutions means you gain them back with a few more. Instead, I’m going to give you a formula to lose weight and to actually keep it off. It’s not quick. It sucks. Embrace the suck and stop looking for quick solutions. Push harder and get real results. Get better. Be better.

Use this formula to lose pounds, build muscle, train for a 10k or to start and grow your own business. It’s not about losing weight. It’s about setting and meeting goals.

Here’s the formula:

1. Set numerical goals:

Don’t have these vague ideas like “lose weight” or “make more money.” Give them real numerical values that you can actually meet. And actually measure:
  • Drop 15 pounds
  • Earn a 20% bonus
  • Read ten books
Having a number in mind makes it easier to remember and gives you an actual goal to shoot for. You will either hit that goal or you won’t, but at least you have something to chase. Keep it clear and focused. As you should be.

2. Break those goals down into smaller obtainable goals

You know the joke about how to eat an elephant? One bite at a time. Don't call PETA on me. It's just another way of saying "one step at a time." You should have a:
  • Yearly goal
  • Quarterly goal
  • Monthly goal
  • Weekly goal
  • Daily goal
Training to run your first marathon or slimming down to fit back into your old jeans takes effort--and time. You will feel better if you can achieve these milestone goals. Not if; when you achieve them. And then...

3. Daily "to-do" items that add up to those goals:

Every day has to figure into the big goals. Now, for some things like marathon training, you need to have days off (of running) scheduled. But for most of these goals, it's repetitive tasks every day that become good habits, or a slowly escalating scale. You need a "to-do" list. Something like:
  • Run five miles today
  • Lift for 45 minutes today
  • Yoga today
The plan may differ (based on the goal), but it has to actually be a to-do item every day— and a commitment to scratch the to-do's off your list.

4. Track everything:

You can’t figure out what you’re doing right and what you’re doing wrong unless you can analyze your actions. And the only way to do either is by tracking your progress. This is getting ridiculously easy with technology like Fitbit, sites like Goodreads and software at work—or you can use an old dependable method like mine: The important thing is not how you track, but that you do. You do get a good feeling checking the box or entering the number on a regular basis. It's true.

5. Build an accountability team

No matter how big or small your goal is, you will be tempted to sleep through your alarm, convince yourself the weather is too crappy, or not feel like following up on business leads. Here's what you need: People you can count on to bug the living shit out of you. You might be able to enlist your spouse or a friend or a co-worker--for me, it's my F3 brothers and they shame me on social media and everywhere else. Just do what works for you. But you will need something or someone. No one can do it alone.

6. Find an event 

Everyone works better with a deadline. And whether it's a number on a scale or a mountain to scale, having the destination on the horizon is a good thing. Especially if it's an event--your high school reunion, the Thanksgiving turkey trot run, the beginning of swimsuit season--the date circled on the calendar is a great motivator. It's also a light at the end of the tunnel. There you go. Your path to fitness, weight loss, business gain, knowledge... you're welcome! Follow the plan. Get off your ass. And have a great 2017.
Excerpt: A simple formula to get shit done
Image Title: How You Can Actually Lose Weight in 2017

Title: I've Been Humbled by Water
Content:
I’m not saying I’m Superman. I’m not cut. I’m not the strongest or the fastest guy around. But I am in the best shape of my life. My endurance is high. I’m lifting more than I’ve ever lifted. I’m decently fast. But man, after my first swim workout, I felt like a little pansy.

I have decided that my big 2018 goal will be a full Ironman triathlon. That’s a 2.4 mile swim, a 112-mile bike ride and a full 26.2 mile marathon run. That’s insanity, given that I don’t bike and I have no idea how to really swim. I must start somewhere, so I’m going to do a Half Ironman this October with the Charleston Sprint Series, five small triathlon events, in the months leading up to the Ironman. That means I have to start swimming and biking right now.

I started swimming on Friday with F3 Summerville’s swim group, Tsunami. For 45 minutes I tried my best to swim laps back and forth as F3 brother and swimming expert, Speedo, tried teaching me proper technique. Let’s just say that it did not go well and I swallowed enough chlorine for my food, coffee and beer to taste chlorinated for the rest of the day.

Swim training continues this week as I lay off the running a bit, tapering for this weekend’s Charleston Marathon. Yep, another full marathon as I take revenge on that son of a bitch course that kicked my ass last year.

I’m also back in full GORUCK training mode. I have a double Light event and then the Fort Bragg Heavy in February. All that is hard core training for what will be the toughest event of my life, an F3 Custom Heavy Heavy, in April.

I’m feeling good. My back is feeling a lot better. I have energy. I got my mind right. I do have a little cold but, hell, it’s never going to be perfect and that’s expected with these 50-degree temperature swings.

Keep me in your prayers on Saturday. Marathons suck and this one is sure to really suck. It’s time to embrace the suck again.

Push Harder!

W.
Excerpt: Half Ironman training begins now

Title: Why Term Limits Are Good For America
Content:
I think term limits would be the best thing for my business because that would mean more campaigns! Honestly, I think term limits is the best idea for our country, so that no one leader gains too much power.

Often, those who claim to support term limits find themselves greedy with power shortly after they get to office. They become power-hungry, and they try to stay in their positions longer and longer to fuel that hunger. It’s a vicious cycle.

Our country deserves fresh ideas, otherwise we will have the same people standing for the same values and no progress will be possible.

I absolutely support term limits.

<center><iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/UXWZlV9QLiA" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></center>
Excerpt: I absolutely support term limits.
Image Title: Why Term Limits Are Good For America

Title: Good People Vs. Bad People
Content:
No political party has a monopoly on morality. It’s easy to demonize the other side based on political issues, but take a minute before you judge.

No matter who you are or what you stand for, remember this: good people can be wrong and bad people can be right. It’s not just about shared values, it’s about individual character.

<center><iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/hHZdZ5bUiVQ" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></center>
Excerpt: No political party has a monopoly on morality.

Title: Have a Reason to Run for Office
Content: What’s the first step to running for office? Having a reason to run. The majority of the time, people don’t have a good reason. Limelight, power and/or a play in the game are not solid reasons when it comes to running for public office. What you really need is passion. I got into politics because I grew up as the “poor kid.” Both of my parents had severe drug addictions, causing my father to be imprisoned, while my mother died of an overdose. My childhood led me to believe that the system was broken, and I wanted to get involved in politics to make a difference. I personally never felt called to run for office. Instead, I thought that I could have the greatest impact being the man behind the scenes, helping hundreds of awesome people get into office to serve. This way, rather than only one individual serving, hundreds of others could make their mark in office. I cannot stress enough the importance of having a reason to run. Without it, you are wasting your time and that of others.
Excerpt: What’s the first step to running for office?
Image Title: Have a Reason to Run for Office

Title: Seeking Advice On Upcoming Fitness Events
Content:
My weekly fitness updates haven’t been so weekly lately. I know you all miss me talking about myself, right? You wake up every morning yearning for my fitness update post so you know exactly how my body feels. It’s okay to admit it. You’re weird like that.

If you’re not my wife or one of my F3 brothers, you probably don’t give two shits about these posts. But maybe you should. You can learn something from me and if you respond, I can learn something from you. That’s what I need right now. I need to learn from you because I’m having a real hard time putting together my workout routine.

Here’s why:

2/4 - Folly Beach Half Marathon
2/11 - GORUCK Double Light
2/17 - GORUCK Heavy
2/26 - GORUCK Gun Course (not a fitness event)
3/12 - Asheville Marathon
3/24 - Palmetto 200 Ultra team
4/6 - GORUCK Heavy Heavy
5/21 - Triathlon Sprint 1 of 5

I have long runs including a marathon and an ultra marathon relay. That requires a lot of running. I have GORUCK events, including a Heavy and a Heavy Heavy, both of which will be grueling and require a lot of ruck time and lifting. Then I start my triathlons and currently I have ZERO swim experience and I don’t even own a bike yet.

So, right now I need to be:

1. Running
2. Rucking
3. Lifting
4. Biking
5. Swimming
6. Yoga (helps prevent injury)

I’m easing up on the running because I feel pretty good. Right now it’s just about maintenance and not losing ground. I have to get more time under the ruck and I must continue lifting. Pretty much NOW I must start swimming three times a week.

Guys, I just don’t know how to fit it all in. I’m mentally prepared. I’ll work out three times a day. I don’t give a shit. I just can’t find the time. And honestly, I’m stressed as hell about it.

If you have any advice you’re willing to give on how I should balance all this, please let me know. Your advice is appreciated.

Have a phenomenal week!

Wesley
Excerpt: Weekly Fitness Update
Image Title: Seeking Advice On Upcoming Fitness Events

Title: Pay to Play Awards
Content:
“I’d like to thank my beautiful wife, my great kids, my Uncle Vic, my dog, my…” Wait. No. I’m not giving an acceptance speech for an industry award. How did we get to this point, anyway?

Here’s what I think happened: everyone who isn’t a professional athlete or a Hollywood movie star felt unappreciated and unrecognized, so an industry organization (or a fast-buck artist) set up an awards show. In some industries, LOTS of awards shows.

The advertising business is especially guilty in this regard (big show in Cannes, just like Hollywood has)—and political advertising is not far behind. I don’t get it. We need a big credenza in the lobby for trophies? Everyone is that desperate to have “award-winning” appear before his or her name?

Here’s what’s worse: I think the industry recognition shows routinely recognize companies and individuals for their accomplishment of paying entry fees. That's right. Because if you don't pay the entry fee, you don't win.
Many of these "awards shows" are not out to recognize the best work--they're just cash registers. It's pay to play.

No thanks.

This isn’t sour grapes on my part. And maybe if I were just starting out, it would make a difference to me if I won something. Know what makes a difference to me now? Winning elections. Winning more market share for clients. Winning people over to an advocacy groups’s position.

And I’d like to thank our clients and staff for making all of that ^ possible.

W.
Excerpt: Things That Drive Me Batshit Crazy #8

Title: The Only Thing That Matters
Content:
My thoughts on Friday night around 0200 There's only one thing that matters right now. It's not a dropped ball by a subcontractor, vendor or utility company. Its not the opening deadline of our brewery. It's not a client screwing me over. It's not the internal politics of politics or corporations. It's not the massive debt racked up by a client. It's not the personal problems of one staffer or the whining of another. It's not the pressure of making payroll this month. It’s not another family death. It's not a crying kid or finding time for Elizabeth. It's not all the things that have my mouth full of stress ulcers or what has me puking after morning workouts. It's not the excruciating pain shooting through my crushed back, shoulders, calves and feet. It's not how many hours we've gone or will go. It's not the miles in front of me. Only one thing in the entire world matters at this moment. Getting this damn 200 pound steel manhole cover to that railroad track. That's it. Don't drop it. Don't stop walking. Find joy in the pain. The obstacle is the way. Embrace this suck. Push harder. Stop being a little bitch right now. You’re reborn hard. Sing something. Caroline, heartbroken hard times never got us down. Walking the same line through every shady southern town. Hand in hand your arm 'round mine. Caroline, you do just fine. That's working. Keep singing. Shit, that hurts. I hope the guys behind me don't drop this thing. That's an immediate broken ankle. Keep singing. AAAAAAGGGGHHHH! You did it. We’re here. The railroad track. Now take another step. Get to that street light. It’s the only thing that matters.

(photo credit: GRT Rich Angelet)
Excerpt: My thoughts on Friday night around 0200
