Title: Digital Supplies Qualitative Insight Into Users True Feelings
Content:
We’re always busy on election nights, it comes with being a politics and crisis communications agency. And it’s worth knowing something we’ve discovered through monitoring election communications that has implications for political and corporate clients alike.

As election days near, while we monitor and manage our candidates’ digital campaigns, we begin to gain qualitative insight into how things could net out. It’s not a quant thing, in large part because there is not yet a reliable resource for analyzing the political intentions of the U.S. electorate. It’s more of a feeling, a sense driven by the tone and volume of commentary flowing on digital platforms.

Not to say polling and other assessment tools aren’t reliable. But, they don’t capture how people feel at their cores. Social media does.

So whether we’re reviewing organic social content, dark posts, forums or video comments, about two weeks out from an election, things begin to crystalize.

Case in point, we felt something coming ahead of last week’s midterms. The experience was a reminder digital has undoubtedly become the frontline, the tip of the spear, in understanding how people really feel.

The challenge is deciphering it, an intensive, manual process that requires manpower and diligence.

Specifically, digital can tell us how people really feel, just ahead of the election itself. Not months before, or years, but right before the end. It’s as much about timing voter commentary as it is where they share it.

Typically, we’d expect a lot of ‘toxic enthusiasm,’ troll behavior from the people opposing our candidates on, say, Facebook or Instagram throughout the cycle. And this year, there was plenty of that. But there was also a steady, intense parade of commentary from people who were making it clear they intended to vote, and not for Republicans.

There was far less “I’m definitely voting, Republican” than there was “Democrats can count on me.”

The opposition voters made a point over the last two weeks to seek out the Republicans in their districts, and let them know their plans. Or to post similar thoughts in forums, video comments, etc.

It wasn’t an overwhelming flood, more like a pugnacious stream. To the untrained eye, this may seem like gentle trolling. But when you spend as much time as we do researching how the public responds to content, A/B testing, revising and honing, you refine your ability to discern posturing from an actual shift in intention.

Now, no one could predict the specific outcomes that came to pass, particularly in Virginia. But it is fair to say digital can reveal changing tides, maybe even better than polls and pundits.

That should be valuable information to brands, whether they’re running digital campaigns, dealing with a crisis, or just trying to figure out what people really think of them.
Excerpt: Of course, it's digital.
Image Title: Digital Supplies Qualitative Insight Into Users True Feelings
Image Caption: Digital Supplies Qualitative Insight Into Users True Feelings
Image Alt Text: Digital Supplies Qualitative Insight Into Users True Feelings

Title: It's My Birthday and I Really Need This...
Content: I turned 38 years old today. And while I’m no longer the young crazy guy that I used to be, I still have a ways to go until I’m a senior citizen. It’s hard watching our parents and grandparents get old. Watching Elizabeth’s grandmother suffer from dementia for years before her passing was devastating to our entire family. That’s why I’m dedicating my birthday and why Elizabeth is dancing for the ARK. The ARK provides hope and relief to families living with Alzheimer’s Disease or a related Dementia through support services such as respite care, support groups, education, caregiver consultations, resource referrals and community development. Each year they host a dancing contest - Dancing With The ARK’s Stars - and this year Elizabeth is one of the celebrity dancers. She’ll be dancing the tango. Her goal is to raise $5,000 by February. I know you can part with $10 today. Maybe even $20. As a birthday gift to me, please click here now and help us support our aging neighbors suffering from Alzheimer’s and Dementia. Every week, I send you awesome content to help you grow your campaign, business and personal brand. I’ve never asked for anything in return. Now I’m asking. This would mean a lot to us. Please click here now and chip in whatever you can today. Thank you. POSITIVE VIBES! Wesley
Excerpt: 38 feels great.

Title: The Toughest Time Of The Year, Every Year
Content: This is always the toughest time of the year for me. For the last three years, I have gotten really sick. As the weather changes I also pick up my mileage for marathon season. My immune system gets diminished and I get hit by the little germ factories in my house… the kids. Right now, I write this laying in the bed. My sixth straight day in the bed. I'm going quite stir crazy, so I thought maybe I should finally blog again. This time of the year is also tough because we’re closing out the books. And I hate talking money. We have to go through the budgets to see what we did right and what we did wrong, so we can set the next year's budgets. We have to hound all of our clients to pay all of their old bills. We have to renew all of our contracts for the following year. We have to set client budgets for the following year. We have to do staff reviews and that always brings up raises. It's the most stressful and worst part of being a business owner. I wish I could just never talk money and only come up with winning strategies and awesome creative. The health issue and the financial issues aren't completely separate issues. The work stress is probably the biggest detriment on my health. I just go hard until my body collapses. Full throttle is all I know. The demons of my past can't catch me if I'm always running, figuratively and literally. All this time in bed has given me a lot of opportunity to not only catch up on superhero shows but to also think about about my content. It's so scattered and inconsistent. And it has been for many years.. You guys know how much I love pumping out content but the problem I have is that I'm too interested in too many things. Some days I like to talk about politics. Some days I like to talk about marketing. Some days I like to talk about entrepreneurship. And some days I like to talk about fitness. But isn't that okay? That just means I'm a real person. I do focus on different things. Why should I try to fake it and be focused on just one thing? That's not me. I should be transparent and authentic in all of my content. As for my readers, some things they will find interesting and some things they won't. What they will always find is the struggles of a real entrepreneur. Really that is what is missing in the market place. We read and watch enough content about superstars who are balling out. YouTube and the magazine racks are full of those stories. What we don't see are the struggles of the normal everyday entrepreneur. Maybe instead of getting focused, this blog should do the opposite. Maybe it should be unfocused so that you can actually help me get focused. Maybe it should be a place for me to just vent. Sometimes written, sometimes audio and maybe one day I'll get back on the Vlog. Sidenote: I adore vlogging but the video team has been too slammed to help me. I'm hiring a third video editor now, which will hopefully give us the bandwidth for me to hop back on it. I don’t mean to be all over the place today. That’s just where the fever has me. Delirious. What I’m Watching: I just finished The Punisher and it was AWESOME. It’s my new favorite Marvel Netflix show. What I’m Reading: It’s Not How Good You Are, It’s How Good You Want To Be by Paul Arden. It’s a very short pocket Bible for creatives. What I’m Training For: A big goal for 2017 was to PR at the Kiawah Marathon. Unfortunately, it’s now looking like this illness will stop me from running the marathon this coming Saturday. I’m pretty bummed. Next up is the Disney Dopey - a 5k, 10k, half marathon and marathon - 4 straight days - in early January. What I’m Listening To: Uncivil podcast by Gimlet Media. It’s about the untold stories of the Civil War.
Excerpt: I'm sick, sidelined and scatterbrained.
Image Title: The Toughest Time Of The Year, Every Year
Image Caption: The Toughest Time Of The Year, Every Year
Image Alt Text: The Toughest Time Of The Year, Every Year

Title: Yes, You Can Hustle Too Hard.
Content: I'm really good at making goals and hitting them. Set a goal. Determine the path. Create a timeline. Break down the timeline to monthly and weekly milestones. Break that down into daily to dos. Stay dedicated. Measure and pivot when needed. It’s a pretty simple formula, as long as you can remain firm on point six –stay dedicated. Unfortunately, unforeseen circumstances can jump in the way too late in the game for point seven, measure and pivot, to even matter. That’s when it’s time to uncover the hidden point, point eight –reset and try again. All year I’ve had a big goal of setting a marathon PR at the Kiawah Marathon on December 9th. That’s this Saturday. I’ve trained hard for months and I was at the final two steps, run a 20 miler and taper. It was on my 20 miler that I first realized I was getting sick. My heart rate skyrocketed, I was dizzy and I puked twice between hailing an Uber at mile 7. I tried running another five miles that afternoon and then another six the following day (last Tuesday). That six miler was the straw that broke the camel's back. By the time I got home a couple hours later, I was shaking and sweating profusely. I went to bed and woke up at 2 am with a 102.8 degree fever. I’ve been in bed pretty much every hour since. It’s now one week later and I’m finally up and back to work. I feel better but I feel far from great. My body is weakened and my sinuses are crushed. It’s time to call it. There’s no friggin' way I’m PRing at Kiawah this weekend. And because I can’t PR, there’s no reason to run the race at all. It sucks. In less than a month, the entire family leaves for our first Disney World trip, where Elizabeth and I will be taking on the Dopey Challenge: a 5k, 10k, half marathon and marathon in four straight days. We’ve dropped a fortune on this trip. It would be stupid of me to try to run Kiawah, kill my immune system even more and not feel great for Disney. So here I am, totally bummed. I didn’t hit one of my biggest goals for 2017. So point eight it is –reset and try again. What I’m Watching: The Gifted - a new Marvel TV show set in the X-Men universe. What I’m Listening To: I’m really feeling Shovels and Rope today. I’ve listened to Little Seeds four times already. What I’m In To: Journaling and meditation. If I can’t train my body right now, I might as well concentrate on training my mind. What I’m Not Into: Closing out the books for 2017 and concentrating on company financials. THE EFFING WORST!
Excerpt: I’ve written a lot about this topic.
Image Title: Yes, You Can Hustle Too Hard.
Image Caption: Yes, You Can Hustle Too Hard.
Image Alt Text: Yes, You Can Hustle Too Hard.

Title: Merry Christmas, Happy New Year and Nothing But Positive Vibes. I’m Out!
Content:
Dear Friends,

It’s time for me to disappear for a few weeks and concentrate on my business and my family. I must deconstruct 2017, figure out what went right, meditate on what went wrong, set the goals and plan for 2018. Then, I’ll spend the holidays with my awesome family before heading to Disney for the Dopey races. I’ll reemerge back on the digital scene in early January. I promise.

So for now... no new blogs. No new VLOGS. And no new videos.

My team will be publishing several 2017 wrap ups with our favorite content from this year. As for me, I'll be in hiding.

This has been one of the best years of my life. Lots of downs, but many, many more ups. I just want to thank each of you for all of your support, love, prayers and positive vibes throughout the year. Seriously, you fuel all the hustle.

Next year is going to be the biggest year yet. I have some extremely huge announcements around my personal content, the Push Digital brand and some new content that's coming soon. Expect all of that as soon as I return in January.

One closing thought...

God made himself man to walk among us as Jesus Christ so that he could bring love and peace to our world. Love and peace, people. I know that some of you reading this may not be Christian. I’m going to guess that the super majority of you are. Or at least that’s what you call yourself.

I fell in love with the Internet and made digital my career because I thought this would be the place where we could all join hands and solve the world’s problems. Instead, it’s become a place that fuels anger and hate.

My final call of 2017 is to ask you to remember why God became man. Take this time of the year to analyze the words coming from your fingertips as you play online. Analyze the tone of your heart. Ask yourself if you are displaying the peace and love God has asked and demanded you to display.

Do you truly love your neighbors? Do you have and display empathy? Does the image of baby Jesus and the words, “Peace on Earth and goodwill toward men,” reflect your general life philosophy?

“Listen to what I say
Pray for peace, people everywhere.
Listen to what I say
A child, a child, sleeping in the night
He will bring us goodness and light.

He will bring us goodness and light.”

Positive Vibes!
Excerpt: Peace.
Image Title: Merry Christmas, Happy New Year and Nothing But Positive Vibes. I’m Out!
Image Caption: Wishing You Positive Vibes In 2018

Title: WAIT –How Many Days Did This Year Have?
Content: Man. This has been one heck of a year. I swear it must have had like 500 days in it or something. No seriously, just look at everything we managed to pack in: The Brewery After many delays and minor frustrations… we finally opened the new Frothy Beard Brewing Company location in West Ashely! The grand opening was absolutely killer and just happened to fall on the same weekend as St. Patrick’s Day and our Fourth Anniversary. It was nuts. Once the guys started brewing, we quickly realized that our baby 10bbl tanks were not cutting it, so of course we increased the brewery's capacity by adding more tanks. BIGGER TANKS. Three 30 barrels baby. Quadrupling our brewing capacity increased our distribution and just like that it was time to start canning. We really busted ass on this thing. The Training So I decided to participate in a triathlon with just one small obstacle: I’m a 37 year old man that didn’t know how to swim. Kind of a big thing, right? Yeah and that’s one-third of the tri. Literally it took months for me to eliminate the panic attacks. Basically just started by blowing bubbles and got some coaching from my buddy Chris. It was much harder than I thought, but well worth conquering a fear. After a couple of months, I was actually able to swim well enough to compete in my first Ironman race. It was a half, but only the beginning. This year my training is focused on a full Ironman in September. Gotta get that tattoo. Push Digital Oh, and for that digital creative agency I founded… 2017 was our biggest and baddest year yet by far. Clients, revenue, staff—growing, growing, growing. Creative…we received notoriety for a SeaWorld video that was ranked as THE BEST TRAVEL AD ON RECORD. And then it was covered by ADWEEK as the Ad Of The Day. Doesn’t get much better than that. Still in shock. Here’s the big thing for 2018… we are already at max capacity in our new space here and our staffers are practically sitting on top of each other. But I’m fixing it with a bigger and more badass office next door. We’re knocking down walls and taking on big brand names. We’re working with clients and getting inquiries from others that I could only have dreamed of just a few years ago. It’s happening. Push is happening. The whole thing is insane and I’m psyched. I’m a lucky man. And I don't just think that on December 31st. All year long I am so thankful for my fantastic wife and children, my staff, our clients, my partners at Frothy and Zombie Bob’s, my F3 brothers and all my other friends. I am blessed. Simple as that. Watch out 2018… nothing but Positive Vibes.
Excerpt: This 365 flew by.

Title: My Favorite Personal Content Of 2017
Content: I've said this before, but December is typically a crazy time in the office. We're wrapping up content calendars and crunching the numbers for next year's budgets, but between all of that and chasing around my precious boys and smoking hot wife, I found a little bit of time to create a new strategy for next year's blog. Don't worry, I'm definitely going to keep pumping out the content... but it could be in a different format. That's all I'm saying cause new content will be here soon enough. This year though, my blog was all over the place. Which is weird because I'm a super structured and organized individual. Like serial killer status. However, I also like a lot of cool shit and I wanted to share it with y'all. So, you know, here we are. But even though my blog was all over the place, my goal was to just keep it real and be my authentic self. I really wanted to share my struggles, and by doing so, I hope that I helped others who feel like they're constantly under water too. Because we all struggle. Whether it's losing weight or breaking down your business goals, struggle is every where and in every form. More than that though, I was hoping y'all would also keep me accountable. And y'all did. Even when my body was calling it quits, my mind was still running in circles so I continued to put pen to paper. From discussing my entrepreneurial endeavors or just belaboring that fact that I'm addicted to fitness, writing has become way more than just a creative outlet for me. I'm all about transparency and sharing my best and worst self with y'all. And I think I did just that. Check out a few of my favorite personal pieces from this year. Jesus Spent 40 Days Embracing The Suck Read this story every day, find a trait in Jesus that you can take, and use it in your daily life. How Do You Have So Much Time? I hope some of this advice can help you find more time in your week, allowing you to knock out some big goals you’ve been waiting to tackle. Push Does These Three Things We specialize. Rather than trying to be all things to all clients, we do three things and we do them really well. Ready? I Live My Life By The Pareto Principle  Have you heard of the 80/20 rule? It’s really called the Pareto Principle, named after an Italian economist named Vilfredo Pareto. Why I Call Out Individuals When They Drop Balls I think it’s a great opportunity for team building along with being a teachable moment. Why? Continuing My Journey Toward A Tattoo Somehow a boy from Goose Creek has made it to 37 with no ink. I'm going to straight up earn one. You Can't Just Do Digital Too I’m totally calling BS on political consulting firms and marketing agencies in general that claim they “do digital, too.” The Struggle Is Real Ignore all the fake bullshit click bait articles. If you want to know the real story, here it is. It’s a struggle, but somehow it’s a manageable struggle. What's In My Kit Last week a buddy asked “what all do you have in your kit?” I started pulling out a wide variety of objects and thought “man, this might be blog worthy.” This Why There Are So Many Positive Vibes  The struggle is real. But the struggle can be overcome when you surround yourself with an amazing team fueled by positive vibes. No more negativity. Ever. Death By Opioid Overdose  This is my most personal blog yet... America needs to WAKE UP. Death by opioid overdose is a problem and it's been knocking on our door for a long time. I'm Positive About Fighting Negativity During my morning commute to the pool, I had a huge epiphany. Learn why I've been unhappy for so long and how positive vibes IS going to change it. Two Tips For Training Your Face Off A lot of people have been asking me for "workout' advice, well, here it is: Don't workout. You have to train. Here are two tips for training your face off. I Am Winston Wolf, I Solve Problems Every brand needs someone to call when they have royale-with-cheese sized problems. Push is that agency because our world is crisis, we live and breathe it. Lastly, all of my VLOGS. If I could turn one of these babies out every single day, I would. I'm obsessed. Not with me, but how awesome my team makes them look. Watch the whole playlist here.

Blogs, infographics, ads, videos, memes, gifs and etc. We do it all. And we do it well. Really freakin' well actually. Title: Crisis Communications Is A Sprint
Excerpt: Toss out the cliché.
Image Caption: Crisis Communications Is A Sprint

Title: At Push Digital, We Sprint.
Content:
This is actually a topic we’ve written about quite a bit in the past year. But for some reason, the speed at which corporations function is still pretty shocking to us, no matter how many big name brands we pick up. The fact is that crises are inevitable. Whether you’re a celebrity, a major corporation, a politician or even a first grade teacher. At some point in time, you will get punched in the face by a PR nightmare. What do you do? We recommend that you hit the ground running. And you keep running–for months and months and months.

There’s a little saying that goes, “It’s a marathon, not a sprint.” When it comes to Crisis Communications, ignore that phrase 100%. Growing up in the political campaign realm, you come to learn that time is the most precious commodity, so you don’t waste it. You can raise more money. You can recruit more volunteers. You can’t create more time. There is an election date that is set and it’s not moving! Corporations should have the exact same mind set, but they don’t. And I think that’s why the way our company operates is so refreshing for our new clients. We’re sprinters.

In today’s digital age, a lie can become a fact in just seconds, so your team better have the story straight and they better be ready to spill the beans ASAP. Because, almost immediately, your brand reputation has taken a huge hit. You may think, “Oh well, no one really cares about the small strand of salmonella found in our chocolate eggs because we’re a trusted family brand blah blah blaaah...” But that couldn’t be further from the truth. Mommies everywhere will have absolutely no problem writing your name off of their shopping lists, forever. The longer you wait to spread the truth and remedy the mistake, the further your brand falls on the buggy blacklist.

It may have been a little rash to recommend that you completely ignore the above phrase, because truly, Crisis Communications is a little bit of both. When your company is in a crisis, your teams’ butts better be sprinting to tell the truth, to take corrective action and to apologize over and over and over again. However, when it comes to rebuilding your brand, you're in for a content marketing marathon. Your team is pivoting. You sprinted out of the gate and now you’re settling into cruise control with positive content about your brand on every channel. Prepare a long-term content plan and then rub it in your readers’ faces. Every single day. Sure, that salmonella strain was pretty sucky, we admit it… but don’t you remember searching for us in your Easter basket when you were growing up in Newberry, SC? We were there! You loved us. And you still love us… See what we did there?

Moral of the story:  with crisis communications, it’s a marathon AND a sprint. Make sure the person advising you knows how to set the pace.
Excerpt: Empty the tanks.
Image Caption: At Push Digital, We Sprint.

Title: Zero Excuses
Content: Did a podcast the other day with this ^ as the title. Right up my alley, right? Absolutely. Kenyon Zitzka was the interviewer—he does personal and business coaching—super cool dude. We had a pretty damn good conversation. You can listen to the episode here OR just keep reading. Here’s some of what we talked about: Many of you know I grew up poor. How poor? Section 8 housing, food stamps, Medicaid kind of poor. The people who only know me as a conservative Republican political strategist and entrepreneur assume I grew up in country clubs. Far from it. You know what they say when you assume... But I’ll say this. My mother used government assistance the way it was meant to be used—temporarily. She went to cosmetology school and learned to cut hair. She was raising me and my sister by herself (after divorcing my abusive father) and she knew she would have to work hard at a decent job to support us. And so she did. My introduction to politics happened around that time. In fact, it was a redistricting proposal (to send all of us poor kids to the same school) and I spoke out at a School Board meeting about it. Literally, I became the “face” of the issue. I also met a state senator in between 8th and 9th grade. That was a really big deal for me, even bigger when he contacted me about working for him. You mean, you can get paid for doing politics? (Light bulb.) After high school, I went to the University of South Carolina as an engineering major. That’s another Wesley you may not know—Nerd Wesley. Star Trek Wesley. Whatever, you actually do know him. But I hate math. And I hated engineering... so I switched to political science. Then never looked back. Ran for USC Republican Chair and State Republican Chair. Basically, my goal was to work on every campaign I could get my hands on. Generally, people are drawn to politics for a cause. For me, that was believing (and hoping) I could actually make a difference. Me. Section 8 kid. Working in the statehouse. Where people make THE LAWS. After college, I worked at a few different political firms, then got the entrepreneurial bug and started my own place. When I made a little more money, I hired my first employee. Made more, so I hired the second one. I've always been a firm believer in spending money to make money. And as hard as it's been to pass off my baby, I've got my own babies at home so I got over it real quick. Last week we officially hired number 40. Oh. And we work on a lot more than just politics now. We have several corporate clients and pump out a lot more issue advocacy work, brand reputation and crisis communications. Those last two are our specialties these days. Some of our clients are Marco Rubio, SeaWorld, Sears and Kmart. And now we have, in my opinion, the sickest office in the state... possibly the Southeast. While we're sitting on top of each at the moment, cause we're expanding in the 3500 square feet next door, at least our staffers get a brewery and a pizza kitchen to hold them over. Could be worse... Just ask the poor kid.
Excerpt: Got candid with Kenyon.
Image Caption: Zero Excuses

Title: A Review Of The Disney Dopey & Marathon Weekend
Content: The first week of January my beautiful wife and I loaded up the kids and we headed to Disney World. Sure, you're thinking, "Awe how cute they're going on vacation with the kiddos..." Wrong. E and I decided to compete in the Disney Dopey, which is a four day race (5K, 10K, Half Marathon & Full Marathon). But we had an absolute blast. Disney knows how to organize and keep people energized. We were running in the early morning and then chasing the kids around the parks during the day. By day four we were both mentally and physically exhausted but we rocked it. Check out my AAR which is WAAAAAAAAY longer than usual. I decided to cut this video because the blogs I read and videos I watched before the race really helped me. I hope this can help some of you training for the races.
Excerpt: Disney knows how to get shit done.

Title: No One Watches My YouTube Videos And I Don't Care
Content: This question popped on my Youtube channel this morning so I wanted to address it. Because... you know... he’s right. No one watches my YouTube videos. No one. [caption id="attachment_1753" align="aligncenter" width="600"] This guy ain't wrong... but here's why I'm right.[/caption] Here’s the truth - I fundamentally believe that I built my company on content. I didn’t have a lot of national connections. I didn’t have partners funneling business to me for kickbacks. I never wanted to make round through the DC circuit and kiss ass at happy hours every evening. I had to show that I knew what I was talking about by actually talking about it. At the same time, I had to prove that I was right by showing results. And I did that through content. Today we pump out far more content than any of our competitors and I’m also pumping out a lot of personal content on a daily basis. So when you look at the raw YouTube views, you probably think I’m wasting my time. But frankly, I don’t really give a damn about YouTube. Personally, I watch A TON of YouTube and it’s actually my preferred social network. I spend way more time there than I do Facebook, Instagram or Twitter combined. But while I consume a ton of content there, it’s not necessarily the platform for the audience I’m trying to reach. I reach my audience in two ways: Facebook. I get thousands of views on each video because I put money behind them and target audiences who need a digital agency like Push. I can reach that audience cheaper on Facebook than I can on YouTube. We actually do a little advertising on YouTube also, but those paid numbers won’t be reflected in our organic views. Email. I have cultivated a large email list. I embed the YouTube videos into blog posts and then link those blog posts in emails. That’s where most of those YouTube views come from. My videos don’t rank high on YouTube. No one finds them organically. I’ve never spent the time on my videos to get them ranked higher like I do for our clients. I don’t need to. I’m not trying to reach the masses. I’m trying to reach a few select targets. And in that scenario –I’m effing killing it.
Excerpt: A troll with some truth.

Title: Fire and Fury: Michael Wolff Wrote the Dems’ 2018 Midterm Playbook
Content: The 2018 midterm election season has just begun, and already it’s promising to be one of the ugliest races in American history. There are many reasons for this, but the most recent is certainly the publication of Michael Wolff’s book, Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House. Many parts of the book have been widely discredited, furthering confusion and eroding trust in journalism. Regardless, the end result is things will be harder for Republicans, who control both the House, Senate, and governor’s seats. I know this because running digital political campaigns are a core part of what we do at Push, and the book is essentially a fishbowl of one-liners perfectly written to knock Republican candidates down a peg or three. When the president’s party is in control of the House and Senate, it automatically does two things. First, it makes each candidate (whether it’s a senator, representative or governor) a proxy for the president. They have to align themselves with the president or risk losing much-needed support from the White House. How can a candidate hope to help their constituents if the president doesn’t agree with their politics? Second, it puts the controlling party on the defensive. Any conservative legislation will become a rallying cry for democrats.   As a for instance, take the tax bill. Democrats will rail against the bill in their campaigns, how it robbed Main Street and lined Wall Street’s pockets. It will be a central theme, right up there with healthcare, infrastructure, immigration, national security. So, republicans will be on the defensive. Add to that a scorcher like Fire and Fury, and the ante has been upped dramatically. The primary effect the book will have is to codify the narrative that the president isn’t fit for office. And by proxy, neither are any republican candidates who support him. It will remind Americans that there’s discord everywhere, from his team in the White House to the House, Senate and even the governor’s association. Take the notion that President Trump’s inner circle doesn’t believe in him, or more worryingly, didn’t think he was going to win. The book alleges that even the president himself didn’t think a victory was possible. The social copy for dems writes itself; “The president didn’t think he would win, and now he’s the leader of the free world. Let’s not empower him by giving up more seats in the (house/senate/governor’s office).” Or put another way; “Republicans don’t support the president, neither should you.” Mental fitness is a central theme to the book, and questions of the president’s capacity to lead abound. For instance, the idea that he isn’t smart prompted what will certainly become one of the president’s most infamous tweets, in which he calls himself a “stable genius.” That he used the phrase himself opens dems up to put the quote next to any issue their party members dislike. “The stable genius’ tax bill wasn’t so smart after all.” Or, “Only a ‘stable genius’ would think a wall between the US and Mexico is a good idea.” The stockpile of ammunition grows taller by the page. He doesn’t process information well; he repeats himself word for word multiple times over a ten minute period; there is more backstabbing in the White House than your average reality TV show. The list goes on. And while the book will certainly provide political campaigners of all stripes (from TV to digital and everything in between), digital is where it will be put to use most fervently. Why? As we learned in 2016, A/B testing wins elections. Volumes of content will pour through your Facebook feed, attempting to coax you into a like, comment, share and ultimately, a vote. This content will spread far and wide via social, codifying party-line democrats. But that’s not the problem. The real issue is it will get in front of centrists, swing and non voters, bringing them ever-closer to voting democrat. This is what republican campaigns are going to have to deal with, and why 2018 will be one of the ugliest races in American history.
Excerpt: Centrists, swing and non voters are in trouble.

Title: Trey Gowdy Is The Best Congressman In America
Content:
Congressman Trey Gowdy is a client. He has been for a long time. I worked on his first congressional campaign and today I serve as his chief digital strategist. FUN FACTS: 1 Trey Gowdy raises more money online than any other congressman. (At least that’s what we’re told). He could literally send out an email that says “What’s up? Sincerely, Trey Gowdy” with a donate button and raise $25,000. 2 Trey Gowdy ranks as one of the most popular politicians in South Carolina. The guy’s numbers would make you believe he walks on water. 3 Trey Gowdy is the most popular politician in his district. That’s one of the most conservative districts in America. One would read these fun facts and automatically assume that Trey is part of the fringe. He’s a political beast who tosses out red meat for breakfast, lunch and dinner. He’s in lockstep with President Trump on everything. Yet this is Trey Gowdy...

Keeping in mind that Trey is a “no bullshit, do what’s right for the country, screw Washington games, results before party, the ends don’t justify the means” politician AND he raises a ton of cash while remaining one of the most popular politicians at home and perhaps even in the nation, you have to ask — why don’t more politicians adopt his attitude? You know the answer. Because most politicians care too much about being in Washington and you can’t have it both ways. You can’t have that “no Washington games” attitude while also working to stay in office forever in order to climb that ladder up the hill. For years, Trey has been complaining to everyone who would listen how much he hates Washington. He didn’t want to be there. He could not care less if he was re-elected. And that’s what makes him the best Congressman in America. Americans are going to get the elected officials we deserve. Go on the internet for 13 seconds and you know we don’t deserve people like Trey Gowdy who just want to solve problems. We’re way more interested in throwing shit than in solving problems.
Excerpt: Gowdy come back!

Title: A Government That Pushes And Rewards Hard Work
Content: I’ve been having an identity crisis lately. I own a Republican digital agency. I’ve been working for the Republican Party since I was fifteen years old. I spent my college years and my entire adult life helping build the Republican Party. But now I look at recent debates and I ask myself “am I still a Republican?” It’s a hard question to answer, but there is an easier one to answer - why did you BECOME a Republican? In this podcast interview with Zero Xcuses I give that answer. Put simply, I am a Republican because I grew up surviving on government handouts - Section 8 housing, welfare, Medicaid and food stamps. If not for government, my mom, sister and I would have been on the streets. But while government helped us survive, I also saw that it trapped my neighbors in a system in which they could not escape. They became dependent. You hear politicians talk about “a hand up and not a hand out.” I believe that, but when I say it, I’m not just giving you a cliche talking point. I’m giving you a direct observation and life lesson. There are two stories. There is the story of my mom, who used government for a few years, went to school to become a cosmetologist, got a job and got off the system. Then there is my dad who used government checks as an excuse not to work. He watched TV all day, became lazy and bored and then turned to drugs. As he laid on his deathbed the doctor told me “it wasn’t the cancer that killed him. The meth took his immune system.” Here’s what I believe... I believe in helping people when they truly need help. I believe in a system that pushes and rewards hard work. I believe we must not trap people in a system that empowers them to fail at life. As long as the Republican Party believes that and acts on it, I am still a Republican. When the party leaves me, I will leave the party.
Image Title: A Government That Pushes And Rewards Hard Work

Title: How I Built A Badass Digital Agency
Content: They say the best way to eat an elephant is one bite at a time. That's how I grew Push Digital into a 42 person badass machine - one staffer at a time over seven years. I didn't start with cash in the bank. No large investments and a crazy hiring spree. No fancy office. I started with one $500 a month client and a dream. I made just enough money to pay the bills at home. Nothing big, somewhere around $30,000. Instead of paying myself more when I made more, I hired my first staffer. Part time at first and then full time. Then I hired another. Then another. Then another. Finally around my seventh staffer I gave myself a small $10,000 raise. Then I hired more. It has never been about putting money in my pocket today. It's always been about the dream - building a long term sustainable company. Here's my advice to budding entrepreneurs: forget the fancy suits, cars and boats. Put on a hard hat and build, build, build. That's what I did. And that's what I'm doing.
Image Title: Wesley Donehue How I Built A Badass Digital Agency

Title: The Coolest Digital Agency Office In America, Maybe THE WORLD
Content: Michael and I were sitting on a Charleston beach, beers in hand while taking a break from a game of bocce ball. We started talking about the kind of company I wanted to build. I say “I” because this was before Michael even joined the team. In fact, this was the conversation where that subject was first broached. “You know what would be badass? If I put Push Digital inside of a brewery. Even Google doesn’t have that,” I said. Admittedly, it was a pretty dumb idea. How would that make any sense at all? Well... I’ll tell you how it would make sense - if you actually owned the brewery. Years later the dream was realized when I invested into Frothy Beard Brewing Company and Zombie Bob’s Pizza. Both needed a new space and Push was expanding. Why the heck wouldn’t we put them all in one place? Now we have the coolest office ever and we’re not done yet. Push is expanding 3,500 square feet and giving up some current space to Frothy, giving Frothy the only private brewery taproom seating in Charleston. Hear the whole story in this snippet from the Zero Xcuses podcast.

Title: The Explosion of Craft Beer in South Carolina
Content: How did we go from being one of the least craft beer friendly states to one of the best states in the nation for craft beer? How did we explode from six to fifty-two breweries in about six years? Four laws and teamwork. In 2007, the badasses at Coast Brewing Company in Charleston led the legislative fight to increase the 5% ABV cap to 17.5% ABV, which gave the industry the ability to really open up craft beer styles to the state. To put that into perspective, we have eighteen beers on tap today at Frothy Beard Brewing. Only six are 5% or lower. The law solidified Jaime and Dave of Coast as the true pioneers of South Carolina craft beer. It was about that time that I started falling in love with craft beer. I visited every craft brewery around the nation that I could and kept wondering why we in South Carolina couldn’t have what North Carolina has. I met Jaime and she explained our antiquated laws and how the biggest hindrance is that they couldn’t sell pints or growlers on premises. They were limited to small samples. Since I worked in the South Carolina Senate and I got a ton of House members elected, I thought I could use my connections to make a difference. Jaime and I teamed up with attorney and craft beer loving freak Brooke Bristow and our little trio went head to head with some of the most powerful lobbyists in the state. Brooke handled the legal aspect. Jaime riled up the brewers and grassroots. I worked the legislative game. With no money, no lobbyists, no real craft beer association - and with the amazing help of Senator Sean Bennett and Representative Derham Cole (both craft beer nerds) - we (literally) snuck through The Pint Law, allowing craft breweries to sell pints and growlers directly to customers in their taproom. To put that into perspective, about 85% of Frothy Beard’s income comes from on-premises sales so you can see why that allowed was the spark that created the craft beer explosion. The next step came when we heard that Stone Brewing Company, based in San Diego, CA, wanted to open an east coast operation and South Carolina was an option. I knew that South Carolina legislators didn’t care about beer, but they did care about jobs. So we used the opportunity to get the next thing we wanted; the ability to serve food and unlimited beer on premises (the Pint Law only allows for three pints), both of which Stone would want if they were to move here. The band got back together, with lobbyist Sarah Hazzard joining in on the fun. Chris Brown from Holy City, John Bauknight from RJ Rockers and Will McCameron from Brewery85 all worked their asses off. We launched the South Carolina Beer Jobs campaign, and the distributors, on behalf of the big beer companies, went ape shit. At one point, they had eighteen powerful lobbyists at the South Carolina Statehouse and we had Sarah, Brooke, and me. We weren’t just David vs Goliath. We were like Fraggles against Goliath. But this wasn’t about craft beer. This was about jobs. That’s the only thing I’d let our team talk about. If we just offered huge incentives to lure Boeing, we should change two silly little laws to lure Stone, especially given that tourism is our top industry. Push Digital launched a digital campaign flooding Statehouse offices with calls and emails. Jaime got the craft beer community doing the same. I called in every favor I could. Sarah worked her magic and pulled off a hat-trick in the House. And somehow, we won! Now, a South Carolina brewery can have a restaurant, and if they do, they can serve as much beer to a customer as the customer can handle. Last year, we took one more small step on behalf of brewpubs like Edmund’s Oast and Hunter-Gatherer by passing a law allowing brewpubs to distribute their beer. Just this week, Edmund’s Oast beers hit taps and shelves, something that could not have happened just a year ago. That’s progress. So, what’s next? Organization. I’ve helped pass three laws by calling in favors with no paid lobbyist and no official association structure. That ends today. Not because I don’t love this community and won’t help, but because it’s time for a few people to stop carrying all the water and for all those who benefit to step up. If the craft beer industry in South Carolina wants any more progress, every brewery needs to become paying members of the South Carolina Brewers Guild. The Guild needs to hire a lobbyist who can be at the Statehouse every day. Brewers are known for being chill as hell. That’s why I love them. But sometimes you can be too chill. If any more progress is to be made, it will require fighters. A lot of people worked their asses off to build this industry, but the people I want to call out specifically, most of whom I already named, are: Jaime Tenny Dave Merritt Sean Bennett Derham Cole Paul Campbell Sarah Hazzard Brooke Bristow Chris Brown MIchael Biondi John Bauknight Will McCameron All of them are beer heroes.

Title: Where Does Your Motivation Come From?
Content: Motivation can come from a lot of different places. Some folks are running to something. Others are running from something. I talk a lot about setting goals here on my blog, to my staff and to my clients. Yet when it comes to my personal and family goals, and to a small part even my business goals, I’m not running to something. I’m running from something. That’s where my motivation comes from. That’s why I’m always moving. My parents and my step-father died pretty young. Two of my best friends, Connie and Derrick, both died way too young. That showed me how short life can be. Life is too short to waste in front of a TV. Sure, I watch the occasional movie and even occasionally binge a Netflix show, but you won’t find me sitting in front of a TV for hours every day like way too many Americans. Here’s something that's been really bothering me lately. Let me get all defensive for a minute... I recently learned that when some of my competitors are pitching business against me, the attack they use against Push Digital is that I personally spend more time working out or drinking beer than I do concentrating on my clients. You see... that’s the bullshit I’m talking about. I out work every single one of my competitors. That’s my super power. I can embrace the suck and the stress more than anyone I know. I do mean ANYONE. I’m able to give my clients the attention they deserve AND do those other things because I don’t sit on my ass in front of a TV all night like most people. My down time is still my up time. I’m sorry that my Instagram feed is way more full of roads and gyms than me sitting in front of my computer. I thought the latter was pretty damn boring. And by the way, owning a brewery doesn’t mean I sit around and drink beer all day. In fact, now that I own a brewery I drink about half the amount that I did. Beer is now business. And I work my ass off at it. Ok, now that I’ve sounded all defensive, which by the way... I AM, here’s a great new clip from my interview with Zero Xcuses...
Image Title: Where Does Your Motivation Come From?

Title: Brad Parscale’s Rise In The Trump Campaign Is A Very Big Deal
Content:
The Republican digital agency sphere is pretty small. I know most of the players. While we’ve all worked against each other for the better part of a decade, we’ve all worked with each other in the fight to prove digital’s place in political campaigns. Brad Parscale, the biggest name in digital politics right now, I’ve never met. I’ve never talked to him. He probably doesn’t know who I am. The dude came out of nowhere. Yet, he’s done something the rest of us have been unable to do. He hasn’t just put digital front and center in a large campaign. He’s literally taken over the biggest campaign in the world, the President’s re-elect.

Frankly, I’ve had my beef with articles detailing the Trump digital campaign. I didn’t at all agree with the articles claiming the Trump Facebook strategy was innovative. Maybe there was something behind the scenes that we aren’t seeing, but the point that targeting a ton of niche audiences with niche content on Facebook is nothing new. We do it on every campaign we work on and we’ve done it for a couple cycles now. If anything, Parscale had the financial resources to target MORE audiences with MORE messages. Truly, that’s badass. But it’s not an innovative strategy like so many reporters have pointed out. I mean, not that they know what they’re talking about. They’re the same reporters who claim that digital agencies make tens-of-millions of dollars without knowing our explaining that our agencies serve as a pass-through for advertising dollars.

Nevertheless, I’m a Parscale fan and I know what he’s done is good for our party and our industry. I, along with the leadership of agencies like Targeted Victory, Harris Media, Prosper Group, IMAGE and others have been in the trenches fighting for every dollar we can get allocated to digital. The TV guys fought back, refusing to admit that digital was on the rise. Every dollar taken away from their line item was a few cents taken out of their pockets. As soon as they could no longer claim that digital wasn’t worth the investment, they began bringing digital in-house so they could get those dollars too. They’ve been screwing us over for years.

Then comes Parscale, an outsider with a direct line to a candidate with a lot of money, who hasn’t had to put up with all the bullshit. He was in the right place at the right time and picked up a candidate that did not carry the same baggage as the other general and TV consultants that he had been fighting for a decade. It was the perfect storm for a man like Pascale. He was able to not only prove the merits of digital, but to also climb the ladder and gain real leadership on this team. Frankly, that’s something I have personally been unable to do because in 99% of Republican political campaigns, digital teams are still put at the kids' table. We get no dollars, no say so and all the blame when the candidate decides to Google his/her name and doesn’t see the results he/she expects. Hell, I just jumped off of a campaign two weeks ago because of this crapfest.

That’s what I appreciate about Parscale. It’s not because of some innovative strategy. It’s because, somehow, he’s been able to do what the rest of us have been trying to do. He’s taken over and proved what digital investments can do.

I’m told by common friends that Parscale is one of the hardest working folks in the business. They say he’s incredibly intelligent, personable and he has the knack for being able to sway people. I’m told by folks at the major digital companies that he listens to their advice, where the Clinton campaign acted like they knew everything and were the smartest folks on the planet. They say that Parscale concentrated on moving small audiences he knew could flip swing states, while the Clinton digital teams were more interested in the businesses they could open after their big win. That’s the way this game is supposed to work. Win first. Then cash out.

The Trump campaign, under Parscale’s guidance, proved that with a heavy investment AND an intense focus on digital, campaigns can move the targeted audiences they need to win. With Parscale taking over the reins of our party’s top campaign, let's hope that many more Republican campaigns follow suit and put a digital pro at the helm.
Image Caption: parscale|brad parscale

Title: Why No Is The Most Powerful Word In The English Langauge
Content: You need to focus on your big goals. That’s an easy statement to make. It’s a lot harder when you’re living in the real world where bullshit is continuously piling on your plate. How do you solve that problem? That actually is easy - don’t let it. This is the image that is set as the background on my phone. It’s also tacked to my closet wall. As for everything? I use the most powerful word in the English language - NO! Listen to this short 90-second clip from the No Xcuses podcast...

Title: The Long Goodbye, A Personal Request From Me To You
Content: I’ve seen a lot of death. It’s always been close to me. Parents, best friends, both expected and very unexpected. One minute they’re here. Then they’re not. Yet, that’s not always the case. They call Alzheimer’s and Dementia, “the long goodbye.”  The person you knew so well doesn’t leave in a moment. They disappear gradually over time. You have to sit and watch as they forget their lives, they forget you and eventually they forget themselves. Then you can’t sit and watch anymore because you have to actively take care of them as they forget how to take care of themselves. Eventually, their organs forget how to function and you can finally say goodbye. Elizabeth’s grandmother, Birdi Lou Harlowe, died four years ago after a long battle with Dementia. Birdi was the right name for a woman who was full of life and who would fly around a room with a smile on her face, energy in her lungs and love in her heart. Watching her become someone else took it’s toll on Elizabeth and her family, on our family. When asked to be a celebrity dancer for the Dancing With The ARK’s Stars Elizabeth immediately jumped at the chance because the best way to honor “Mimi” is to help other families going through what we went through. The ARK is a Summerville, SC-based organization that offers support to families affected by Alzheimer’s and Dementia. Elizabeth has been working her tail off for this event. I jokingly say that I’m ready for it to be over because it’s all she talks about! She spends hours every week learning the tango and she’s only a few hundred dollars away from meeting her fundraising goal. We only have four more days until the big event. That’s why I’m writing today. I need you to open up your wallet, pull out your credit card and donate $10 today. I’ve already ponied up and donated $500. Will you join me in donating just $10 BEFORE SATURDAY NIGHT’S EVENT? Just click Here. Are you a craft beer fan? In donating $10 you can also join our raffle to brew with our Frothy Beard brewers for the day. You can help develop the beer idea and even name it. Every raffle ticket is $10. The drawing is tomorrow. Just click Here and enter RAFFLE in the notes. Thank you for your consideration and your friendship. Wesley

Title: The Most Uncomfortable Part of Being An Entrepreneur
Content: Taking on so many different endurance events has taught me that pain will always be there. It doesn’t get any easier. The best it will ever be is uncomfortable. The goal isn’t to stop it from being uncomfortable. That’s called sitting on the couch and watching Netflix. The goal is to get comfortable being uncomfortable. Being an entrepreneur is a lot like that. It’s very uncomfortable. And I find that the most uncomfortable part of the whole thing is trusting other people with your business and letting go. It’s my baby. I conceived it. I birthed it. Now, it’s like dropping my kid off on the first day of school and just expecting someone to take care of him the way I take care of him –with all your heart, soul and mind. The truth is that no one will ever love it the way I love it. But that doesn’t mean other folks are automatically bad stewards of my company. They will work hard for me. But trust, oh trust, is so hard for them to gain. I can hold on and squeeze with all my might but that only leads to one outcome –failure. For me, failure means stagnation. Not moving forward. Not growing. I can’t manage 42 people. I can, however, manage 5 people and they can manage 5 people and they can manage 5 people. It’s all about letting go and delegating. That’s what I talk about in this clip with Zero Xcuses...
Image Title: The Most Uncomfortable Part of Being An Entrepreneur
Image Caption: The Most Uncomfortable Part of Being An Entrepreneur
Image Alt Text: The Most Uncomfortable Part of Being An Entrepreneur

Title: Pushing Positive Vibes To You
Content:
Recently, I sat down with Kenyon for his Zero Xcuses podcast and he asked me what’s up with all the POSITIVE VIBES all over my social media accounts. The answer is simple. It’s to cast away the cesspool of negativity that's surrounding me and killing my mood and the productivity of my team.

For the last several years, I’ve been a shamefully unhappy person. It sickens me to think about it because this kid from the ghetto has so much great shit to be thankful for. My smoking hot wife, my beautiful baby boys and all of my entrepreneurial enterprises. I am #blessed beyond being. Many of you reading this will understand but as an entrepreneur… my work isn’t just Monday through Friday from 9 to 5. My mind is always thinking about high-level strategy for my clients. Are we going to make payroll? What’s the flip is up with our office expansion? My mind is a business machine 24/7 and 365. I’m unhappy because I am surrounded by literally so much effing negativity. The news is negative. Facebook is negative. And even our clients can be negative —which makes my employees negative. This is unfortunate because often times I find myself bringing my negativity home, which is not ok. Here’s the catch: it’s still my job to grow audiences. For our political candidates and advocacy clients, we work to attract more followers, and then to push (get it?) those people to action—to volunteer, to vote, to donate, to contact a legislator, to side with us on a bill. Makes sense? We do this with creative content that gets people interested and involved. And you want to know what isn’t working? Positivity. What works? Anger. The current state of American politics is depression inducing negativity. Sure, we could do an ad or write a blog supporting our troops overseas. People love a good soldier coming home story, but right now the new rhetoric is anti-immigration, building dystopian-style walls, and slapping sex scandals in people’s faces. It’s sad, but it’s true—right now, everything that works online is negative. Because right now, that’s what the people want. And it’s hurting me deeply to serve it up and to be a participant in an atmosphere of vitriol. I did not get into this business to be a fear monger. But there is a HORRIBLE negative vibe in this country right now—and it’s been coming from both sides for some time now. So, I’m putting my foot down. If news and political strategies ain’t changing, I sure as hell am. For my health, for my office’s aura, and most importantly for my family. I encourage everyone else (and myself) to give off ONLY positive vibes. I start each day that way. I hope and trust and believe things will change. Yes. Change for the better. I’m positive about it.
Image Caption: Pushing Positive Vibes To You

Title: Saving Stores With Experiences
Content:
I was a pitiful teenager. While my friends were out smoking weed or learning how to drink, I was stalking the shelves at Toys R Us for the newest Star Trek and Star Wars toys. I was a real Toys R Us kid. Refusing to grow up as the commercials sang. That really confused my wife when we married and I brought boxes of action figures to our new home. I was sad to see Toys R Us announced that all of their stores are closing, yet another victim of the new digital world. Having just wrapped up months of work for K-mart and Sears, we know the story all too well. Just two days ago I stepped into Target for three items. None of them were there. I pulled up my Amazon App, purchased all three and then told my wife that I am done shopping at stores. She just called to say that two of the three items already arrived today. That’s why Toys R Us is joining all the stores that used to line shopping malls. But it didn’t have to be that way. One word could have saved them –EXPERIENCES. The experience matters and for brick and mortar retailers, the experience is everything. I own a craft brewery in Charleston, SC. The craft beer nerds come for the beer. The much broader population comes for the experience, to meet the people making the beer, for our awesome kids’ center and for our total geeky vibe. Our taproom and deck go from crowded to flooded when we throw a big party (ex: wrestling, oyster roasts, trivia) because people are looking for things to do and not just for food to eat and for stuff to buy. I am the proud father of two boys. We are always looking for stuff to do. It is almost too easy to come up with ideas for Toys R US. Here are ten ideas my team came up within just two minutes!
  1. Lego Tournament: leave the kits at home folks, it's time for the kids to go old school and freestyle with piles and piles of lego pieces.
  2. Paw Patrol: let your local animal shelter join in on the family fun with a day of play with furry (and adoptable) friends.
  3. Candy Land: turn your store into a sweet and sour obstacle course. Not all candy characters are as sweet as they seem...
  4. Pirate Party: scour the seven seas, meet mermaids, and search for hidden treasure and prizes throughout the store.
  5. Video Game Tournament: We're playing for keeps! Plug in and test out the latest in gaming for the ultimate prize.
  6. Laser Tag: Dodge, duck, and dive behind barriers and battle it out with your family and friends.
  7. Easy Bake Oven Cook-Off: Can your kiddos handle the heat? BYOK (Bring Your Own Kitchen) to an Easy Bake Oven Cook-Off, where you can have your cake and eat it too.
  8. Safari With Stuffed Animals: Come to the safest (and softest) safari in town! Where cobras are cuddly and giraffes are still relatively giant.
  9. Jedi Training With Lightsaber Duels: May the force be with you during this once in a life time Jedi training.
  10. Super Hero Day: Dress up as your favorite superhero and unleash your powers to help you grab as many goodies as possible.
Not only would these ideas fill stores and provide a quick income boost, they would also build a loyal customer base. Sure, it is hard, but going out of business is a lot harder. Every year, hundreds of Charleston-area families turnout for Elfstravaganza, an event hosted by Wonderworks and owned by my friend Christine Osborne. Their website states, "Come play with the hottest toys of the year, presented by 20 of the nation's top toy vendors! See what's trending this holiday season and let the little ones play and engage –the perfect way to preview just how much play value your family will get with each toy on their list!" This is something Toys R Us has the scale and resources to do nearly every single weekend. [caption id="attachment_6407" align="aligncenter" width="600"] (Pics by CarolinaGarrison.net which now that I know is a thing, I must join.)[/caption] Yesterday, I walked into a Home Depot where a sign hung announcing a free telescope building class for kids. BINGO! Get kids building early and teach them how to use tools. Give them something productive to do instead of sitting on the couch in front of an iPad. Kids will love it. Parents will love it. Home Depot will stay in business. All brick and mortar stores should follow their lead. It’s all about the experience.

Title: We’re Pushing Something New
Content:
I’m super stoked that we will be releasing our new website and new branding package for Push Digital early tomorrow afternoon. I just can’t tell you how proud I am of our creative and production teams. They’ve really encapsulated everything that Push Digital is - creative work, data-driven placement and really badass people that work together in a fun culture. I’m not going to go into it too much today, but I did want to give you a little sneak peek of what to expect with this new sizzle reel produced by the amazing Blake Williams.

More tomorrow.... it’s going to be AWESOME! POSITIVE VIBES!
Image Caption: We're pushing something new

Title: Push Digital Just Leveled Up And I Love It
Content:
For the past couple of weeks, my team has been teasing the world with elements of our rebranding process and I’m so stoked to announce that our new website and branding package are finally LIVE. It’s done. It’s badass. It’s beautiful. It’s clean. Go take a look. Right now! GO. I mean it. Click here.

Ah, there are just no words for how much I love Push Digital’s new experience. And that’s exactly what this exercise was – an experience. From beginning to end, for everyone involved, this whole process was an experience. Not to take away from the magnitude of what our creative and production teams accomplished in the last couple of months, but this kind of touches on something I’ve talked about a lot when it comes to being an entrepreneur.

For a long time, practically since the beginning, I was the only one who produced the content. Here and there I had help, but it’s something I have taken ownership of and something I just plain like to do. Doesn’t hurt that I’m pretty damn good at it either. However, I thoroughly believe that content is the driving force behind the Push Digital machine. Even our business development plan practically thrives and survives on it. Recently, I’ve taken a bit of a step back from the Push Digital content calendar to focus on my personal stuff. Was it hard as hell (because this company is my baby)? Bet your ass it was. But from the mouth of an entrepreneur, who always has business on the brain, this is the single biggest step towards real growth.

You don't just add an account manager here or a developer there. Your goal should be to surround yourself with people who care about what you’re trying to do as much as you do. Do I always feel like that is the case? If I’m being totally honest, no. But to me, this rebranding process reinforces in my mind that Push Digital is the company that I’ve always wanted it to be. Also, I'm truly surrounded by people who actually freaking care. It's days like today that just make all the stress of being an entrepreneur 100% worth it.

Back to the internal accolades, I just want to throw some serious credit to every single pair of hands that helped on this project. It started out with a company-wide survey that trickled into several brainstorming sessions. And then once the foundation was laid, my crew got to work. The creative team made design magic, developers coded their butts off and account managers created content calendars. So here we are today… looking at a bomb new website that encompasses everything I’ve ever envisioned for Push Digital.

How can you have anything but POSITIVE VIBES?

-Wesley

Title: The Truth About Cambridge Analytica And Your Privacy
Content:
Let me tell you a story… In 2013, I built a really badass Facebook app for Ken Cuccinelli’s bid for Virginia Governor. At the time, it was a monument to my love of social media and just plain savvy as a political strategist. Never afraid to push the boundaries of technology, it proved to be an early and effective tool in weaponizing social media for the sake of politics. Just a few months prior, the Obama campaign built a targeted sharing app that allowed a person to sign in using their Facebook account and then pull in all of their friends who they could then send a specific message based on the location of that friend. Time wrote, “More than 600,000 supporters followed through with more than 5 million contacts, asking their friends to register to vote, give money, vote or look at a video designed to change their mind.” That’s a big deal because when a person gave the app permission to access their Facebook data, they were also giving the app permission to access their friends’ data without their friends giving permission themselves. It was all part of Facebook’s Open Graph. I took it all another step. This is from a memo I wrote in 2013: “In 2012, Facebook’s targeted sharing application was a game-changer for the Obama campaign. No marketing technique proved to be more effective than peer-to-peer messaging. Obama staffers even went so far as to say that the application was their most innovative technological development. We can take their model to the next level by merging it with the RNC voter file, Cuccinelli field IDs, and microtargeting data. The idea is simple: have supporters share messages with their friends that are specifically tailored to each individual friend, instead of broad, generic messaging. Each issue message should include a call-to-action coordinated with field staff activities.” Let’s say that Erin is friends with George. Erin logged on to the app and it pulled in all the information about George that Facebook would give me. We matched George to the voter file and then to our microtargeting data, which told us which issues George cared about the most. In this case, George is a hardcore pro-lifer. Instead of Erin sending a generic message to George about Cuccinelli and jobs, Erin sent George a message about Ken Cuccinelli being a national leader in the pro-life movement. That’s what my app did. We built the app and it worked beautifully. I can’t say that it was a game-changer, but on election night the race was much closer than anyone thought it would be. Cuccinelli lost, but I like to think our little app played a small part in picking up some votes we didn’t think we had. Technologically though, it was a big success. I tell you that story because I’m getting questions about Cambridge Analytica and Facebook everywhere I turn. My answer has been, “it’s nothing we haven’t done.” The only difference is that we stopped accessing that data when Facebook plugged the data spigot. My app wouldn’t work today because Facebook changed the rules. We have a good relationship with Facebook and they know we’re a political agency and, as such, we’ll take every little bit of data they put in front of us. Here’s a dirty little secret that you should know - all political operatives take data. Whether it’s old school excel spreadsheets or social data via APIs - if politicos can get their hands on data, they will take the data, keep the data, and probably even use the data on another campaign. Anyone who tells you different is absolutely lying and trying to ride some non-existent high horse. Politicos take data. Plain and simple. End of story. Pro-tip: if you’re running for office, make all politicos sign list confidentiality agreements. So if Facebook turned off the spigot and I couldn’t build my app today, how did Cambridge Analytica pull it off? It sounds like Facebook has different rules for political campaigns and academia. The man who accessed all the data, Aleksandr Kogan, was a researcher at Cambridge University. He told Facebook that he was accessing the data for academic purposes. He then built an app on top of the data for Cambridge Analytica. So, who’s to blame here? Shit, man. I don’t know. Here’s what I do know:
  1. Facebook used to allow us to access the same data using their Open Graph API but then changed the rules and cut off the spigot.
  2. Facebook allows researchers to still access that data.
  3. A researcher lied and said he was using the data for academic reasons, took the data, and then used it for political purposes.
One more thing I know: Facebook is giving us a service for free and we, in turn, are telling it and every other social media platform everything about ourselves. We’re bitching about privacy while standing in front of a window butt ass naked. Do we really think that people aren’t going to snap pictures and video when they see us standing there? That’s the world we live in now. We’re doing it to ourselves and then blaming corporate America. The dude who lied is to blame. Cambridge Analytica is to blame. Yes, Facebook is to blame because they should have more oversight in this kind of situation, but they did change their rules and stop the flow of data for political reasons. Can they really stop people from lying? You and I are also to blame. We’ve given up our privacy. When we give it up, people will take it.
Image Title: Wesley Donehue Pondering The Truth About Cambridge Analytica And Privacy
Image Caption: Wesley Donehue Pondering The Truth About Cambridge Analytica And Privacy
Image Alt Text: Wesley Donehue Pondering The Truth About Cambridge Analytica And Privacy

Title: Advice To Mom and Pop Shops
Content:
Happy #nationalmomandpopshopday!

A lot has changed for the Mom and Pop shops of America. No longer is the next Mom and Pop shop down the street your big competition. You’re not just competing against the Targets and Walmarts down the street these days either. Today, you’re all competing against the one-click wonder that is Amazon.

No driving to the store and sitting in traffic. No searching through aisles of junk for what I really need. No longer finding what I need but it is the wrong size or color. No longer finding an empty spot where what I need is supposed to be. I can just open the app, find exactly what I need in 30 seconds, click one button and it arrive at my door in two days. Man, that experience just can’t be beat.

Yet, it can be beaten. I wrote about Toys R Us two weeks ago. You should click here and read that article.

I’m following up on that article because my brewery, Frothy Beard Brewing Company, just had two of it’s largest days in months. The first was on St Patrick’s Day when we threw a huge party. Drink specials, food specials and lots of St Patty’s Day themed activities. The following Saturday was our 5th Anniversary. All kinds of craziness ensued including an archery battle in the parking lot. No, we weren’t putting each other in the hospital. The arrows were foam tipped.

You can get beer anywhere. Hell, you can get great beer anywhere these days. But we don’t just give people great beer (and the best pizza in Charleston, SC). We give them something to do. We give them a place to hang out. We give them an experience.

Starbucks doesn’t just sell coffee. They are a place to work, to meet or to just chill for a little bit. Build-A-Bear doesn’t just sell teddy bears. They let you build your own custom teddy bear.

Hardware shops like Home Depot are now hosting DIY courses.

Do you sell t-shirts? Have t-shirt design contests and sell the winner in your store each week.

Do you sell books? We’d take our kids to book readings or costume contests where kids dress up as characters from the book of the week.

Do you sell tires? Teach classes that teach people how to change tires. Hell, I’ll go to that one.

Mom and Pop shops can’t just sell stuff. They have to find that Starbucks and Build-A-Bear equivalent. Every Mom and Pop shop has to do exactly what we’re doing at Frothy Beard Brewing. Give consumers an experience they can’t get anywhere else. That’s how you will survive, Mom and Pop.
Image Title: Advice To Mom and Pop Shops
Image Caption: Advice To Mom and Pop Shops
Image Alt Text: Advice To Mom and Pop Shops

Title: The Merging of New And Old School Communications
Content:
We used to hear a lot about how digital was going to take over TV. I was one of the few digital guys who never made that claim. I always thought that TV content was here to stay, but that the method in which people consumed that content would change. In other words, digital and TV would blend together. That’s exactly what we’re seeing happen now.

I watch Star Trek Discovery with my CBS streaming app, The Walking Dead through iTunes, Game of Thrones on HBO’s app, Black Mirror via Netflix and Grey’s Anatomy (yes, I watch it and I’m not even embarrassed) on Hulu… I could go on and on.

As for devices, I typically watch them on my TV using AppleTV and Roku or on my iPad.

Digital isn’t eliminating TV. It’s changing TV.

The same can be said for traditional strategic communications and grassroots activity. Digital has changed the way we communicate for our clients and drum up grassroots support. That’s how we won uphill battles like creating a thriving craft beer industry and passed a roads funding bill in South Carolina. That’s how we’re getting difficult legislation passed in states across the country. However, the more digital work we do, the more we find that the old school, tried and true communications and grassroots strategies aren’t being replaced –they’re evolving to work in conjunction with new digital strategies. Just like CBS is working with online streaming platforms to broadcast the new Star Trek series.

Yes, going around journalists and straight to the voters with digital advertising is very effective, but journalists still matter –a lot. Every day we get calls asking if we can do our digital tactics AND talk directly to journalists because the operation is best when it’s working seamlessly and simultaneously. The same is true for grassroots work. Yes, drumming up emails and calls into legislative offices with digital tactics is the cheapest and most effective way to bombard a legislator, but direct contact from a Grasstops leader the Legislator personally knows is still extremely important. In fact, it can be argued that it’s even more important now because it cuts through the clutter of all the noise we’re creating with digital efforts.

That’s why we’ve expanded our Columbia, SC office and opened our new division, Push Strategic Communications. It’s just not smart in 2018 to run one without the other. Digital and offline efforts must be married. Direct outreach to voters, pitching journalists and offline contacts from trustworthy supporters must all work hand in hand. That’s what we’re doing with our new agency. We’re evolving because the public relations landscape is constantly evolving.

Push Strategic Communications is being led by Greg Foster. A longtime friend, Greg used to be a real thorn in my side. I ran communications for the South Carolina Senate Republican Caucus and he did the same for the House Republicans. Despite being the same party, the two chambers never got along. He was a worthy adversary and I quickly learned that he was one of the best communications guys I knew –and I was working with some of the most experienced folks across the nation.

Greg spent a decade at the SC State House honing his communications skills. He understands the art of messaging and the importance of leveraging relationships to produce outcomes –an offline ability that will greatly strengthen any online strategy.

Push Digital is a digital-first agency, but that doesn’t mean we can be a digital-only agency. Not in 2018. Those worlds aren’t dividing. They’re coming together to be one seamless effort.
