Title: Facebook Isn’t Selling Your Data
Content:
What you’ve heard isn’t true. Facebook isn’t selling your data.

Let us repeat - Facebook is not selling your data.

With Mark Zuckerberg testifying in front of Congress last week, the internet is in a panic about how their data being used and whether it’s a huge breach of privacy. As an agency who uses Facebook to advertise on almost every media plan we build, we disagree that Facebook is the ‘big bad wolf’ everyone is making them out to be. And while we agree that they screwed up with Cambridge Analytica (Click here to view article), here is why you shouldn’t be freaked out:

Facebook doesn’t give advertisers your actual identification. They only let us advertise to a pool of users after we give them specific parameters. We have no idea who the specific people in that pool are.

For instance: we are able to target males in their 30's, married with two kids, driving a Jeep, living in Summerville, S.C. who have an interest in Star Trek and running marathons. We are NOT able to target Wesley Donehue. Facebook’s platform anonymizes its local data. As an advertiser, we have no idea of the identification of the actual people we are targeting. We repeat, advertisers on Facebook never get identification information unless you share it.

Let’s say we’re advertising for Altra shoes... Of course, we want to target Males who have an interest in Marathons... it’s the product our client sells. But unless Wesley Donehue actually purchases a pair of shoes on the Altra website, we don’t know that Wesley Donehue is the individual engaging with our ads.

The granularity of data Facebook has on its users is no different than the data that Google, Amazon or Yahoo all have on their users. Facebook just has more of it because that’s where you’re spending all your time and where you’re sharing everything about yourself.

This is also no different than the way advertisers have been purchasing TV, radio and newspaper ads for decades. The station or publisher gives advertisers the demographics of their viewers/readers and then the advertiser builds creative around that specific audience. Again, the only difference is the amount of data those stations and publishers have on their users. Believe us, if they had what Facebook has, they would use it in a heartbeat.

The definition of “selling” is “giving or handing over something in exchange for money.”  Facebook provides access to a pool of users, but it does not hand over that information to us. We cannot remove the information from Facebook and keep it for ourselves. We can only put our creative material into the Facebook platform and have them show that creative to their users for us. We have no ownership of anything. We don’t buy anything. Facebook doesn’t sell anything.

Moral of the story: Facebook isn’t as scary you think it is... And if you’re still worried, you should probably quit using the internet all together!

Written in collaboration with Push Digital's Director of Marketing and Advertising,  Brooke Willaby

Title: Trump’s Tariffs Will Hurt Craft Beer
Content:
Love him or hate him, one thing is for certain - President Donald Trump is hurting the craft beer industry. President Trump’s trade war with China should come as no surprise. He repeatedly promised on the campaign trail that he would fight the Asian country’s unfair trade practices. On March 1, 2018, he stood by that promise, imposing hard tariffs on steel and aluminum. “People have no idea how badly our country has been treated by other countries,” President Trump claimed. “They’ve destroyed the steel industry, they’ve destroyed the aluminum industry, and other industries, frankly.” Of course, he followed that statement up with a tweet: “When a country [USA] is losing many billions of dollars on trade with virtually every country it does business with, trade wars are good, and easy to win. Example, when we are down $100 billion with a certain country and they get cute, don’t trade anymore-we win big. It’s easy!” Sure, the tariffs may help our nation’s steel and aluminum industries, but in doing so, it crushes the exploding beer industry that relies on steel tanks and aluminum cans. According to Jim McGreevy, President of the Beer Institute, "the aluminum tariff alone could cost the industry $347.7 million and result in the loss of more than 20,000 jobs nationwide." Frothy Beard Brewing partner, Joey Siconolfi, addressed the issue on Fox News:
In South Carolina’s coastal city of Charleston, a group of friends started Frothy Beard Brewing Company in 2013, which has grown 400 percent since it opened. The owners say the tariffs on steel or aluminum could impact their future business growth.
“We’ve been buying new steel tanks, (and) we are planning to add two or three more,” Frothy Beard Brewing Co. head brewer Joey Siconolfi told Fox News. “So, it’s a 25 percent increase on steel they’re talking about and we are also getting into canning…that can have a huge impact….”
 Frothy Beard Brewing cans more than 18,000 beers in one day. They have plans to expand their canning production, but they say it could cost them hundreds of dollars per day. Siconolfi said the aluminum cans typically cost 12 cents each. If the 10 percent tariff on aluminum is applied, the cost for 18,000 cans would go up from about $2,100 to more than $2,300.
OUCH! ? Frothy Beard’s other partner, Steve McCauley, also addressed the issue, talking to Charleston’s Post and Courier:
When Frothy Beard Brewing Co. started canning its signature jalapeno cilantro pale ale in October, the bright green aluminum cans carried hope for the Charleston brewery trying to expand into other markets.
But now, something new is clouding Frothy Beard's 10-barrel system off Ashley River Road: Fear.
Since last month when President Donald Trump announced plans to impose a 25 percent tariff on imported steel and 10 percent on imported aluminum, South Carolina brewers have been scrambling to determine how the trade war will trickle into taprooms.
Frothy Beard co-owner Steve McCauley, who oversees packaging and distribution, said rumors in the industry are swirling. He's heard aluminum prices could increase anywhere from 1 penny to 5 cents per can from the tariffs that took effect March 23.
"There's going to be reckoning, but none of us knows what it's going to be yet," McCauley said. "The sad thing is that whatever it is, it's probably all going to get passed to the consumer."
??? At Frothy Beard Brewing Co., we’re going to keep growing. We’re going to buy more steel tanks and distribute more beer in aluminum cans. We’re not going to stop. That is... until you get sick of the rising cost of craft beer. When that happens, you can thank President Donald Trump.     Photo credit: Gage Skidmore

Title: An Agency Of Knife Fighters
Content:
We’re creative. We’re smart. We’re fun to work with.
But that describes a lot of agencies. What really sets us a apart is our background. Buzzfeed calls our CEO “a knife fighter.” It’s true. We work harder than everyone else. We’re scrappier than everyone else. To put it bluntly- we get shit done.

Title: I Drink Unicorn Piss To Dominate Life
Content: I’ve come to a sad conclusion about our culture — No one cares about the human traits we used to find best in a man. You know, those things Jesus Christ himself told us to portray; humility, honesty and kindness. Today, we idolize those who make bold claims about themselves and their abilities, even when their claims are rambling rants in the form of tweets, barely distinguishable from a two-year-old just learning the English language. We buy their records. We obsess over their reality shows. We even elect them to public office.  We love it. We digest every second, every ounce of it. The media shoves it down our throats for ratings and clicks. Talking heads flood the airwaves, giving their opinions on the latest gossip. What has become crystal clear is that the idea of problems and solutions has been completely wiped off the American mindset. Research, logic, big ideas, concern... all dead. No one. Gives. A Shit. Now it’s, let’s all follow the absolutely loudest and most colorful person. The person we turn to for answers is the self-indulging, selfish person who feeds off your attention. The person who will say and do absolutely anything to make you love them. Or hate them. Hell, it really doesn’t matter, as long as it’s about them. I’m a businessman. When people want cheeseburgers, I make cheeseburgers. That’s why I’ve decided to go all in.  I’m 100% dedicated to the insanity. That’s the path to power, to money, to love. So, I’m changing my tone right now. I mean, why not?  I’m the smartest person I know. It’s time for everyone else to know that too. Clearly everything I touch turns to gold. I am the path to power and prosperity for my clients. I don’t lose when a client does exactly what I say. I am the way. I’m the best political operative in America. I touch the hearts of every voter, every demo, every district. My creative is the political equivalent to Van Gogh, but even more bloody because I don’t just cut off ears. I slay every opponent who comes my way like David slayed Goliath, but I didn’t even have to sling a rock. I do it through pure will and power of mind. Ask all the people around me. Ask my team. There is no team better on the North American continent. And I’m not just talking about in politics or marketing, I mean in any industry. I build monuments to causes that will never be torn down. I’ve been in my cave and now I return with the speed of a cheetah and the motivation of a bull, running down the crowded streets of my blood vessels. A complete witch hunt! The witches come but they can’t find me. I hide in the dark corner of their minds, taunting their spiritual needs. Their spells deflected by the love of all my fans. I pull on the strings and my fans twirl. All for me. In whichever direction I demand. I win. Everything. It comes from the unicorn piss I drink with my vitamins made of hippopotamus sweat. It’s what you eat. It’s what you want. I will solve all your problems. Believe it. Because I said it. Because I’m the best at everything. #tigerblood #dragonenergy ? W. P.S. - “Be humble.” - Kendrick Lamar. Maybe Jesus said it first.

Title: Pushing Positive Vibes On Everyone We Meet
Content: We’re knife fighters. It comes from our political background. We work hard. We work fast. We get shit done. Here’s a video all about our culture. I hope you’ll watch it. But here’s the thing - that political background gives us the ability to operate at a different level than most agencies, but it can also hurt us. Politics is extremely negative. There’s a lot of drama. Everyone is trying to cut everyone else’s throats. It’s Game of Thrones on crack. Look, the corporate world is like that too, but politics is politics. Negativity can harm morale. It can be downright depressing. And that’s the big problem - low morale and depression dramatically decreases creativity (unless your Van Gogh or Ernest Hemingway, but we don’t want our staff offing themselves). That’s why you’re hearing so much about POSITIVE VIBES. In our line of work, we can’t just talk about it. We have to live it. Everything we do at Push Digital is about positivity. We force fun into our meetings, our calls, on our staff and even on our clients. Hell, our agency is literally inside of a brewery for this exact reason. We believe that when we’re having fun and smiling, our brains are stimulated and they’re working harder and more creatively. We see it in our strategies. We see it in our designs. We see it in our videos. We see it in our results. POSITIVE VIBES = POSITIVE RESULTS Check out this new video and hear from our staff on why we push POSITIVE VIBES. -- https://youtu.be/1vfxOVcgkRc

Title: Advice for Office Staff
Content:
“What are my fitness goals? I want to feel better about myself, to start taking better care of my body, and if I lost a little weight in that process I wouldn’t be mad. (But I mean who would?) So to make those things happen, I need y’all’s help! How do you stay motivated? How do you stay on a consistent schedule? How much do your eating habits affect the way you work out? I’m open to any and all suggestions! Help ya girl get fit and then stay tuned to figure out how exactly I plan on doing it.”

That’s how one of our Account Executives recently closed a post on her personal blog here. As CEO and an avid fitness junkie, I get questions about staying motivated (whether it’s fitness or work) all the time.

So today I’m giving advice to all those who find themselves trying to change their situation. This is for all those who want to start but don’t know how to actually get started. For all those sitting in front of a computer all day, snacking on bullshit with no actual plan.

*Disclaimer: I’m not an athlete, coach, nutritionist or a doctor. I’m just a guy who’s proven that the following advice works, and is sharing the knowledge.

1. Start Small

Through a lot of trial and error I’ve learned that when trying to get better — in fitness or at work — it’s always best to start with the basics. Start small and build up. For example, we all know fad diets don’t work. You do it for awhile, lose some pounds, get sick of the regime and then those pounds suddenly reappear. It’s the same with work. You can’t build Rome in a day. Don’t try to go all in at once. Just like you would cut the bad things out of your diet one by one, try to cut out one bad work habit per week.

Week 1: Stop saying “I’ll get to it.” Make realistic to-do lists for immediate, ongoing and future tasks.

Week 2: Stop letting your inbox pile up. Take the time to tackle it and answer every email you can.

Week 3: Stop putting things off. Just because you may not want to do something doesn’t mean it will go away. Just get it done. Eliminate procrastination.

Week 4: Stop waiting for direction. Speak up. Take more initiative.

2. Reset

This may be more commonly known as having a “cheat day.” It’s okay to splurge once in a while when you’re on a diet. Just like it’s okay to give yourself time to reset at work. As CEO, I give my employees the option to work remotely on Wednesdays. I think the time that they have at home helps their energy stay up when they’re in the office, it helps keep their creativity fresh by providing a change in scenery, and it gives them a chance to reset.

3. Set Goals

I’m a firm believer in goals. If you don’t know where you want to end up, how are you ever going to get there? Pick the destination, set the course, and go! A goal gives you something to celebrate. It gives you a light at the end of the table. Most importantly, it gives you a reason to get out of bed in the morning. So whether it’s the 5k you signed up for or the big presentation you want to kick ass on, that big day is coming no matter what. You can stay in bed but you’re going to fail. Get out of bed and work every day until you reach your goal.

4. Find A Battle Buddy

Why are running clubs so popular? Why do you think successful people always find themselves in the company of other successful people? It’s because who you surround yourself with often reflects who you are. In fitness and in work, make sure you surround yourself with people that provide positive vibes, help you stay sharp and push you to be your best. The team you join (or build) is a great indicator of just how well you will perform. Why do you think I’ve hired so many bad asses at Push Digital?!

5. Flexibility Matters

Stay flexible. While it may seem obvious that flexibility is important in fitness, it’s equally as important within a business. As a digital marketing firm, everyone at Push Digital has to be able to change directions at the drop of a hat. Whether that means in the creative process, dealing with constant changes to digital advertising platforms or sometimes working after hours to meet the needs of your client — flexibility and adaptability are key.

My advice may not turn you into a beast in the gym or in the office, but it will get you started. It will help you get healthier, advance at work and maybe even make more money.

It’s important to point out one very important fact: the brain and the body are connected, just in case you didn’t realize that yet. The mind is sluggish when the body is sluggish. The mind is unhealthy when the body is unhealthy. Remember to start small, take time to reset, set goals, find your battle team and stay flexible. You’ll be more clear minded, you’ll be more productive, you’ll be more creative. In short, you’ll be a better worker.

Title: Are you tough enough to be my assistant?
Content:
Here you’ll find a job description of a position for which we are currently hiring - my assistant. I want to give you the more honest description.I’m not easy to work for. I’m not an asshole or the kind of boss that yells at people. I just move super quick and I’m constantly bouncing from one thing to another. It’s hard to keep up with me. You’ll receive messages at 4 AM because that’s when I wake up and my mind is thinking of work the most. You’ll get messages on the weekends and when I’m jotting ideas down on a napkin at happy hour. It would be your job to keep all that organized, to keep my life in order. I’m the CEO of five digital agencies under one brand. I’m a partner in a brewery and a pizzeria. I’m currently building a new holding company with new business ventures. I’m married with two boys. I’m training for an Ironman. My schedule is literally booked from the moment I wake up until the moment I go to sleep. I’m always traveling. My schedule is EVERYTHING and you would be its keeper. On top of keeping my life in order, you will also be responsible for the marketing of Push Digital, Frothy Beard Brewing, Zombie Bob’s Pizza and my personal brand. That’s because I refuse to give those up to anyone else and I oversee them myself. So basically, you would be one-part personal assistant and one-part account executive. You’ll get more entrepreneurial experience than anyone else in the company because you’ll be my right hand. You’ll see the big picture ideas as well as all the nitty gritty details. This is probably the toughest job in the entire company. It’s stressful. It’s hard work. It’s also super fun and rewarding. You’ll learn more about business in six months than you would in four years of college. Also, as tough as I am to work for, I’m also super fun and I take care of my team. Here’s my former assistant’s take on the job before she got married and abandoned me ?
https://youtu.be/XrhqLCOPy-I

Title: Facebook's Political Ad Policies Adapt
Content:
You’ve heard a lot about new transparency measures being enacted by Facebook and Google following the 2016 election debacle. Yesterday our advertising team, led by Brooke Willaby, was in Washington, DC to meet with Facebook and Google representatives to discuss how the changes will impact our work and our clients. We’ve been getting a lot of questions from our clients and friends about these changes. Instead of typing up a whole blog post to answer these questions I’ve decided to publish an internal Push Digital memo Brooke distributed last week to our team.

I hope this helps answer some of your questions. Brooke asked that I let you know that these new changes are happening rapidly and last week alone we received four separate emails from Facebook about their changes. All to say, don’t take this memo as gospel. Things are still changing. Brooke wil report back after her meetings in DC this week with any additional changes.

Positive Vibes,

Wesley — — BACKGROUND As a result of the Russian interference in the 2016 election and the Cambridge Analytica data breach, Facebook has been actively updating its political advertising policies to create transparency and prevent future abuse in elections. See the original announcement here.

3 MAJOR CHANGES: 1. Ads must be placed by an authorized user 2. All “political” ads must carry a paid for disclaimer 3. All “political” ads will be added into a public political archive

WHAT IS BEING DEFINED AS A POLITICAL AD? Electoral ads aren’t the only ads being categorized as political. As of May 8th, “issue ads” concerning political topics being debated around the country are also considered political ads. Facebook developed an initial list of key issues, but it is important to note that this list will continue to evolve over time. See the full current list here.

One of Push Digital’s Facebook representatives went even further to clarify by saying, “If the ad is advocating for or against a position on one of the issues outlined in the list we released yesterday, or broadly encouraging Congress or another legislative body to take some form of action, I’d anticipate that those ads will also need to follow the political guidelines.”

AUTHORIZED USERS Advertisers must be authorized as a political advertiser. This involves verifying each advertisers identity and location (through the US Mail). Additionally, all ad accounts must be identified as political and disclose who is paying for the ads.

DISCLAIMER Every ad will show a “paid for by” disclaimer. The paid for disclaimer can be up to 360 characters and must be accurate and complete. The disclaimer will go through a 24 hour approval process once submitted. Disclaimers can be edited at any time, but will go through Facebook’s approval process again. Facebook has not yet released what exactly this will look like on the ad, but we will keep you updated as we get more information.

Note: Facebook’s disclaimer field is not a substitute for the obligation to include in your ad all necessary disclaimers and other notices required by law.

ARCHIVE Facebook is releasing a public, searchable political ads “archive” that will contain all ads with the “Political Ad” label. It will update in near-real time basis (within an hour) and ads will remain in the archive for 7 years. The archive will show the image and text, as well as additional information like the ad spend, impressions shown, unique reach and demographic audience information for each ad. Ad spend, Impressions, and Reach will be shown in ranges instead of exact amounts. Below are the initial ranges for the launch on May 22nd. These ranges will change over time. The current ranges are:

  • Ad Spend: <100, 100–499, 500–999, 1000–4999, 5000–9999, 10000–19999, 20000–49999, 50000–99999, 100000–199999, 200000–499999, 5000000–999999, Greater than 1M
  • Impressions Ranges: <1000, 1000–4999, 5000–9999, 10000–19999, 20000–49999–50000–99999, 100000–199999, 200000–499999, 5000000–999999, Greater than 1M
  • Total Unique Reach: <100, 100–499, 500–999, 1000–4999, 5000–9999, 10000–19999, 20000–49999, 50000–99999, 100000–199999, 200000–499999, 5000000–999999, Greater than 1M

See a video of what the archive may look like here.

In addition to the archive, Facebook has created a feature called “view ads” that lets the public see every ad a Page is running — even if they are not on your News Feed. This applies to all advertiser Pages on Facebook — not just Pages running political ads. Learn more about “View Ads” here.

TIMELINE Facebook’s new policy will go into effect Tuesday, May 22nd. Push Digital is prepared for this roll out and have taken the steps to become authorized advertisers as well authorize our client’s pages and ad accounts. Facebook continues to stress that these updates are in the initial phases and they will continue to evolve. As always, we will keep you posted on updates that are made. We want to thank you for your patience and understanding around Facebook advertising during this time.

Title: Fitness Advice For Office Staff — Part 2
Content:
(Note: Last week I wrote this post. The original concept of the post was to give pure fitness advice to my staff who kept asking, but that piece got turned into something much different for our company blog. I still thought this post, as originally, drafted was important for my team so I’m also sharing it here with you on my personal blog. I hope it can help get some of you started. — Wesley)

“What are my fitness goals? I want to feel better about myself, to start taking better care of my body, and if I lost a little weight in that process I wouldn’t be mad. (But I mean who would?) So to make those things happen, I need y’all’s help! How do you stay motivated? How do you stay on a consistent schedule? How much do your eating habits affect the way you work out?
I’m open to any and all suggestions! Help ya girl get fit and then stay tuned to figure out how exactly I plan on doing it.”

That’s how one of our Account Executives recently closed a post on her personal blog. I’m always being asked what I do to stay motivated — just recently three other staffers asked me those same questions. So today I’m going to give advice to all those workers, including my team, who find themselves sitting in front of a computer all day, snacking on bullshit, with no actual plan to get fit. This is for everyone who wants to start, but don’t know how to actually get started.

*Disclaimer: I’m not an athlete, coach, nutritionist or a doctor. I’m just a guy who’s proven that the following advice works, and is sharing the knowledge.

Through a lot of trial and error I’ve learned that there are a few key things to keep in mind when getting started with fitness:

1. Cut The Crap

We all know that fad diets don’t work. You’ll do it for awhile, lose some pounds, get sick of the regime and then those pounds will suddenly reappear. Skip the diets and just eat healthy. Starting the process is as easy as cutting out one unhealthy thing a week. Don’t try to go all in at once. Start small. This is how it went for me:

Week 1: Cut fast food

Week 2: Cut soda

Week 3: Cut sugar out of my coffee

Week 4: Cut dairy out of my coffee

Week 5: Cut all processed foods

Week 6: Cut all dairy

Personally, I don’t have a big sweet tooth so candy and other sweets weren’t on my “cut out now” list. Once I had eliminated what I wanted to out of my diet, I started concentrating on what I SHOULD eat: organic foods, lots of fruits and veggies and clean meats.

2. Cheat Days

It’s okay to splurge. Food is one of life’s greatest pleasures. I personally use Saturdays as my day to take in as much crap food as I can. Six days on and one day off is the most effective way for me to stay healthy while keeping my sanity. It may be different for you, so be sure to strike up a good balance between on and off days to find what’s right for you. Ease into it and give your body time to adjust. You’ll find your balance eventually.

3. No Excuses

“I can’t run” is the biggest bullshit excuse I’ve ever heard. Everyone can run. Not everyone can go out and run five miles on their first try, but everyone can run. Again, this is all about starting small. Don’t get discouraged because you can’t run a quarter of a mile. Forget the distances for now. Just run as long as you can, and then walk. Then do it again and again until you find a ratio that works for you. A few options include: run 2 minutes, walk 1 minute; run 3 minutes, walk 1 minute; run 4 minutes, walk 1 minute.

Once you get your rhythm down, put your focus back on distances. Aim for one mile on the first day, a mile and a quarter on the second, a mile and a half on the third, and so on and so forth. It’s all about start small and growing. Before you know it, you’ll be at ten miles with no clue how you got there. There’s no excuse for not trying. You can run — so lace up and get going.

4. Set A Goal

I’m a firm believer in goals. If you don’t know where you want to end up, how are you ever going to get there? Pick the destination, set the course and go! An event gives you something to celebrate. It gives you a light at the end of the tunnel. But most importantly, it gives you a reason to get out of bed in the morning. The big day is coming no matter what. So work hard every single day until that big day — whether it’s a 5k, a 10k, a half marathon or a triathlon — arrives.

5. Find A Battle Buddy

This is ultimately what changed my life. I have my workout group, F3. I can’t tell you how important they are to me. My guys text me at night asking me if I’m going to workout the next day and then they beat my ass when I don’t show up. Even if I don’t want to go, I know that my guys are waiting on me. I can’t let my F3 brothers down. And in return, they don’t let me down. They keep us accountable. So find yourself an accountability partner (aka a battle buddy), and start kicking some serious ass!

6. Stay Flexible

Mobility matters. It just does. I may be fast, but I’m as stiff as the Tin Man. Most of my current fitness problems come from hunching over a computer for decades. Y’all, trust me on this. Sitting all day does a lot of damage. Please get up. Walk around during your conference calls. Use a standup desk. Sign up for a couple of yoga classes a week. Staying active in the small ways is the easiest way to start getting in shape.

My advice may not turn you into a beast immediately, but it will definitely get you started. These six simple tips will help you get healthier, and help counteract the effects of sitting in front of a computer for hours upon hours every day.

It’s important to point out one very important fact: the brain and the body are connected, just in case you didn’t realize that yet. The mind is sluggish when the body is sluggish. The mind is unhealthy when the body is unhealthy. Remember to start small, cut the crap, find your rhythm, set goals, find your battle team and stay flexible. You’ll be more clear minded, you’ll be more productive, you’ll be more creative. In short, you’ll be a better worker.

Title: The Latino Voter Base is Booming: Why You Should Care
Content:
Holding A Goldfish’s Attention

Digital technology has changed politics. You can no longer look at one without the other, and while that may be for better or for worse, candidates across the nation are seeking digital experts for the competitive edge needed amidst close elections.   For our political team, that means studying news media trends, navigating digital platforms, and analyzing demographic data to push content that mobilizes voters with the right message at the right time. And while digital technology has allowed political campaigns to access a plethora of voter data, campaign success relies on figuring out how best to cut through the information overload, access echo chambers, and grab voters’ attention. With our attention span becoming shorter than that of a goldfish’s, seeking and capturing the American voters’ attention long enough to care about an issue is no easy feat. Fortunately for our candidates, Push Digital always stays one step ahead.

Tapping Into the Latino Vote Fun fact: Every 30 seconds, a Latino becomes eligible to vote

Resourcefulness and adaptation. To survive the ever-changing political landscape in today’s digital era, you need both of these skills. As a Colombian-born millennial working for Push Digital’s political team, I am a direct manifestation of one of the many evolutions seen throughout recent American elections – a rising Latino voter population. As of 2016, more than 27.3 million Latino voters were eligible to vote, and that number has been continually growing since.  In fact, estimates show that by 2050, the Latino population will rise to 133 million. But here’s the thing, the rate of eligible Latino voters is increasing faster than the number of Latino voters from our previous presidential elections. In other words, while the Latino voter base is growing, actual turnout pales in comparison.

Bridging the Gap Between Voter and Ballot

While knowledge of the rising Latino voter population in the U.S. is nothing new, it’s more pertinent to campaign success than ever before. Now the largest ethnic minority in the country, this group’s influence over the political agenda is far-reaching. Safe to say, appealing to this demographic is the golden ticket to winning elections, and to do that, we must do the following:
  1. Dispel Myths

Even though Latinos have historically leaned left of the ideological spectrum, we saw a surprising, and quite unexpected change within the GOP voter base, as Latinos made up roughly 29% of the Trump voter electoral base in 2016. Continuing polarization among parties will allow further capitalization of this change, and Republican political campaigns especially will need to adapt digital strategies to reach a more ethnically diverse voter base.

  1.   Methodology

The largest percentage of eligible Latino voters are millennials. Which is great, because they have a higher tendency to be digitally inclined, bilingual, and aspirational. So how can campaigns target this group to increase voter turnout, especially within battleground states like Florida, Pennsylvania, and Ohio? According to surveys, young voters within this demographic are ambivalent over casting a vote, simply because they feel it won’t make a difference… Oh the irony. To mobilize young Latino voters, the effort must be put in regardless of the risk. At Push Digital, clients are coming to us to reach this demographic because they know it’s in their campaign’s best interest.

  1.   Curated Content

There are many challenges that come with connecting to an ethnically diverse voter population. For one, candidates may face backlash from voters who only speak the English language. Studies show English-speaking voters’ attitudes over seeing Spanish-language political ads to be extremely negative.  Likewise, not every Latino population is the same and should be advertised the same content, even within the message matrix. This is particularly true when it comes to different dialects of Spanish speakers. In order to effectively communicate political messages among Latino voters - content needs to be curated in accordance with language, dialect, age, and country of origin. It’s important to keep these items in mind when developing your message and digital targeting.  

Have I lost you yet?  There’s a reason a large source of the Latino Voter population remains untapped - it’s gruesome work. Mitigating between the digital space, political arena, and rising diversity among the U.S. voter population is tricky terrain. But someone’s gotta do it, and here at Push Digital, we aren’t afraid of a little challenge. ? Thanks for reading, Camila Romero

Title: 2018 Has Totally Sucked
Content: Two years ago this past weekend, my family and Mark Baker, who we call “Hotspot” in F3, flew off to France where Hotspot and I took on the most painful event of my wanna-be endurance athlete career - the GORUCK HTL. The long and the short of it is, Hotspot and I got our asses kicked for nearly 40 hours on the beaches of Normandy by American special forces operators on the anniversary of D-Day. Over 600 men have come through F3 Summerville and Hotspot and I were the first ones to earn the coveted lightning bolt patch. Up until yesterday, we remained the only two. This weekend, two years to the date of our Normandy adventure, GORUCK held a D-Day themed HTL right here in Charleston, SC. Because of my Ironman training I decided to forego the hardest parts of the event, but I did jump in for the last five hours, the Light, to support my F3 Summerville brothers who were going for the bolts. I choked back tears watching my brothers Double Trouble, Defib, KY and Stringbean get patched, thinking about how much that little piece of fabric has meant to me. A lot of bloggers write about how awesome their lives are. They’re crushing it. Everything they touch is gold. You should buy their book or pay for their video subscription and learn how to be just like them. In a matter of 6 months you will be making an extra million a month and driving that Ferrari. About 95% of it is Internet garbage. It’s #FakeNews. Let me be a lot more real with you -- 2018 has SUCKED. We entered the year with the best client roster, best staff and the most momentum we’ve ever had. Then within 30 days we lost three major corporate clients because of internal turnover and I decided to part ways with a premiere statewide candidate. For the first time in the agency’s history, I had more money going out than coming in. I laid off staff for the first time. I stopped sleeping. I stopped eating. I stressed puked every morning. I kept getting sick over and over again. I hid from my friends and F3 brothers. I’ve been through more stress throughout my life than most humans I know. Dealing with stress is my superpower. I’ve always been able to just muscle through it. But this time was different. The more I pushed, the more I got stressed, the more I got sick, the more I was out of commission. I made a decision. I moved all my race medals and GORUCK patches to my office. I started staring at them. They are right behind this computer as I type this sentence. I look one inch to the right and there they are. A real reminder of some shit I’ve endured. One random day a thought popped into my head- I didn’t just endure those events. I didn’t just push through them. I developed a plan. I put all the pieces in place to enact the plan. In every single event I’ve taken on, I’ve crossed the finish line. No matter how slow or how painful, I ALWAYS finished. And more importantly - I learned something new from each event. I learned something about myself. I learned how to find comfort in pain. I put together a new business vision and a new plan of action. I brought on new people and restructured the team. I reassigned job duties, including mine. I can give you pages upon pages of details, but you don’t want all that right now. The summary is simple: I decided to get comfortable being uncomfortable. I found comfort in this new uneasy place in which I found myself and my company. I found comfort in the instability. That reduced the stress, enabling me to take a step back to develop a plan of action. It’s exactly what I did two years ago when hiking in the middle of the night alongside Omaha Beach from Point Du Hoc. My feet completely covered in blisters, my back and shoulders on fire, and my head in the darkest place it’s ever been in, I decided right then and there to enjoy the pain because the pain was proof of progress. I found comfort in complete anguish. That enabled me to get my mind right. That enabled me to develop a plan. And that enabled me to finish. When my boys got their patch this weekend, I could see on their faces that they’ve been exactly where I’ve been. Not just two years ago- but two months ago. The same dark place. The same path out. It’s the same damn thing. Today, we’re almost back to the place we originally planned for 2018. We’ve picked up some huge clients, including a Fortune 70 company. We’re in the process of hiring more people than we laid off, bringing us to the largest and most talented staff we’ve had yet. And we’re less than one week from moving into our expanded office. I get asked all the time “How do you have time to run your business when you’re training all the time?” Where I then ask myself, “How else could I learn such valuable business lessons?” W

Title: The Most Little Bitch Thing I’ve Ever Thought
Content: Two years ago I walked along the cliffs between Pointe Du Hoc and Omaha Beach. We were about 35 hours into a long endurance event put on by GORUCK known as the HTL. The Heavy, Tough and Light are three back-to-back-to-back events. The Heavy is 24 hours. The Tough is 12 hours. The Light is 5 hours. My feet were covered in blisters and rubbed raw from the Heavy’s 40 mile walk, carrying a 40 pound ruck, which was preceeded by re-enactments of us storming and low crawling across Utah Beach. We were covered in sand from head to toe without the ability to wash ourselves off before the long walk. With every step the sand rubbed across my skin like sandpaper. My feet, the space between my legs (including those sensitive spots), under my arms... everything was raw. Still we marched on carrying as much heavy shit as the cadre could pile on our shoulders. I completed the Heavy but the damage was done by the time we started the Tough. There was no fixing the blisters and skin rashes between events. All I could do was pop Ibruprofin and Tylenol. We started the Tough at Pointe Du Hoc where about 150 Army Rangers were killed trying to take the highest point between Utah and Omaha Beaches. Again, we were loaded up with as much heavy shit as we could carry (sand bags, poles, anything the cadre could find) on top of the 40 pound rucks we were required to have on our backs. We began to walk. One hour became three which became ten. I reached one of the darkest places my mind has ever gone. As the sun began to rise we reached Omaha Beach where, again, we had to re-enact the troops emptying out of Higgins boats and storming the beach. The water was some of the most frigid I had ever encountered. Unlike the Heavy event where we immediately started the hike, the cadre set us down for an hour to give us a history of Omaha Beach. Sounds nice, right? A history lesson instead of carrying heavy shit mile after mile? No, this is where the dark got darker. Because we didn’t get PTed or forced to hike, we remained soaking wet in the frigid cold, sitting on the beach as the cold air blew in. All manliness left as I snuggled up closer to my partner in pain, Hotspot. I couldn’t stop shaking. I was cold to my core. I started feeling what I thought was hypothermia. I didn’t honestly know what that felt like, but I was pretty sure I was there. It was, with all honesty, as dark as my mind has ever gotten. I considered quitting the HTL right then and there. How could it get any worse? Seriously. That’s what I asked myself sitting on Omaha Beach. How can it get any worse? Are you EFFING kidding me? What kind of little bitch ass thing is that to think? Obviously this is just a movie, but let me show you how it can get A HELL OF A LOT WORSE! https://youtu.be/X-bogN0V8RM I could be an 18-year-old kid who is leaving his mother for the first time. I could really be jumping out of a Higgins boat, not just pretending, after puking my guts out and being drug to the ocean floor by ruck and weapon. I could be making to the beach where Nazis are trying to blow my face off. I could be laying on the beach after being struck by a mortar, my leg just blown off and screaming for my mother. Right here, in this very spot where I sit, men and even kids poured their blood and their literal lives into the sand and I’m sitting here bitching about blisters, rashes and the cold. They did it to save Europe and to ensure that Hitler’s regime never reached America. This was the counterattack. Right here. This turned the war. This saved the world. This was too hallowed ground for me to quit. Hell, it was too hallowed for me to even whine or feel sorry for myself. That’s where my mind went. Everything got brighter and I found the energy to carry on. Every single step that got me to the finish line was fueled by the thought of those heroes.

Title: 5 Digital Tips For Political Campaigns
Content:
We’re expanding, taking on more advocacy projects and corporate clients, but political campaigns are in our DNA. We can’t just rip out a part of our DNA. We’re told that biology doesn't work like that.

Political campaigns may work us to death, spend way too much money on TV, sometimes not even pay their bills and have the loyalty of Little Finger from Game of Thrones, but we’re in for the long haul. There are too many problems in this world that need fixing for us to just turn our backs on the leaders who actually have the power to fix them.

Why am I telling you all this? Because in the past six months I’ve heard no less than 50 times “you guys still do political campaigns?”

YES! We still do political campaigns. We’re one of the premier Republican digital agencies in the nation. We’re just getting more selective about who we work with because life is too short to work for people who aren’t serious about the monumental problems facing our city, our state, our nation and especially our planet.

So, while we’re busy working on our selective political client list, we’re still throwing out a lot of free advice to all the Republican political campaigns out there. Here’s some new awesomeness from Phil Vangelakos who leads our political division.

Title: 5 Reasons Why Mark Sanford Lost
Content:
[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mSfYVrxhdVw&feature=youtu.be[/embed] At 4:12 pm, President Donald Trump sent out this tweet in the midst of South Carolina’s primary election day... The polls closed at 7 pm. A few hours later, freshman state legislator Katie Arrington shockingly defeated Congressman Mark Sanford, with some pundits claiming the defeat was the result of the “Trump Effect.” So, was Trump really responsible for this outcome? The short answer is no. A last minute tweet by President Trump did not cause a mass exodus of people rush to the polls to vote Arrington for Congress. So, how was Arrington able to defeat Sanford? Here are the five reasons.
  1. Strength vs Weakness
The personality trait the GOP wants most is strength. They want strong leaders with strong personalities. Terry Sullivan, a political consultant, told Yahoo News the GOP has lost its ideological compass, explaining how Republicans care more about personality than ideas. In the race between Arrington and Sanford, Katie Arrington came across as a strong female ready to take on the role as Congresswoman while Mark Sanford, as usual, came across as an ideologue and frankly, a very weak man. When you think Mark Sanford, the last thing you think of is strength. From his famous Appalachian Trail hike disappearance to his admittance of engaging in an extramarital affair to crying on national TV, Sanford has epitomized what it means to be weak.
  1. Sanford Didn't Take Arrington Seriously Until It Was Too Late
Mark Sanford got out worked. Big time. We didn't hear anything from Sanford for weeks while Katie was working her tail off. She was everywhere. Her signs were everywhere. She was all over TV. She was all over the Internet. She was physically all over the district attending pretty much any meeting where two or more people gathered. The lady straight up worked her ass off.   On the other hand, even when he wasn't in Washington, Sanford was nowhere to be found until about the last three weeks of the race when he finally decided to start spending some of his huge war chest on TV and start showing up in the community. The weekend before the election we finally saw him with his head out in Summerville. He was walking around the local farmers market with no staff, no literature, no stickers and barely talking to people. On second thought, he may have just been buying vegetables. Regardless, Sanford wasn’t nearly as present as Arrington was.
  1. Sanford Didn't Have A Real Campaign Or A Ground Game.
Did Sanford have a campaign manager? A communications director? A political director? Nobody knows. All indications are that he did not have a campaign at all and if he did, we sure didn't see it. He must have thought he could win with a last minute TV blitz alone. Big mistake. As the owner of one of the nations most prominent Republican digital agencies, you'd expect me to say that grassroots politics is dead and that you should throw all your money online. Well, that's horseshit. Ground games win close elections and this one was close. Arrington put together an excellent campaign team that concentrated on grassroots. She didn't just outwork Sanford alone. She put together a badass team that outworked Sanford.
  1. Mark Sanford Left Too Much Money In The Bank
Sanford is notoriously cheap. He doesn't like to spend money. However, he could have hired a great team for a small amount of money. Why? Because in campaigns, people are the cheapest thing you can buy. Sanford has one of the best TV firms in the nation. He could have leaned on them more and been on TV months earlier. He could have effectively drowned Arrington out. But instead, Sanford left over $1 million in the bank. Let that sink in. One. Million. Dollars. That's just campaign negligence.
  1. President Trump.
President Trump endorsed Arrington once it didn’t matter anymore. His endorsement tweet came at the last minute, when he already saw she was going to win. What President Trump did do was sit back and let Mark Sanford attack him. And in South Carolina, that's enough. Every South Carolina GOP primary poll I've seen in 2018 indicates that the number one issue voters care about is loyalty to President Trump. Sanford stood his ideological ground and took numerous shots at President Trump. Arrington used that in every way she could, including on TV. She is a Trump loyalist. Sanford is a Trump antagonist. And right now in South Carolina, the loyalists will prevail.

Title: I Don't Belong In Jail
Content:
[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slo0_0JQnwA&feature=youtu.be[/embed]
I got into a couple extremely heated social media fights in the last month. Yeah, go figure, right?  Wesley Donehue got into a social media argument. I know you can’t believe it.

Anyway, a couple dudes started harassing me for helping lead the push for the big SC roads bill in which the state raised the gas tax to collect $500 Million to fix our extremely shitty and dangerous roads. They called me a criminal. They said that the bill is theft. I belong in jail. I’m immoral and unethical.

Millions of dollars were spent this election cycle by candidates and shady out of state special interest groups to attack Republicans who voted for the bill. In every case, the Republican who supported the roads bill won.

BOOM! It seems that South Carolina voters don’t think I belong in jail after all.

That’s what Michael talks about in this new video.

Title: Do Ground Games Really Matter?
Content:
We're all digital. It's what we do and it's what we know. It's even a part of Push's name. So, in an increasingly digital world, do ground games actually matter in a political campaign?

Is direct mail effective anymore? Do people really pay attention to yard signs or newspaper ads? 

Well, I've weighed in on all of it. And, while it's not so cut and dry, my opinion might surprise you.

Check out my latest video!

[embed]https://youtu.be/1Eqx8qoyVwQ[/embed]

Title: Does It Matter? - Digital Platforms Edition
Content:
Anybody who's somebody is on social media. It's how people keep up with each other and how people express themselves.

People use social media for everything, from posting their latest vacation photos to posting what they ate for dinner to getting into heated political debates over Trump's latest tweet.

Social media has taken the world by storm.

So, what role does social media play in a political campaign?

Social media has the power to drastically change the course of an election. However, that's only if you know what platforms to use and how to use them.

By using social media, politicians can connect to voters in a way that has never been done before, by responding to questions and current events in real time.

Politicians should be taking advantage of the fact that they have a direct line of communication to voters. But, with so many different digital platforms out there, it's important to know which ones are worth your time and energy, especially if you're running a political campaign.

Check out my latest video, where I examine the best digital platforms to use in a political campaign!

[embed]https://youtu.be/mhmrKuRrgX8[/embed]

Title: Does It Matter? - Digital Advertising Edition
Content:
While it's important for political candidates to be visible on digital platforms, that's not possible without digital advertising.

Digital advertising encompasses everything from search to facebook ads to pre-roll to display. While they're all important, knowing which one to target more than others will make all the difference in a political campaign.

In short, search matters more than any other platform and display is dead. 

Learn more by watching Brooke Willaby, Director of Marketing and Advertising at Push Digital, give her take on the best platforms to put money behind in a campaign!


[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=trENjQNOCOE[/embed]

Title: There Is No Excuse For Not Publishing Awesome Content
Content:
“I don’t like to be on camera.”

“I don’t write well.”

There is always an excuse. For anything. For everything.

That’s certainly true when it comes to putting out great content. We hear these excuses over and over again. The truth is that everyone has a talent. Everyone has a way of expressing themselves. Everyone can pump out awesome content, if they have something awesome to say.

My excuse is that I don’t have time to write. I love writing. But with meetings, calls, staff interruptions, a wife and two boys always wanting my attention, I just can’t find the time to sit down, clear my head and put the words on paper. That’s why I pump out so many videos. It’s not that I love seeing myself on camera. I typically cringe every time I see my crooked nose. It’s just easy and something I can do in 10 minutes between the chaos.

That brings me to our lead graphic designer, JP Phillips. JP is as introverted as they come. He would say he has “overwhelming social anxiety.” When we tasked every staffer with taking over our Instagram Story for one day and it was his turn, JP didn’t come to me with an excuse. He used his amazing talent as an illustrator to express himself in a completely unique and amazing way.

I’m super stoked to share with you JP’s Instagram Story highlighting his day at Push Digital...

[tribulant_slideshow gallery_id=1]

Title: Branding 101
Content:
If I had to guess, you’re currently consuming an overpriced Starbucks drink while scrolling through this article on an Apple device. Have you ever stopped to think about why these companies are so popular and widely recognized? It’s about more than just good coffee and efficient technology. It’s about how they’ve successfully branded themselves! Branding is one of the most vital aspects in developing a company. It’s a company’s identity. It’s who they are and how the rest of the world sees them. Push Digital may have started as an exclusively political agency, but we’ve continued to expand into consumer brand marketing and advocacy! From logo design, to videography, to websites — we’ve got the creative chops to take on any task. We pride ourselves in our ability to create a company’s identity through a detailed process. For PUSH Digital, branding is more than just designing a logo or developing a website. It’s about connecting with a client, creating their identity, determining their mission, and executing a plan of action. It’s about getting to know every single part of a brand, but it’s also about the brand getting to know us. It’s about figuring out what the brand needs and how we can meet those needs. It’s about using the incredibly talented designers we have and showcasing their unique skills. The branding process at Push is tailored to each individual client, paying close attention to their wants and needs. The process is broken down into three phases:
  1. Discovery Phase
  2. Production Phase
  3. Marketing Phase
The Discovery Phase is essentially like speed-dating. We try to get as much information about our clients as possible through a series of conversations and interviews. In doing so, we’re able to create a creative blueprint that is used in the last two phases to ensure our content is cohesive. The Production Phase is all about development. Whether it’s developing a brand’s logo or a company’s website, the production phase puts pen to paper…or hand to computer mouse. It involves drawing the logos, selecting fonts and colors, building wireframes, etc, all of which involves close contact with the respective client to refine any and all details. Now, you have your final product! Your logo and/or website is finally created! That’s it, right? No. You’d think we’d stop there, but we don’t. We don’t just build your content, we market it, too. The Marketing Phase calls on our top-of-the-line marketing and advertising teams, who are ready to drive continuous engagements to your content. They work closely with our clients to determine who they want to target and how they can best target them. This means that we are guaranteed to generate the best ROI possible. Throughout these various phases, we work to find ways to differentiate a brand from other markets in similar fields. In short, Push Digital pushes the limits when it comes to branding.

Title: Branding: Getting To Know You
Content: Arguably, one of the most important phases of the branding process at Push is the Discovery Phase! The Discovery Phase is exactly what it sounds like - discovering everything we possibly can about your company and future goals! We achieve this by using our tried-and-true process, which uses a combination of conversation and collaborative online questionnaires to establish a solid foundation for your project. Throughout these conversations, we work to figure out everything we can about a client - their purpose, audience, goals, timeline, challenges - everything that could help us get closer to determining who they currently are and who they want to become. One of the most helpful tools we use are questionnaires! Questionnaires are created by account executives and tailored to each client. Each questionnaire involves a comprehensive list of questions about the business itself, their customers, and their identity. After reading and analyzing the responses to the questionnaire, our account executives then create a baseline assessment. This assessment essentially reviews a company’s existing brand experience and story, including culture, benefits, values, and target audience - all of which provide the groundwork for our plan of action. In addition, we also survey a brand’s competitive landscape, looking at both direct and potential competitors. This helps us determine industry norms, which can further identify visual cues, opportunities, and things to avoid. All of these steps are then combined to create a brand’s Creative Blueprint. This blueprint is a guiding document that aids our account executives and designers in determining their direction. The Creative Blueprint is our direction forward. Each blueprint restates client directives on style, asset needs, and content, which are then translated into timelines. It helps us and our clients visualize what we’re saying in design-speak, so to say. Overall, the Discovery Phase is our way of becoming a part of the brand. It’s not just about listening to what a client wants and executing it, it’s about listening and understanding how we can grow and improve the brand - short-term and long-term. It’s about using our knowledge and experience to determine how we can differentiate a brand in their market. The Discovery Phase highlights the brand’s most important features and challenges - all of which provide us with the tools we need to embark on the next phase of the branding process, the Production Phase!
Image Caption: Wesley Donehue Writing

Title: Put Your Money Where Your Posts Are
Content: Remember the days when all you had to do was create a following on social media and then pump out content? Back then, it was easy to flood people’s feeds and timelines with your content. And, you knew people would see everything you created. Not in today’s world. Everything has changed. Nowadays, you shouldn’t even bother posting content, if you’re not putting money behind it. You’re just wasting your time and resources. Everything is pay-to-play. Find out more below! Title: Put The SOCIAL Back In Social Media
Content:
In today's world, everyone is constantly looking down. Everyone has their face buried in their phone, scrolling through their texts and social media feeds.

People have lost basic communication skills in all facets of life, including social media. Social media is supposed to be a place where people can actively engage with their friends and followers. However, people have lost touch with what it means to be "social" on social media.

Social media is not just for talking TO people, it's for talking WITH people.
