Title: Choosing The Right Ad Mix For You
Content: Where should you advertise? Here’s your answer. I’m contacted a few times each week by friends or people who have found me online asking specifically where they should advertise - TV, mail, digital, etc. The answer is that it completely depends on your audience. There are common themes and big messages that resonate with a large swath of the population. These can be formatted into ads delivered across mass media such as television, radio or billboards, or across all digital channels. Basically, places where everyone sees them, a shotgun approach that provides a large bang for the buck. Think McDonald’s. Everyone loves cheeseburgers so their audience is everyone. Mass media makes sense for them. There are more specific themes that resonate with a more specific audience, say women and cosmetics. These ads can be placed on mass media platforms such as television, but should be targeted to channels and shows watched mostly by females, or in female targeted publications such as Cosmo. In today’s media environment the most optimal platforms to place these ads are digital because of the ability to receive instant feedback on performance, allowing you to change and perfect messaging, creative and targets. We call this optimization. Lastly there are very specific messages for niche audiences. These messages are best delivered over digital channels or perhaps in the mailbox. Aside from Runner’s World magazine, there isn’t a great way to reach a small audience such as marathoners. Or Star Trek fans. This is where you really utilize digital. You can get insanely granular using millions or data points. Want to reach 41 year old white dudes who run marathons, love Star Trek, listen to the Wu Tang clan, have three children and run marathons? Yeah, me. You reach me across digital platforms. Good luck coming up with that creative. The best media plans use a little bit of each, which is called a media mix. Lets look at a political campaign as an example because that’s where we are the best in the nation. We are a converged media company, meaning we do marketing across all platforms. We may have five big television ads in rotation across different media markets across a state with big messages that resonate with everyone, ie this guy is an honest and ethical family man. Then we may have 200 niche ads running across digital platforms, including connected televisions, targeting pro-lifers, gun owners, hard fiscal conservatives, moderates, moms, and many many more audiences. In the current iteration of the internet, referred to as Web 2.0, we are hyper focused on media mixes based on television, connected television and all digital platforms. Occasionally we run mail, billboards and other print ads, but those are mostly done for local races. If you need more specific help with your media planning give us a shout. Email austin@pushdigital.com.
Image Title: 211111_Wesley Donehue_Choosing the Right Ad Mix For You_1200x628

Title: Brain Fog
Content:
Where are the book reviews? There’s a good reason the book reviews have slowed down. It’s because the reading has slowed down.  A lot of people talk about the physical exhaustion that comes with training for endurance events. Rarely do people talk about the mental exhaustion. I’ve reached the point when mental fog weighs heavy in my head.  Just looking at a page hurts my brain. I’ve repeatedly read pages and then asked myself “what the hell did I just read?” Listening is no better. Currently I’m in the middle of a few books: The Bitcoin Standard The Almanack of Naval Ravikant Dune Dreamland How Will You Measure Your Life? Moonraker Propaganda  The Swamp Fox I have a stack of at least 20 books sitting behind those.  Now that I have passed the last big weekend of training and I’m entering the taper phase with just ten days before the big Ironman in Cozumel, I’m hoping that the brain fog clears so that I’m able to bring you some new reviews. In the meantime I would like to know what you’re looking for. The two questions I get asked the most on a daily basis are:
  1. How do I get started with cryptocurrency?
  2. What books should I read?
Ignore #1 for now and lets focus on the books. What do you want?  Just a list of my favorites? Best business books? Best books to read drinking beers on a beach? Let me know and I will work on some lists when the brain fog clears. I hope you have a phenomenal day full of Positive Vibes!

Title: The Metaverse Is Coming Soon
Content: Last week news broke that Nike has filed seven trademark applications to sell virtual shoes as it prepares to enter the metaverse.  This is no longer just something nerds like me are talking about, or have been talking for years. This was always going to be Web 3.0. The Covid pandemic just sped it all up a few years because everything in our lives, from work to happy hours, became virtual in 2021. You’re going to see me writing a lot about Web 3.0 because it’s been a passion of mine and now that everyone is talking about it, a lot of you are hitting me up with questions. To answer any of them you first have to understand exactly what Web 3.0 is. The first website, pictured above, was launched in 1991. It was just text on a screen. That’s Web 1.0. Can you believe we’ve come so far in just twenty years? That’s what you have to know about digital technology. There isn’t a linear progression. It’s a compounding progression. Every advancement speeds up the next advancement.  Web 2.0 is what we have now. There’s lots of interaction and it’s dominated mostly by user generated content on mobile devices and accessed through apps. Let’s pause for a second and talk about ownership. This is something that should and will be a separate post but we must skim across it to understand Web 3.0.  In Web 2.0 you don’t own anything, other than perhaps a domain name. You upload content to Insta and TikTok but you don’t actually own the content. You’ve given it away.  Most people look at Web 3.0 as virtual reality, but really it’s where virtual reality meets ownership. Or more specifically, where VR meets blockchain. Companies like Facebook or Epic Games may build the virtual world, but you will own the things in that world, like those Nikes mentioned above or the NFTs you keep hearing about. You will own land, buildings, art and purses. Yes purses. Louis Vuitton is already making moves for the metaverse.  You will own part of the internet because of blockchain. Think of it like this - God created the world but you own your house and your car. Oh no, did I just compare Mark Zuckerberg to God? This is very important. You will be spending a large part of your day in a virtual world that will have actual ownership, thus a robust economy. That economy will completely disrupt the economy of the real world, making them inseparable. And if you’re a marketer or campaign hack like me, you best believe that much of your campaigning will happen in that virtual world. I know, you’re rolling your eyes right now thinking “yeah, right.” And I’m rolling my eyes right now thinking “that’s what you said when I told you that you’ll be campaigning on Facebook.” Much more on this topic in the coming weeks.

Title: Turning the Flywheel Book Review
Content: Turning the Flywheel: A monograph to Accompany Good to Great by Jim Collins  Like a few other “books” I’ve reviewed, this one is too short to even classify as a book. However, it’s also super important so I do want to review and recommend.   Turning The Flywheel can be better classified as a companion to Jim Collins’ masterpiece Good to Great. In Good to Great, Collins explains the flywheel concept. Here he dives in much deeper: “Picture a huge, heavy flywheel—a massive metal disk mounted horizontally on an axle, about 30 feet in diameter, 2 feet thick, and weighing about 5,000 pounds. Now imagine that your task is to get the flywheel rotating on the axle as fast and long as possible.” “Pushing with great effort, you get the flywheel to inch forward, moving almost imperceptibly at first. You keep pushing and, after two or three hours of persistent effort, you get the flywheel to complete one entire turn.” “You keep pushing, and the flywheel begins to move a bit faster, and with continued great effort, you move it around a second rotation. You keep pushing in a consistent direction. Three turns … four … five … six … the flywheel builds up speed … seven … eight … you keep pushing … nine … ten … it builds momentum … eleven … twelve … moving faster with each turn … twenty … thirty … fifty … a hundred.” “Then, at some point—breakthrough! The momentum of the thing kicks in your favor, hurling the flywheel forward, turn after turn … whoosh! … its own heavy weight working for you. You’re pushing no harder than during the first rotation, but the flywheel goes faster and faster. Each turn of the flywheel builds upon work done earlier, compounding your investment of effort. A thousand times faster, then ten thousand, then a hundred thousand. The huge heavy disk flies forward, with almost unstoppable momentum.” “A flywheel is an underlying, compelling logic of momentum … there’s an inevitability built in. If you do A, you almost can’t help but do B. And if you do B, you almost can’t help but do C. And if you do C, you almost can’t help but do D. And around and around. And it’s driven around because there’s an underlying connection. There’s a logical sequence that builds dynamic momentum, because A drives B drives C drives D and around back to the top of the loop.” “The key is you build it over a long period of time. The power of a flywheel is that it’s an underlying logic, it’s an underlying architecture.” Collins dives into how many companies, including Amazon, have created their flywheel. Good to Great is a top five must read for every entrepreneur. This companion is a must read immediately after. #65in2021

Title: Advice For Political Staffers
Content: “For over a thousand years Roman conquerors returning from the wars enjoyed the honor of triumph, a tumultuous parade. In the procession came trumpeteers, musicians and strange animals from conquered territories, together with carts laden with treasure and captured armaments. The conquerors rode in a triumphal chariot, the dazed prisoners walking in chains before him. Sometimes his children robed in white stood with him in the chariot or rode the trace horses. A slave stood behind the conqueror holding a golden crown and whispering in his ear a warning: that all glory is fleeting.”  ⁃ General George S. Patton The slave should have also been whispering in the ears of the conqueror’s assistants as they are even more likely to fall victim to the praise of the crowd.  Today they are the gatekeepers. Tomorrow they are the beggars. If there is but one piece of advice I can give to political staffers it’s this. Whether they are working on a campaign or in a legislative or executive office I find that political staffers often forget that they are simply a wagon hitched to a horse and not the horse itself. Without that horse they are stagnant.  If glory is fleeting for the horse and the horse is creating all the movement, what do you think happens to the wagon?  It simply sits and rots. How political staffers treat people while they are the gatekeeper determines what happens when they are no longer hitched to the conquer. They could be picked up by the next conquer or they can be left to rot.  Far too often we see political staffers walk around Washington or campaign events like they are the most important person in the world. “I work for so and so” we hear. Yeah, but so and so won’t always be there. Then what? You won’t always have that power because the power isn’t even with you today.    How you treat people when you yield the power given to you by the fleeting politician determines how you will be treated when that politician is gone. You will be loved or you will be despised.  I suggest finding someone to whisper “glory is fleeting” in your ear a few times each week. Post it on your fridge. Tattoo it on your arm.

Title: The Gap and the Gain Book Review
Content: The Gap and The Gain by Dan Sullivan I have so much. A beautiful, smart, driven and giving wife. Three awesome boys who are everything to me. A gorgeous home. The car I wanted. Money in the bank, the market, real estate and crypto. Multiple successful businesses producing positive cashflow and badass teams running them. The ability to travel the world and do stupid endurance events. I could go on but it would sound braggy and douchey and that’s not the point of this post. The point is that I’ve come a long way from that Section 8 housing in North Charleston. That’s called the Gain. It’s where we started to where we are now and all the great achievements in between. When we focus on the Gain and how much we have achieved we are in a better mental space because we are so much more grateful for what we have. Unfortunately that’s now where most of us are. We are in the Gap. That’s when we focus on where we are today compared to all the things we want. We become dissatisfied with our lives because we are focused on what we do not have. That’s not to say we shouldn’t have big goals. The problem is that we get into this comparison game with others and we start thinking that our lives suck because we don’t have what they have. Social media, and especially Instagram, have made this all so much worse. With complete honesty and transparency, that’s me. I live in the Gap. I compare myself to my competitors or other entrepreneurs like the ballers in my mastermind group and I start losing confidence. I ask myself why I’m not killing it like them. Why am I not printing cash, bringing home $1 Million every month, buying a yacht, flying private and driving a Ferrari? What I really need to do is take a step back and ask myself where those guys started compared to where I started. Did they grow up on welfare and live in single wide trailers with holes in the floor? Did they grow up in a violent home with addicts? Maybe they did but I’m guessing it wasn’t many of them.  Even then, why does it matter where they came from? Thats when I have to take yet another step back and realize the only thing that matters is me. I should be comparing ME to ME only.  When I do that I realize HOLY SHIT, life is absolutely AMAZING! Look what I have! Look what I’m doing! I’m hopping on a plane with my family in just two days to do a full Ironman in Cozumel!!! I’m living the freaking dream. I’m in a place I never thought I would be. Anything from here on out is just icing on a badass cake. And just like that my mind goes from being unsatisfied to satisfied. From pessimistic to optimistic. From depressed to excited. That’s the difference between living in the Gap and in the Gain. I strongly recommend this book to everyone. It’s a real mental game changer.  #66 in 2021

Title: All You Have To Do Is Not Suck
Content: I’m writing this from a flight to Mexico where I will take on my second full Ironman triathlon. I do so without my tri kit, the little outfit we wear for all three disciplines - swim, bike and run. I ordered the kit from Love The Pain, which as far as I can tell, produces the coolest looking triathlon and cycling gear available. The expensive price tag of $400 would make you think that Love The Pain would have amazing customer service, especially since their product is used for specific events on exact dates. My experience with the company was anything but awesome and should be used as a teachable moment for all entrepreneurs during these “uncertain times.” It is true that businesses around the world are facing both staffing shortages and supply chain issues due to the Covid pandemic, or rather, government’s horrible reaction to the pandemic. While this is a criticism of the US government, it’s not one of our government alone. Nations around the world have shut down factories, creating a global supply chain issue. Here in America we have passed out money for people not to work, making many to retire early and others left asking “why work at all?” As the co-owner of a brewery, I can tell you that I have directly felt both the supply chain and staffing issues in our business.  These challenges give business owners a choice. They can make excuses or they can step up and deliver exceptional service. No, scratch that. In 2021 businesses don’t even need to deliver exceptional service. They just need to do the basics and deliver the expected service. They just have to do the bare minimum. The bare minimum isn’t something a business should strive for, but it highlights how horrible customer service has become across many verticals. Turn on the news for 30 minutes today and you will hear that Thanksgiving dinner will cost more than ever and you better have already ordered your Christmas gifts because they will likely be stuck on ships for weeks. The situation is no better locally when you try to go out for dinner or order an Uber. Everything takes longer. Everything is more expensive, if you can get it at all. And because it’s so bad, entrepreneurs have an opportunity to succeed that they may never get again. Customers are so frustrated that have become exceptionally happy to just receive what they are promised. Some things will be out of a business owners control. They can’t create supplies in a Star Trek style replicator and those robots we’ve been promised for decades aren’t here yet to cook your food. That means business owners have to deliver exceptional service where they can. Back to my story. I ordered my tri kit six weeks ago with the understanding, because of warnings on their website, that orders were taking about two weeks longer than normal. Two weeks ago I received the bottom half of my kit. I didn’t freak out. Last week I contacted the company and explained that I was leaving for my event on the 18th. They said “your order is done and should arrive on time.”  Friday I still had not received my kit top so I contacted them again asking if I could pay to have it overnighted. You would think that would be something they would offer me. Nope, that was my idea after they offered absolutely no horrible solution. I literally messaged them “what do I have to pay to get this done.” They responded “contact us on Monday and we will see.” Yeah, “we will see” isn’t quite the service I was expecting.  So I contacted them Monday and they said if I paid $150 they would ensure it’s done and overnighted. I paid, putting my total for a triathlon kit to $550. Crazy, right. I expected the kit to be sent to USPS, FedEx or UPS the next morning. I heard nothing on Tuesday. I woke up Wednesday with an alert that the kit was shipped overnight but dropped off after the overnight cutoff time on Tuesday. That means I wouldn’t receive the kit until Thursday, after I leave for Mexico. I contacted Love The Pain yesterday and politely told them that they dropped the ball. They responded “Thank you but we are doing great. Staffing shortages and supply chain issues can’t be avoided.” I agreed, so I responded “I simply expect you to do what you said you would do.”   The Covid pandemic has created a problem, a big problem. It has given companies like Love The Pain an excuse to deliver shitty service. All a company has to do is say “Covid” and we are expected to understand. In this case, the kit was produced and sitting in their shop. They simply didn’t put it in the mail even after I paid $150. This isn’t a supply chain or a staffing shortage. This was a work ethic issue. This was a dropped ball, a failure to deliver on a promise. While Love The Pain did screw me over, I should take part of the blame. I should have researched the company more. Had I done so I would have seen the hundreds of complaints to the Better Business Bureau. I guess I’m just not used to having to research companies. I just expect them to do what they say they’re going to do. Don’t let that be you. If your business has been impacted by Covid, just be honest with your customers. But be totally honest. Tell them how you can help them. Go above and beyond to help them. Then just deliver on your promises. That’s it. People will understand, especially when you voice that you too are frustrated. Just don’t be that business, like so many businesses right now, that are just using Covid as an excuse to be lazy. Instead use Covid as an opportunity. If everyone else is sucking, all you have to do is not suck. It’s a low bar, but that’s where we are in 2021.

Title: Who Not Now Book Review
Content: Who Not How by Dan Sullivan I have coaches for everything. I have a business coach, an agency coach and a sales coach. I have a run coach and a swim coach. I even have a crypto coach and a market advisor. I had an idea a couple years back. Instead of asking HOW to do something I started asking myself WHO can help me with this. When I started reading and watching everything I could about business, finance and fitness I quickly realized that I don’t have enough hours in the day. That’s not to say I’m going to stop teaching myself, which I obviously have not. I just wanted to move quicker than my time would allow so I needed to find experts who could help me.  That’s what this entire premise of this book. Instead of asking HOW to do something, ask yourself WHO can help you. That may be coaches or teammates or outside vendors. It’s not limited to work. Hiring someone to do your lawn or clean your home frees you up to do things that you’re good at or things you just want to do.  I was already in this headspace but had I not been this book would have been a gamechanger for me. Instead it was just affirmation that I’m on the right track. I highly recommend this book to you. #67 in 2021

Title: How Will You Measure your Life Book Review
Content: How Will You Measure Your Life by Clayton Christensen I have a job. Actually, I have a few of them. I’m the leader of Push Digital and Laurens Group. I am an investor in Frothy Beard Brewing and a couple other companies. I am the owner of a short term rental company.  But those are not my most important jobs. I am the head of my household. I am the provider, protector and teacher of three boys. I am a supportive husband.  Yesterday I listened to a podcast by Mark Evans DM in which he said his purpose is to “change the direction of my family tree.” I love that so much and I may adopt it as my purpose. That’s what I’ve been focused on. Mark just said it better. The problem is that in doing so, and I’m speaking only for myself here, the focus immediately goes to money.  To truly change the direction of my family tree I need to focus on more, on all my jobs. Some call it work/life balance. I prefer to call it work/life integration. Balance can never truly be achieved. I’m not even sure what the appropriate percentages are. What I do know is that while focusing on wealth creation I must also be focused on teaching my boys ethics, integrity, honor and strength. I have to help my wife chase her dreams. I have to help move my community forward. I have to do so much. The books answers the question “how will you measure your life” by pushing professionals toward focusing on all their jobs and not just the one that produces income. Only then can one find true happiness. I enjoyed this book and recommend it to entrepreneurs. It’s a simple reminder that we are building businesses and wealth for a reason. It’s for our lifestyles, our happiness and our families. The wealth is not the end. It’s the means to an end.

Title: Life is the Experience
Content: BOURDAIN The Definitive Oral Biography  I don’t know how to write this review because the life, or rather the death, of Anthony Bourdain says so much about our world and life in general. On the day Bourdain died I asked on Facebook “what does it say about the meaning of life when the person you most envy kills themselves?” It’s no exaggeration to say that Bourdain’s death shook me. It still does. I was obsessed with the man. I often respond with the cheesy line “I’m living the dream” when asked how I’m doing. Bourdain literally did. Or so I thought. And that’s what I wanted. I look back at past social posts and I see that I used to always travel in Bourdain’s footsteps. I’ve watched every episode of A Cook’s Tour, No Reservations, The Layover and Parts Unknown multiple times. Kitchen Confidential is one of my top ten favorite books. My posts show that I’ve visited London, Paris, Istanbul, Lisbon, New York, San Francisco, Austin, New York and Nashville all through his stops and those are just the ones I posted about. I’ve long said that I shouldn’t be chasing money. I should be chasing experiences. But if the man who had all the best experiences hates his life, what does that say about my aspirations? What does it say about my definition of cool or success? This book, more than anything, showed me that it’s in our definition of experience. The experience isn’t just about traveling to awesome places and eating amazing food. The experience isn’t even about an individual day or trip. The experience is life and not just a part of life. It’s everything. Sure, it’s visiting amazing places but it’s also about relationships and family. It’s about people. Perhaps the more Bourdain traveled the more he realized how empty his life really was. What does it mean to see everything if you see it alone? This review is my most unsatisfactory one yet because I want to write an entire essay on this topic and don’t have the time or space now. I really enjoyed this book and I recommend it to anyone who is as obsessed with Anthony Bourdain as I have been. It’s not written like a traditional biography. It is an oral history so each story comes from multiple voices. I enjoyed that even more. #69 in 2021
Image Title: 211206_WesleyDonehue_Bourdain Book Review_1200x628|211206_Wesley Donehue_How you normally do it_01 copy

Title: Today's Impossible Can Be Possible Tomorrow
Content: This year was rough. I got sidelined with an IT band issue twice for a total of one month. I slipped a disk in my back twice. I had strep throat once and bronchitis twice. Every time I took a step forward I took a step backward. I felt as if I was injured or sick the entire year. Still, I kept going. I’m not exaggerating when I say that every single day someone tells me “I can’t do that.” I’m not even talking about marathons or triathlons. I’m talking about maintaining basic fitness. I’ve heard every single excuse imaginable.  Still, heart disease and obesity related illnesses continue to be the number one killer in the nation. Even during the Covid pandemic when obesity is the primary underlying condition putting people in the hospital or in the grave, our nation continues ignoring the problem and instead takes the easy route of pushing drugs. This isn’t a vaccine rant. You do you. But you’re kidding yourself if you think a shot is going to solve your personal problem or the nation’s problem. It’s a temporary solution, not your permanent fix. It simply gives you an excuse to ignore the underlying problem killing you and this nation. I’m no Terminator style machine. I get injured. I get sick. On top of that I have very little time in my day with a family and multiple businesses. Still I go. And you can too. You can make moves or you can make excuses. I hope you will make the right choice. I’m here to support and push you along the way.
Image Title: 211206_WesleyDonehue_Make Moves MAke Excuses_1200x628|Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 9.36.17 AM

Title: The Goal Is To Beat Yourself and No One Else
Content: In this picture I’m asking Elizabeth “did you see my swim time?” As you can see from the smile on my face I was full of joy. Now that I look back at my time I see that out of 310 men in my age group I was 302nd out of the water. That’s the bottom 3%. When I tell people that my hobby is endurance races they almost always say “I can never do that.” Guys, if I can make it out of the water, even in damn near last place, you can do “impossible” shit too. Don’t lessen yourself. You are capable of so much more. Just five years ago I didn’t know how to swim.It wasn’t just that I couldn’t swim. I was scared to swim. The thought of swimming 2.4 miles in an open ocean scared the shit out of me. Then I just did the work to train my body and my mind. I’m a middle of the pack athlete and I’m okay with that. My goal is to get better each year. I’m only in competition with myself. Yeah it’s a bit embarrassing to come out of the water so near the end but guess what… I came out of the water. That would have been impossible just a few years ago. So yeah, that big thing might be impossible for you today. That doesn’t mean it has to be impossible next year. You just have to do the work. I really hope you do.
Image Title: 211206_WesleyDonehue_Confessions of Middle Pack_1200x628|Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 9.40.15 AM

Title: A lot of Pain and A lot of Fun
Content: After Action Report Swim: l just can’t believe it. I would have never thought it was possible. It was beautiful and peaceful. There was a current but nothing huge. I still wasn’t fast and I lagged behind at the end of the pack (or is it school?). I was passed by hundreds of people. But for me it was great. I never floated on my back. I just tried to be one with the water. T1: No screwing around. In and out faster than a drive thru customer at Chick-fil-A. Bike: Just brutal. The weather turned nasty real quick producing puddles as high as our pedals. The rain gave my mind a distraction and I had fun the first 80 miles, especially when I saw the family and caught up to Jenn. Then the headwind came and I could barely hold 16 mph. My IT band started giving me bad problems and it felt like someone stuck a knife in my right glute. I was miserable the last 30 miles and just wanted off the damn bike. I thought my legs would be crushed for the run and any possibility of a sub-13 hour was gone. T2: I limped in and got lost. I couldn’t find my bike in the parking garage. Total cluster. Finally found it and stormed out. Run: I just worked the problem. I put my head down and embraced the suck. I decided on a 3 min run / 1 min walk routine. I stuck with it the entire marathon and it worked. Everyone walks the later miles so I decided to force myself to chill instead of blowing up. It worked. I hurt bad around mile 18 but Elizabeth gave me the pep talk I needed and Harlowe said “Daddy, don’t stop.” I just repeated that in my head the next eight miles. I wanted a sub 13 and finished in 12:22. I’m beyond elated. My body is totally crushed but my spirit is on cloud nine. Time to drink on the beach!

Title: A List of Thank Yous
Content: A week ago right now I was sitting on Sam Eagle for six hours. Each time I biked past our support crew I thought of how thankful I am for all the people who support my crazy goals. Ironman is a multi-year journey and while I may have crossed the finish line alone, it took the work of a lot of people to get me there. Before Thanksgiving week is over allow me to throw out some thank yous: Jenn Parvin - for taking on this challenge with me and for both pushing me and pulling me back when I needed it. George, the man who never stops smiling and bringing Positive Vibes, always there to help in every single way. Gardner Leigh and Whit for being amazing cheerleaders. Endurance Farm - Chris and Jaime taught me how to swim, how to bike and how to use my body. Chris is a brother from another mother. No one has helped me more. Sarah Bishop - for having me in the best run shape of my life and for talking me off a ledge when I was sick and injured. Nancy Montgomery- for being an awesome massage therapist focused on athletes, who is constantly fixing my jacked up body. Kimmie and Donna Balaguer - Kimmie, my favorite liberal in the world, our cruise director, for being there for absolutely anything ever needed. Donna for being part of our family, chasing children and for being so damn fun. The Touchberry’s, the Arntz’s and Taylor Charpia- for trekking to Mexico to stand in the rain to cheer us on.  Jaime for being a rabbit for me to chase all year. Push and Laurens Group - the entire team has been supportive but I have to specifically call out Phil Vangelakos for taking the reins of Push this year and Christiana Purves, Jordan Russell, Phil Bailey and Austin Stukins for tackling so many business trips, allowing me to stay off the road this year more than I have in fifteen years. Lastly, my family. This is too much for a couple sentences. Elizabeth, Harlowe, Tennyson and Lawton are everything. Everything. There are many more but I cannot go on forever. People like Cannoli who constantly send encouraging messages. You all know who you are. Thank You! On to the next adventure…

Title: How Francis Marion Saved The American Revolution
Content: The Swamp Fox by John Oller  Without South Carolina and Francis Marion Americans would be saying “God save the Queen” today. When people talk of South Carolina’s history they almost always talk of the Civil War or the atrocities of slavery. We hear of the slaves routed through Charleston, the angry words of John C Calhoun and the bigotry of Ben Tillman.  We hear of how South Carolina tore the nation apart. Rarely do we hear how South Carolina helped create this nation. We were a late supporter of the cause and it took a lot of convincing for South Carolina to sign the Declaration of Independence. As the richest city in the colonies, Charleston was full of British loyalists who had a lot to lose. It was also pretty obvious that Charleston would be a first and primary target for British invasion. Charleston, along with Savannah did fall and the British were poised to move on from the South to the North where they could focus all efforts on destroying Washington’s army. Most of you outside of South Carolina have probably never heard of The Swamp Fox, Francis Marion. You may have seen The Patriot, starring Mel Gibson. The character was a composite of three men - Andrew Pickens, Thomas Sumter and mostly Francis Marion. Marion is considered the father of guerrilla warfare. Rather than confronting superior British forces face to face, which was the norm, Marion raised a militia and moved in secret throughout the woods and swamps of South Carolina to cut off British supply lines. His efforts hindered British southern efforts, forcing Cornwallis to refocus time, resources and men down South. This splitting of British priorities allowed Washington to gain decisive wins up North while also giving time for the French to arrive. There’s so much to the story of Francis Marion. I loved this book for many reasons. Marion’s character and leadership as well as military genius could take a lifetime of research in itself. This book provides a good broad overview. Mostly though I loved this book because as a South Carolinian I literally walk through or drive past so much history on a daily basis. So many battles happened right here where I stand yet I go about my day ignoring or forgetting. This book should be read by every lover of American history, but it’s damn near required reading for every South Carolinian.

Title: Don't Be In The Asshole Quadrant
Content: Radical Candor by Kim Scott Hi, I’m the asshole. A few years ago a local magazine did this feature on me in which they wrote “If you don’t want to know what Wesley Donehue thinks, you’d best not ask him. He’s smart, passionate, talented, and ferociously honest.” I’m not sure about being smart, but I am ferociously honest. Everyone will tell you that. It makes me a great consultant. It has also lost me clients, colleagues, friends and staff.  Honesty is a great trait. At least compared to the bullshit artists who dominate business and politics. The problem is that people with absolute candor can also come across as absolute assholes. That’s me. I’m the asshole. 🙋🏻‍♂️ Most people are candid because they give a damn. They give too many damns. Unfortunately they, or we, don’t always show it. That’s where this book comes in. In the comments of this post I’ve included an image. You will see two axes.  The vertical axis is what the author calls “the give a damn axis” pointing toward care personally. The horizontal axis is “the willingness to piss people off” axis pointing toward challenge directly. The key is to get in the quadrant where care personally meets challenge directly. This is where radical candor lies.  Truthfully, I live in this quadrant. Or, I should say, I think I live in this quadrant.  I care. I care too much. I care about my clients and I care deeply about my staff. The problem here is balance. I have a natural tendency to lean more into candidness than caring because I assume people know how much I care. That assumption gets me into trouble and I fall into the bottom right quadrant, what the author calls “obnoxious aggression” or “the asshole quadrant.”  The best bosses challenge their employees while showing empathy. It’s not enough to feel compassion. You have to actually show compassion. That’s easier said that done. Luckily, the author gives a detailed roadmap on how to get there. I enjoyed this book because I needed this book. In a lot of ways it was a slap in the face. Mostly I realized that it doesn’t matter what I think about myself. What matters is what others think about me. They won’t think of me as a wise consultant, good teammate or great boss if they think I’m an asshole. As I tell every political client, they have to like you before they will listen to you. Your ideas are shit if they think you’re an asshole. As for me, while nailing the honesty part of this equation, I have to not only care, but show I care. I recommend this book to all entrepreneurs.

Title: The Decentralized Alternative to Central Banking
Content: The Bitcoin Standard: The Decentralized Alternative to Central Banking by Saifedean Ammous In continuing my research into everything crypto I picked this one up because it’s number 1 on Amazon. Whether or not you should read this book is completely dependent upon your journey into the world of finance, economics and cryptocurrency. Pros: It explains the history of money and what money actually is. In fact, it actually focuses more on the history of money than on cryptocurrency and for that reason alone I think you should read it. Because let’s be honest. You think you know but you don’t because our education system is built to keep us all stupid. It explains the basics of Bitcoin, why it’s digital currency and why it’s a good store of value. It does a great job explaining why you should buy as much Bitcoin as you can. Cons: It author doesn’t believe in the blockchain technology behind Bitcoin. He doesn’t see the bigger picture at all. In fact he actively attacks anyone who believes in the concept of Web3 and says that blockchain will not be a revolutionary technology. He calls it “an overhyped toy.” He diminishes the roll of Altcoins, including Ethereum. History has already proven him to be wrong. About Altcoins he writes “one has to wonder if their only purpose is to advance the richness of its creators. Summary: At this point I’m consuming at least two hours of crypto information every day. Something I read two days ago is already old. So yeah, a book written in 2018 on this topic is going to be absolutely ancient. I’m torn on this recommendation. Yes, you should read it to understand money and Bitcoin. You should not read it to understand anything else. In fact, read it up to Chapter 10 and then toss it.

Title: The Murderbot Diaries Series
Content: All Systems Red by Martha Wells  This will be a short review because my week is stacked with insanity before everyone checks out for Christmas week.  All Systems Red, the first in The Murderbot Diaries series, is a must-read novella for every science fiction fan. It’s a quick read full of wit and action. I can’t wait to start the second book this weekend.   Murderbot is a robot, one of many, created and leased out by a company that specializes in security and defense. Murderbot is a security bot and he’s not really a robot at all. He’s a cyborg, part machine and part cloned human, which means he has consciousness. Each cyborg has a governor which allows it to be controlled by humans, but this particular “SecUnit” has hacked its governor so that he can be autonomous. He then names himself Murderbot because its primary function is to murder. However, instead of murdering all the humans he just keeps doing what they tell him to do while spending its time watching “serials” which I think are the future’s soap operas. Then all hell breaks loose when something tries to kill the team he has been leased to and our boy Murderbot gets to work.  This book is short. The humor and action will make you keep turning pages so you’ll probably knock it out in a day. I definitely recommend this book to all my fellow nerds out there.

Title: Peloton's Week From Hell
Content: Move Fast Without Breaking Your Reputation — Peloton’s Week From Hell Peloton is having the year from Hell and even when they do everything right and I’m ready to label them this week’s big winner on the Under Fire podcast, things immediately go sideways. They just cannot win. Their stock price has continued to fall all year as American’s are fed up with quarantine and getting out of their homes for outdoor and gym workouts. Peloton bikes are collecting dust while sales tumbled and projected sales look abysmal.  Just when it looked like things couldn’t get worse, HBO’s rebooted Sex and the City killed off Mr Big in it’s first episode. He had a heart attack while riding a Peloton and watching a trainer loaned to the show by Peloton. HBO didn’t warn Peloton of Mr Big’s demise. And because Sex and the City and Peloton pretty much share the exact same target audience, Peloton’s stock price tumbled 25%. Peloton went into action mode with a speed I typically only see in political campaigns. I was impressed. Real impressed. First they released a quick statement from a cardiologist blaming Big’s death on years of smoking, drinking and eating red meat. He also had heart problems two decades ago on the show. They went on to say that if not for the Peloton, Big probably would have been dead years ago. Even more impressive is that they released an ad, staring Mr Big and voiced by Ryan Reynolds stating that Mr Big was very much alive and ready for his next ride. The ad, produced by Reynolds, was up within 36 hours of Big’s death. This is almost unheard of in corporate and a lesson taken directly from political campaigns. The ad quickly went viral. Very impressive! But with speed comes danger and this one blew up in Peloton’s face. As soon as the ad went up two women came forward accusing Mr Big actor Chris Noth of sexual assault and the ad was scrubbed from existence.  Typically I would criticize Peloton for using Noth without extensive research into his past, but lets be real - the man has been used by HBO for over twenty years so it could be assumed that if nothing has yet to come out, nothing will come out. It makes you wonder why now, but that’s a topic for another day. There are two lessons from this story: First, a corporation must move with the speed of a political campaign. They need operatives (like us, and now it seems, like Ryan Reynolds) who can build out and launch quality content within hours.  Second, moving fast is key but not at the expense of research. If you move too fast you will trip over your own feet. Mark Zuckerberg says that you should “move fast and break things.” He’s right, unless that thing you’re breaking is your own reputation. Listen to our podcast all about public relations disasters and crisis communications at www.underfirepodcast.com. You can find us on Spotify and iTunes.

Title: It’s Time To Move Past Centralized Finance
Content: DeFi and the Future of Finance by Campbell R. Harvey Crypto is all the rage right now and so many of you are really interested. I know that because I’m getting blown up with a ton of questions from friends, staff and people following me that I really don’t even know. I too am super interested so I’m spending a lot of my down time reading books, articles and white papers, listening to podcasts, watching YouTube videos and taking courses. I hope I can pass along some of this knowledge to you. De-Fi, or Decentralized Finance, is an important aspect of crypto and I believe it will be the future of finance. It’s a distributed network, based on the blockchain and controlled by computer code with no central controlling entity. That’s opposed to the current iteration, centralized finance, which is controlled by powerful entities such as governments and banks. A book review is too short to explain how this works so instead I’ll just recommend you pick up this very short book to fully understand. While the author does a great job I will warn you that he gets very in-depth. Yes, it’s good for beginners, but it’s not one you can just listen to on a run. You need to read this one slowly. If you’re like me you will have to jump back and forth between the book and Google to understand broader financial concepts the author assumes you already know. Outside of this book, I have one concern about this whole idea. These techies assume this will all happen because of the natural advancement of technology. What they fail to realize is that those with power never want to give up power and that wide adoption of decentralized finance will take much longer than they believe because government regulation will happen. You already see Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen constantly yellen. The crypto community fails to understand politics. They better start playing the game. Still, I recommend this book to everyone wanting to understand crypto and the future of finance.

Title: The Best Book I Read In 2021
Content: The Almanack Naval Ravikant by Eric Jorgenson It’s fitting that one of my last books of the year is also one of the best books I’ve ever read. It’s nice to end the year on such a high note. You need to pick up The Almanack of Naval Ravikant today. Ravikant is a brilliant entrepreneur I’ve been following since hearing him on The Joe Rogan Experience. His outlook on life is one I have been trying to adopt. That outlook is laid out nicely in the book. He didn’t write the book. Instead all his public statements, including a lot of tweets, were scraped and organized into this quick read. If you read just one book in the next year, it should be this one because it is so large, yet so small. Ravikant’s views on business, morality, spirituality, health and much more are succinctly displayed and organized so that you can absorb decades of knowledge in three or four hours. Pick up this book. I cannot recommend it more.

Title: Ten Books You Will Enjoy
Content:
My Top Ten Favorite Books of 2021  Last year I set a goal of reading 50 books in one year. I knocked out 90. This year I set the same goal and read 75.  For two years I have been posting reviews in hopes that I can help you find something useful that can change, or at least help improve, your life. I started with short little two sentence reviews. Those have turned into full commentary.  This week I’ll give you a few lists of books I discovered this year, starting with my top ten favorites. These books are in no particular category and in no particular order. They are simply the ten books I most enjoyed this year.  You can find all the reviews in the link posted in the comments section of this post. I’m not posting it here because link posts won’t show up in your feed because Facebook’s algorithm is a giant mess altering our minds, our world and our future. My Top Ten Favorite Books of 2021
  1. The Psychology of Money
  2. Sapiens
  3. How To Change Your Mind
  4. Atomic Habits
  5. Project Hail Mary
  6. Shoe Dog
  7. Snow Crash
  8. The Almanack of Naval Ravikant
  9. Greenlights
  10. Tao Te Ching 
I really hope one of these books gives you many Positive Vibes.

Title: Top 10 Life Changing Books I read in 2021
Content:
Often a book is read and never thought of again. Occasionally a book comes along that completely changes your life. Maybe it changes just one small thing, like a habit. Maybe it goes bigger and changes your entire view on something, like management or finances. Occasionally a book can change your entire view of the world and maybe it even changes your soul. Here are ten books that changed me in some way this year (in no particular order)
  1. The Psychology of Money: Timeless lessons on wealth, greed and happiness
  2. On the Shortness of Life
  3. Tao te Ching
  4. Almanac of Naval Ravikant: A guide to wealth and happiness 
  5. The Wim Hof Method: Activate your full human potential 
  6. Die with Zero: All you can get from your money and your life
  7. Atomic Habits: An easy and proven way to build good habits and break bad ones
  8. Magician Not Mule: Ultimate guide to lifestyle, wealth and freedom 
  9. The Subtle Art of Not Giving A F*ck: A Counterintuitive Approach to Living a Good Life
  10. The Gap and The Gain: High Achiever's Guide to Happiness
I hope this list helps you find something that can put you on track to crush your goals in 2022.

Title: Risk Is What Makes Entrepreneurs Different
Content: Power Play: Tesla, Elon Musk, and The Bet of The Century  Risk Is What Makes Entrepreneurs Different A Review of Power Play: Tesla, Elon Musk, and The Bet of The Century by Tim Higgins I’m the dog who caught the car. I could step out of Push Digital today and no one would barely notice. Perhaps we wouldn’t be diversifying, planning for the future or starting new divisions, but we definitely would still be picking up huge political campaigns, servicing clients better than anyone else and winning huge races that impact the direction of our nation.  I’ve built a machine that can run without me. It took thirteen years. I didn’t sell my company to a larger one like some of my competitors. Ownership hasn’t changed hands. I didn’t take a big investment. I just took risks. A lot of risks. I had nothing when I went out on my own. Elizabeth supported our family through her job. I had one $500 a month client. When I got up to $2,000 per month in income I hired our first full-time staffer, gave him $1500 and lived off my $500. I did that for months. When I got to $2000 again I got another staffer. Then another. Numerous times I went without a paycheck for months so that I could make payroll or pay rent.  I’ve put it all on line more times than I can remember at this point. I do remember a few things. I remember not sleeping for three nights after losing a major corporate client. I remember crying at my desk when I was stiffed $300,000 by a political client. I remember an invoicing error from Google that set us back $250,000. Each time I thought we were done. Each time I threw all my chips on the table. Risk is what entrepreneurship is really all about. It’s hard to see. Money is easy to see. Someone is always counting your money. It’s why God told us not to covet. It’s natural. People see the new car, the new suit and the new office. They don’t see the times you could have lost it all. They don’t see when you got up from your sleepless haze and said “screw it. Lets do this.” I’m not Elon Musk. He is a once in a generation mind. We do have one thing in common, that one thing most entrepreneurs have in common. We risked it all. That’s my biggest takeaway from this book. It’s also why I’m so frustrated by the attacks on him from people like Elizabeth Warren.  Elon wasn’t given shit. He’s the richest man in the world because he made it happen. Because he took huge risks. Power Play tells the entire story of Tesla’s founding and growth, but what really stuck out to me was how Elon almost lost it numerous times. He had to sleep on couches and on factory floors. He funded the operation with his own money and when that was gone he was living on loans from friends.  Now people are attacking him like he was handed everything, like he owes the world something beyond trying to save us from ourselves. It frustrates me because people want what Elon has without taking the risks.  It’s all about the risks. Success is all about the risks. Risk nothing, gain nothing. Risk everything and maybe, just maybe, you can have something. Maybe not everything, but definitely something worth risking it all for. I enjoyed this book and recommend it.

Title: The Volatility of Cryptocurrency
Content: This past Fall I was up $180,000 in crypto. Two weeks ago I was down $67,400. Yesterday I was down $34,600. This morning when I woke up I was up $3.  Right now I'm up $5,354. Crypto is the hot new thing and I'm getting far more questions about it than anything else. Before you get involved please know that it's incredibly volatile. If you are trying to day trade and make a quick buck you are most likely going to lose it all. Rule #1 - Don't invest anything you aren't willing to lose. Rule #2 - Play long term. Rule #3 - Don't check it every day. You will stress yourself out and live on an emotional rollercoaster.  Hope that helps.

Title: The Big 4 Have Overplayed Their Hands
Content: We are all caught in the rat race.  We rush from one thing to another, work to school to baseball practice, so rapidly that we barely have enough time to put the cereal bowl in the dishwasher. We surely don’t have time to research physiology or government regulations. That’s why we elect leaders, fund scientists and pay insurance companies. We go to work, pay taxes and expect our money to speak for us. We don’t pay attention because we pay others to do so for us. We trust institutions like the media because we’ve been told it’s the fourth estate, the next branch of government. Journalists have always been there for us, keeping tabs on government and business, shining a light on corruption because, it is true, sunlight is the best disinfectant. They are here for us. They aren’t chasing profits. Or so we are told. We trust because we have to. We trust because it’s more important to compete against our neighbors than it is to read a book. Fauci says it, Trump says it, Biden says, Tucker says it, Maddow says it, hell even Big Bird says it… so it has to be true. We follow like sheep because we have time for nothing else. I’ve been feeling pretty hopeless the last two years. I’ve felt like our nation was heading down a course that could not be reversed. I’ve felt like I was alone and that the supermajority of Americans were asleep, or worse, following Big Tech, Big Government, Big Media and Big Pharma like sheep. This is the first week I’ve felt any semblance of hope. Finally I feel a shift, albeit a slow one, in public sentiment. I finally feel like Americans are waking up. The people are tired of lies and back peddling from politicians. The people are tired of being told they need another shot, then another shot, then another shot and then another. The people are tired of being put out of work while pharmaceutical companies print billions of dollars. The people are tired of government actions creating inflation and putting us on a course toward global economic collapse. The people are tired of censorship and the squashing of alternative scientific opinions. The people are waking up. The Big 4 have overplayed their hands.
Image Title: 220104_WesleyDonehue_Blog Posts Book review_DeFi and the Future-of Finance

Title: America Must Reverse Course To Keep Thought Alive
Content: What did we accomplish this year? Covid still plagues the world. Nations remain shut down. The rich and the poor are further apart. We as a people are more divided than ever. Our leaders don’t lead. Our workers don’t work. The very foundations of our nations are crumbling while we stare at our phones and allow algorithms and media executives to control our feelings, and even worse, our thoughts. Perhaps change is finally beyond our reach when even doing one’s own research is mocked. Maybe the problems are just too much to bare for a citizenry too oblivious to face them. Everything is fine. Someone else will handle it. Or maybe we’ve fallen too far down the clickhole to even care anymore. Some still care. Maybe even the majority still care. They care so much they think of nothing else. Or rather, feel nothing else. Fueled by echo chambers and cable news pundits, they point their energies toward the enemy, blaming them for every problem, refusing to budge and attacking anyone and everyone even hinting of compromise. They too see the nation crumbling but refuse to acknowledge they are holding the sledge hammer, day in and day out pounding down on the brittle ground keeping us connected. There is a a narrow opportunity, a single escape we must run toward. We must turn inward and put up walls protecting our minds from manipulation. We must put down the phones and turn off the TVs. We must see truth as truth, fact as fact and people as people. We must cut the leash and refuse to be anything other than freethinking humans. 2022 is an important year. The course we are heading can be changed, but the divergent path is rapidly approaching. There does come a tipping point when manipulation wins and going backward becomes impossible. 2021 delivered a devastating blow to free thought but it’s not dead yet. Whether it survives 2022 is up to us.
Image Title: 220104_WesleyDonehue_Blog Posts Book review_DeFi and the Future-of Finance copy

Title: We Must Allow The Scientific Method To Thrive
Content: The Price of Tomorrow - Why Inflation Is The Key To An Abundant Future by Jeff Booth “There is no one inventor of the scientific method. Like science itself, it continued to be refined thanks to the likes of Galileo, Bacon, Descartes, and Newton. The process involves 1. observation, including rigorous skepticism (to counter our cognitive biases); 2. formulating a hypothesis; 3. making a prediction that can be determined to be true or false; 4. experiments and testing to determine the validity of hypothesis. The process continually repeats, allowing better and better hypotheses to be tested and confirmed. Perhaps the most compelling thing about science and the scientific method is that it is almost never “good enough.” It is designed to continually bring in more evidence to prove existing understanding wrong and to correct it further. Error correction is the basis of all intelligence.” - Jeff Booth This week Big Tech companies such as Twitter and YouTube continued silencing scientists such as Dr Robert Malone and Dr Peter McCullough for their opposing opinions to current Covid treatments and regulations. Just yesterday Twitter and YouTube deleted Joe Rogan’s interview with Dr Malone giving no reason other than “it is misinformation.” I am no scientist or doctor, as many like to point out, so I don’t know if Malone or McCullough are actually wrong. I also don’t know if the scientists and doctors with Big Pharma companies are wrong. That’s the point. And that’s the reason for the scientific method. I cannot say it any better than Booth writes in this book. “Error correction is the basis of all intelligence.” Therefore if we silence those who point out errors, we actually lose intelligence itself. We are no longer an intelligent species. We as humans become something different. I fear that free-thought is on life support, the scientific method has been discarded and Americans have become too dumbed down by social media scrolling to even care. However, as I wrote earlier this week, I do finally see signs of Americans waking up. Much of it is fueled by Joe Rogan who we saw this week now has double the audience of traditional Big Media outlets. Actually, that’s not what this book is about at all. It’s just that Booth’s description of the scientific method punched me right in the face at the exact moment this was all on my mind. This book is actually about how scientific advancements in technologies such as artificial intelligence, energy, self-driving cars and manufacturing will create high unemployment, over abundance and deflation. He argues that we will have much more at lower costs and we must embrace that so those unemployed can also reap the benefits of technological advancement without transfers of wealth. Booth writes “We are trapped in a system where we don’t know what we would do with ourselves if we didn’t have jobs. Allowing abundance without the jobs might actually open an entirely new enlightenment era where we have time to enjoy the benefits that technology brings.” I argue all this technological advancement can only happen if we allow the scientific method to thrive, meaning we must stop censoring scientific dissent. I really enjoyed this entire book and recommend it to anyone interested in economics or emerging technologies.

Title: Why This Is The Greatest Time For Opportunity
Content: Welcome to 2022! So much opportunity lies ahead of us because the media has everyone full of fear. The new Covid variant will kill you if you leave your house. Hyperinflation is on the way so brace for global economic collapse. Fear creates stagnation. Here's the good news: stagnation for everyone else creates opportunity for you. The world is changing as rapidly as it did during the beginning of the industrial revolution. This new knowledge revolution is actually reversing the industrial revolution where everything became centralized. Today everything from financial services to space travel is being decentralized. Blockchain technology is disrupting banking and even government controlled finance. Fueled by the pandemic, virtual and augmented reality is coming quicker than anyone originally thought. It will disrupt the office, travel, real estate development and life as we know it. Artificial intelligence may never truly replace the creative brain, but it will replace factory lines, distribution workers and even delivery drivers. Space travel is no longer being led by government initiatives. Instead, it's being challenged by private companies. Energy is becoming cheaper to harness as the cost of solar technologies trend downward like flat screen televisions and we see more electric vehicles at every stoplight. The media landscape has been changing for a decade and we now enter a new phase where a single person with a microphone can double the audience of a global media titan. Any one of these disruptions will change our world, but when combined they will change humanity itself. As the world changes and central power from historical authority is decentralized this generation has more opportunity than any generation before. You can invest in cryptocurrency. You can create a business capitalizing on one of these emerging technologies. Or you can simply grab a microphone. The possibilities are endless. The aliens could arrive or maybe our future selves shut down the simulation before any of this happens (I’m kidding, sorta). Until then I recommend picking up The Price of Tomorrow - Why Deflation Is The Key To An Abundant Future, by Jeff Booth. Booth does an excellent job explaining many of these changing factors. I’ve posted a full book review here. Have a phenomenal week full of Positive Vibes.

Title: The One Opportunity That Creates Hundreds More
Content: I’m loving this painting sent to me by my new mentor Mark Evans DM] . He, along with the 30+ men in our mastermind group, are changing the way my mind works. Honestly, I thought I was a big thinker. I thought I was doing big things. Then I met these guys. The Internet has given you an opportunity you may not realize you have. A single opportunity that brings hundreds of subsequent opportunities. You have the ability to find killers who are willing to be your mentor and entrepreneurs doing things much bigger than you who are willing to give you their advice. I started with a local entrepreneur group. It’s subdivided into smaller groups of 6-8. The folks in my “forum” have become my closest confidents. Their advice has been invaluable. They’ve helped me through dark times and celebrated with me during great ones. Last year I joined a national group, the DM Family led by Mark Evans DM] . The men in this group have me thinking at a level I didn’t know was even possible. In just five months I’ve taken a deeper dive into crypto and started a new business. I think this group alone is going to one day make me millions of dollars. Both of these groups cost money but you can also find groups for free. Just know that you get what you pay for. You are not alone in your journey. I went alone for over a decade and then found myself stagnant, no matter how hard I worked. I truly believed that it was about hustle alone. I could run my way to success. I quickly learned that I was often running backwards or sideways instead of running toward the finish line. Find yourself a mentor and a mastermind group. It’s an opportunity sitting right in front of you and one that opens the door to many more.  Take Massive Action today!

Title: Do Your Quarterly SWOT Analysis
Content: Our new office is simply spectacular. The delays created a lot of frustration but the wait was worth it. The wait also forced me to face one of my biggest weaknesses. It is important to do a self analysis, specifically a SWOT analysis, throughout the year. I do one each quarter. SWOT stands for: Strengths Weaknesses Opportunities Threats This is how we approach each client and each situation. It is also how I approach my own self improvement. I attempt to firm up my strengths, strengthen my weaknesses, deflect potential threats and rapidly take advantage of opportunities. My biggest weakness is impatience. Like Veruca Salt “I want it now.”  Building out the new Push office as well as the new Frothy Beard location in 2021 while also dealing with every COVID delay possible may have finally fixed this weakness. Now about 763 other weaknesses to tackle. Perhaps this is something you can try in your life. Draw a quadrant diagram and label the quadrants S, W, O, T. Then just start listing. It’s that simple. If you’re in downtown Charleston I would love for you to stop in and see the new place. We are at 343 East Bay St. Just give me a heads up first. Have a great day full of Positive Vibes! @melissaervininteriordesign

Title: Put In The Work and Do What Others Won’t
Content:
I have a lot of notches in my win column, but one race always stands out - Shane Massey for South Carolina State Senate. It wasn’t the biggest and it wasn’t the sexiest. It was, however, the one that allowed me to level up from political operative to political consultant. It was 2007, and the Democrat who held the seat resigned to take a big paying Washington job. There weren’t many people who thought Republicans could pick up the seat with a 41% BVAP (Black Voting Age Population). It wasn’t a safe Democrat seat but it was so difficult that most Republicans wrote it off. Even the folks I worked for at the time wrote it off. They actually refused to let me work for Shane because they didn’t want the L. Eventually, they conceded after I threatened to do the race in my spare time.  I wanted the race so badly because I knew Shane was different. He was only 32, just five years older than me, and I could sense a work ethic in him that I hadn’t seen in other candidates. I told him exactly what he needed to do to win, and he didn’t hesitate to trust me. He explained his high values and told me that he would follow my lead as long as I didn’t ask him to do anything shady. He did precisely that. Shane Massey surprised everyone for two reasons:
  1. He outworked everyone.
In both the special primary and general elections, and then again immediately in the normal elections, Shane worked harder than anyone he was up against. He knocked on every door and made every call sent to him. Eventually, I told Shane to not even leave his house. I said, “I don’t care if you even get out of your pajamas or take a shower. Just call everyone on this list.” It was thousands of people. He just sat there for hours at a time and called all day, day after day.  No excuses. No refusals. He just did the work.
  1. He did what others wouldn’t.
Republicans in the South typically write off African American voters. The demographic is reliably Democratic, so using limited money and time is generally targeted to those swing voters a candidate can actually persuade. Shane didn’t agree, and neither did I. Shane did something you rarely see Republicans do. He knocked on the doors of African Americans. He called African Americans. He went to NAACP meetings. He visited black churches. I don’t remember exactly what the number was, but to win by the margins we got on Election Day, Shane would have needed about 14% of black voters. That just doesn’t happen.  But it does if you’re as nice a person as Shane Massey. I’ll take some credit for this win. I developed the strategy and told Shane what he should do. But this win was because of grit. To this day, I’ve never advised a person who worked as hard as Shane Massey. I’m proud that he’s my friend and now the Majority Leader of the South Carolina Senate. These lessons aren’t just limited to political campaigns. You have an opportunity to win if you are willing to put in the world and do what others won’t.

Title: Winners Don’t Get Sidetracked By Shiny Objects
Content:
TWO HUNDRED MILLION DOLLARS flooded South Carolina when national Democrats wrongly thought they could take out United States Senator Lindsey Graham. Our team had the financial resources to run the perfect digital campaign we’ve always dreamed of for the first time ever. So you would think that was my favorite campaign of 2020. Nope! My favorite campaign was the re-election of SC State Senator Chip Campsen. However, a lot of it was because of that big US Senate race. The cluttered airwaves forced me to get creative in developing a strategy that would grab the voters’ attention. Nationally we are considered one of the best GOP digital agencies. In South Carolina, I still do a lot of general consulting, meaning I oversee the entire campaign. Last cycle, I had the privilege of serving as SC Senator Chip Campsen’s GC while Push Digital oversaw all media.  Senator Campsen has represented South Carolina’s 43rd district since 2004, but he had an incredibly low name ID for two primary reasons. First, the district has grown by leaps and bounds with an incredible population boom, resulting in thousands of new voters. Second, Senator Campsen has not had opposition since the district was redrawn ten years ago. The district is long and skinny, encompassing a full half of South Carolina’s coast, making it difficult to campaign in, especially during COVID-19 lockdowns.  The district has been trending blue (or at least purple), as seen with the election of Democratic Congressman Joe Cunningham in 2018. Polls showed President Trump upside down in the district. The biggest problem was the national attention on our state. Not only did the two US Senate races clutter the airwaves, but they were joined by every big SuperPAC and DC Committee. On top of that, the district was also covered up by a top targeted congressional race. In all my career, I had never seen everything so cluttered. Televisions, every digital platform, local newspapers… I mean everything!  How do you get a message out when you can barely even buy an ad? How do you cut through the clutter? You do it by getting hyper-local. You use data to deliver niche messages to smaller audiences. Through polling we discovered that both national and state issues moved voters, but what cut through the clutter were hyper-focused issues important to each local community in the highly spread-out district. Yes, we used broadcast and cable television to deliver a big picture message across the Charleston and Savannah DMAs. Still, half the resources were used to target local communities. We talked to Isle of Palms about tree cutting and parking meters. Edisto Beach cared about beach erosion. Kiawah Island cared about bobcats. Yes, bobcats. Poison was used to kill rats, bobcats ate the rats, and a local treasure was dying off.  Luckily I had a client in Senator Campsen who worked incredibly hard on local issues instead of getting sucked into the camera chasing gimmicks of national issues. Senator Campsen didn’t get sidetracked by shiny objects. He always focused on what moves the ball furthest down the field for his constituents. Everyone thought this would be a close race. The State Democrats thought this was a pickup, and they poured a ton of money into it. In the end, we won by 14 points.  There are some lessons here for you:
  1. There is a lot of opportunity in targeting smaller audiences using data and niche creative. You don’t have to target everyone to win. Find the people who matter with the message that cuts through the clutter. This is true across all marketing verticals.
  2. Winners focus on what moves the ball down the field, and they don’t get sidetracked by shiny objects. Figure out your goals and which KPIs (key performance indicators) matter most. Ignore everything else.
